choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase
Increased advanced glycation end products

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual presents with signs of premature aging, including graying hair, wrinkled skin, and cataracts. Genetic testing reveals a condition known as Werner syndrome. What is the underlying cause of Werner syndrome with premature aging?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

 

  • Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. The etiology of Werner syndrome involves mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a RecQ helicase protein.
  • This helicase is essential for maintaining the stability of DNA and proper telomere maintenance.
  • The loss of helicase activity leads to DNA damage and the shortening of telomeres, contributing to the accelerated aging observed in Werner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased length of telomere: Increased telomere length is typically associated with enhanced cellular longevity and is not a cause of Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. Increased advanced glycation end products: While these products are associated with aging and diabetes complications, they are not the primary cause of Werner syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased lipid peroxidation: This is not related to the pathogenesis of Werner syndrome. Lipid peroxidation refers to oxidative degradation of lipids, which is more associated with oxidative stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Werner syndrome, characterized by premature aging, is caused by mutations in the WRN gene leading to short telomeres, damaged DNA, and loss of helicase activity.

choices.text: Superior Sagittal Sinus

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with headaches and symptoms suggestive of increased intracranial pressure. Imaging studies reveal impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage. Which venous sinus is most involved in the reabsorption of CSF due to the presence of the greatest number of arachnoid granulations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior Sagittal Sinus

 

  • The superior sagittal sinus runs along the midline at the top of the brain within the falx cerebri.
  • It is the primary site for the drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) via numerous arachnoid granulations.
  • These granulations protrude into the sinus, facilitating the reabsorption of CSF into the venous system, which is essential for maintaining normal intracranial pressure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous Sinus: Located on either side of the sella turcica, the cavernous sinus receives venous blood from the ophthalmic veins and other small veins but is not the primary site for drainage of arachnoid granulations.

 

Option B. Sigmoid Sinus: This sinus is a continuation of the transverse sinus and drains blood from the brain into the internal jugular vein. It does not receive significant drainage from arachnoid granulations.

 

Option C. Straight Sinus: Found at the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli, the straight sinus receives blood from the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein (vein of Galen). While it participates in venous drainage, it does not have the highest number of arachnoid granulations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The superior sagittal sinus is the major site of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reabsorption due to the presence of numerous arachnoid granulations, playing a crucial role in regulating intracranial pressure.

questions.text: An adult patient presents with generalized lymphadenopathy, and a blood film shows 70% immature-looking lymphocytes. What should be the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunophenotyping

 

  • Immunophenotyping is the next best investigation in a patient with generalized lymphadenopathy and a high percentage of immature lymphocytes on blood film.
  • This test involves using flow cytometry to analyze the expression of specific cell surface markers on the lymphocytes.
  • It helps in differentiating between different types of lymphoid malignancies, such as acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL), and other lymphoproliferative disorders.
  • By determining the specific immunophenotype, clinicians can make an accurate diagnosis and guide appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genotyping/karyotyping: While genotyping and karyotyping are important for identifying specific genetic abnormalities associated with certain leukaemiaâ€™s and lymphomas, they are typically performed after the initial diagnosis is established by immunophenotyping.

 

Option C. Bone marrow: A bone marrow examination can provide valuable information about the extent of disease involvement and help in staging the disease. However, it is usually performed after immunophenotyping has suggested a specific diagnosis that requires further confirmation and staging.

 

Option D. Peripheral smear study: A peripheral smear has already been performed, revealing 70% immature lymphocytes. While the smear provides important initial information, it cannot differentiate between different types of lymphoid malignancies. Therefore, further investigation with immunophenotyping is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the evaluation of a patient with generalized lymphadenopathy and a high percentage of immature lymphocytes on blood film, immunophenotyping is the next best investigation to accurately diagnose the specific type of lymphoid malignancy and guide appropriate treatment.
  • It identifies cell surface markers (CD markers) to:
    • Distinguish between B-cell and T-cell lineage
    • Differentiate CLL vs. ALL vs. lymphoma spillover
    • Confirm whether the cells are monoclonal (malignant) or polyclonal (reactive)
    • Immunophenotyping is the gold standard for classifying lymphoid malignancies

choices.text: Organism typically affects the colon
The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man
The treatment of choice is metronidazole
The aspirate shows “sterile pus” on microscopy

questions.text: A 42-year-old male had visited Mumbai a few months back. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for a few days on returning, which subsided on its own. He now presents with right upper abdominal pain, low grade fever, and weight loss. On examination, the patient shows pallor and tender hepatomegaly. Ultrasound shows fluid collection in liver with necrotic debris. What is incorrect about this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man.

 

  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of amoebic liver abscess. It's caused by the parasite Entamoeba Histolytica. Its entire life cycle is in man.
  • The life cycle is partly in sheep and partly in man:  This statement is incorrect. Entamoeba histolytica's life cycle is entirely within humans, who are the definitive hosts. Sheep are not involved in the life cycle of this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organism typically affects the colon: This is correct. Entamoeba histolytica primarily infects the colon and can cause amebic dysentery, but it can also spread to the liver to form an abscess.

 

Option C. The treatment of choice is metronidazole:  This is correct. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for invasive amoebiasis, and diloxanide furoate is used as a luminal agent to eliminate intraluminal cysts. Chloroquine may be used adjunctively for the treatment of amebic liver abscesses, particularly when metronidazole alone is insufficient.

 

Option D. The aspirate shows “sterile pus” on microscopy:  This is correct. Aspirates from an amebic liver abscess typically do not show bacteria when cultured, hence the term "sterile pus." The aspirate is often described as looking like "anchovy sauce" due to the presence of necrotic liver tissue and blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Entamoeba histolytica is the causative agent of amebic liver abscess, with a life cycle that occurs exclusively in humans, not sheep.
  • The treatment includes metronidazole, often combined with other agents like chloroquine and diloxanide furoate, and the condition is characterized by "sterile pus" in the liver abscess aspirate.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgical resection for a pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone, but the surgery did not fully remove the tumor. What is the first-line treatment to manage the residual disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

  • Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of several hormones, including growth hormone (GH).
  • It is particularly effective in the management of acromegaly, a condition resulting from excess GH, typically due to a pituitary adenoma.
  • Octreotide reduces the levels of GH and is often used when surgical treatment is inadequate or in patients who cannot undergo surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide:  This is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, primarily used in the treatment of hormone-responsive cancers such as prostate cancer and in conditions like endometriosis. It is not effective in reducing GH levels.

 

Option B. Goserelin:  Another GnRH agonist similar to leuprolide, used for the same indications and also not suitable for treating excess GH production.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Also a GnRH agonist, used for endometriosis and central precocious puberty, not for acromegaly or GH excess.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions:

 

Mnemonic – SOMATostatin

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPoms, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

choices.text: Left optic tract
Right visual cortex
Right optic nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. On examination, visual field testing confirms right homonymous hemianopia. Where is the lesion likely located in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left optic tract

 

  • A lesion in the left optic tract results in right homonymous hemianopia, which is the loss of vision in the right halves of the visual fields of both eyes.
  • This occurs because the optic tract contains fibers from the contralateral visual field.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: A lesion in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, affecting the left halves of the visual fields of both eyes. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: A lesion at the optic chiasma typically causes bitemporal hemianopia, characterized by loss of the outer visual fields in both eyes, due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not affecting the left eye. This would not present as right homonymous hemianopia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Match the following: Mapleson circuits

 

Column A

  1. Mapleson circuit of choice for controlled ventilation in adults
  2. Mapleson circuit of choice for controlled ventilation in children
  3. Mapleson circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation in adults
  4. Water’s to and fro circuit

 

Column B

  1. Mapleson F
  2. Mapleson C
  3. Mapleson A
  4. Mapleson D
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-c, 4-b

 

1-d The Mapleson D circuit is preferred for controlled ventilation in adults.

2-a The Mapleson F circuit (also known as the Jackson-Rees modification) is used for controlled ventilation in children.

3-c The Mapleson A circuit is the best for spontaneous ventilation in adults.

4-b The Water’s to-and-fro circuit corresponds to the Mapleson C circuit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mapleson D circuit is preferred for controlled ventilation in adults, Mapleson F for controlled ventilation in children, Mapleson A for spontaneous ventilation in adults, and Mapleson C corresponds to the Water’s to-and-fro circuit.

choices.text: Acute hepatitis B
Chronic hepatitis B
Acute Hepatitis C
Hepatitis B Window period

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below?

 

  • Anti-HBc (Total): Positive
  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Negative
  • HBsAg: Negative
  • Anti-HBs: Positive
  • Anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Hepatitis C

 

  • The patient's serology reports show positive Anti-HCV, indicating exposure to hepatitis C virus (HCV).
  • Additionally, the absence of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) and positive Anti-HBs (hepatitis B surface antibody) suggest no evidence of current or past hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection.
  • The negative Anti-HBc IgM further supports the absence of acute hepatitis B. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis is acute hepatitis. Anti-HBc (Total): Positive and Anti-HBc (IgM): Negative indicate that it is a resolved Hepatitis B.
  • This is the correct option. The positive Anti-HCV indicates exposure to HCV, and the absence of markers for hepatitis B infection supports the diagnosis of acute hepatitis C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute hepatitis B: This option is incorrect because the serology findings do not support acute hepatitis B. The absence of HBsAg and the presence of Anti-HBs indicate no active HBV infection, and the negative Anti-HBc IgM further suggests the absence of acute HBV infection.

 

Option B. Chronic hepatitis B: This option is incorrect as the serology reports do not indicate chronic hepatitis B. The absence of HBsAg and the presence of Anti-HBs suggest resolved or past HBV infection, rather than chronic infection.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B Window period: This option is incorrect. The serology findings do not suggest the hepatitis B window period. The presence of Anti-HBs and absence of HBsAg and Anti-HBc IgM indicate either resolved HBV infection or immunity to HBV, rather than the window period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with fever, jaundice, and malaise, serological testing plays a crucial role in determining the etiology of hepatitis.
  • In this case, the presence of positive Anti-HCV, absence of HBsAg, and positive Anti-HBs suggest acute hepatitis C as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a swelling in her neck, which has been progressively enlarging over the past few months. On examination, the swelling is found to be located in the region of the thyroid gland. Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sternothyroid

 

  • The sternothyroid muscle plays a crucial role in preventing the upward extension of a thyroid swelling.
  • This muscle attaches to the thyroid cartilage, creating a physical barrier that limits the upward movement of the thyroid gland.
  • When the thyroid gland enlarges, such as in goiter or other thyroid pathologies, its superior extension is restricted by the sternothyroid muscle's attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland and other structures in the anterior part of the neck, but it does not specifically prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: The thyrohyoid membrane connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone. While it is involved in the movement and stability of these structures, it does not directly prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: The Ligament of Berry attaches the thyroid gland to the trachea and helps maintain its position in the neck. It is not primarily responsible for preventing the upward extension of thyroid swelling.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The sternothyroid muscle prevents the upward extension of a thyroid swelling due to its attachment to the thyroid cartilage, creating a physical barrier that limits the superior movement of the thyroid gland.

choices.text: Acute on chronic Type 2 respiratory failure

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with increasing shortness of breath and lethargy over the past three days. He reports a productive cough with yellow sputum. On examination, he is found to have diminished breath sounds and wheezing. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results are as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 

 

  • pH: 7.28
  • pCO2: 50 mmHg
  • HCO3-: 32 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute on chronic Type 2 respiratory failure

 

  • The patient's presentation and arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate that he is experiencing an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
  • COPD can lead to chronic Type 2 respiratory failure, characterized by chronic hypercapnia (elevated pCO2) and compensated metabolic alkalosis (elevated HCO3-). In this case:
  1. pH: 7.28 - This indicates acidemia.
  2. pCO2: 50 mmHg - Elevated pCO2, indicating hypercapnia.
  3. HCO3-: 32 mEq/L - Elevated bicarbonate, suggesting chronic compensation.
  • The combination of an elevated pCO2 and elevated HCO3- with a low pH suggests that this patient has chronic Type 2 respiratory failure with an acute exacerbation.
  • Chronic Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by chronically elevated pCO2 with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.
  • The current acidemia (low pH) indicates that the patient is experiencing an acute worsening of his chronic condition, leading to "acute on chronic Type 2 respiratory failure."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Type 2 respiratory failure: Acute Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by sudden onset hypercapnia (elevated pCO2) with acidemia (low pH). There would be no time for metabolic compensation (elevated HCO3-) in an acute setting, so bicarbonate levels would remain normal. This does not match the patient's presentation with elevated HCO3-.

 

Option B. Chronic Type 2 respiratory failure: Chronic Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by chronic hypercapnia (elevated pCO2) with compensatory metabolic alkalosis (elevated HCO3-), maintaining a near-normal pH. The patient's current low pH indicates an acute exacerbation rather than a stable chronic condition.

 

Option D. Acute Type 1 respiratory failure: Acute Type 1 respiratory failure is characterized by hypoxemia (low PaO2) without hypercapnia (normal or low pCO2). This does not fit the patient's ABG results showing elevated pCO2.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • "Acute on chronic Type 2 respiratory failure" is characterized by a patient with chronic hypercapnia and compensatory metabolic alkalosis experiencing an acute exacerbation leading to a drop in pH (acidemia), as seen in the elevated pCO2 and HCO3- levels with a low pH in the ABG results.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who received a kidney transplant 2 years ago and has been on chronic immunosuppressive therapy, presents with multiple hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Biopsy of one lesion confirms malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

 

  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is the most common malignancy seen in post-transplant patients due to chronic immunosuppression, particularly in sun-exposed areas, matching the presentation described.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. PTLD: Refers to a range of lymphoid proliferations that can occur following transplantation due to immunosuppression. However, it does not present with hyperkeratotic skin lesions.

 

Option C. Leukaemia: It can occur in the post-transplant setting but would not present with localized skin lesions.

 

Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma: It can occur in transplant patients but typically presents as violaceous plaques or nodules and is less common than squamous cell carcinoma in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignancy seen post-transplant in patients on immunosuppressive therapy is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, often occurring on sun-exposed areas.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is considering using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for birth control. During her medical evaluation, the healthcare provider needs to identify any absolute contraindications to OCP use. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to the use of OCPs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thromboembolism

 

  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are widely used for birth control but have certain absolute contraindications due to the risk of severe adverse effects.
  • Thromboembolism is a condition in which blood clots form in blood vessels and can travel to vital organs, causing serious complications.
  • OCPs, particularly those containing estrogen, increase the risk of thromboembolic events.
  • Therefore, a history of thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of OCPs because of the significant risk of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic renal disease: While chronic renal disease requires careful management and monitoring when using OCPs, it is not an absolute contraindication. Patients with renal disease should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis.

 

Option B. History of amenorrhea: Amenorrhea, or the absence of menstruation, is not an absolute contraindication for the use of OCPs. In some cases, OCPs are even used to help regulate menstrual cycles in women with amenorrhea.

 

Option D. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication for OCP use. However, women with diabetes, especially those with vascular complications, should be carefully monitored while using OCPs due to potential risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of oral contraceptive pills due to the increased risk of blood clot formation associated with these medications.

questions.text: The STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) utilized by the World Health Organization includes various measurements to assess chronic disease risk factors. Which of the following is included only in the EXPANDED component of the STEPS approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measurement of hip circumference

 

  • Measurement of hip circumference, is correct as it is included only in the EXPANDED component of the STEPwise approach to surveillance. The expanded component involves additional measurements that provide a broader understanding of risk factors, which include hip circumference and heart rate, not typically measured in the core component.
  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
  • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
  • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measurement of blood glucose: Incorrect because blood glucose is measured in both the CORE and EXPANDED components of the STEPS approach.

 

Option B. Measurement of blood pressure (BP): Incorrect as blood pressure is also measured in both the CORE and EXPANDED components.

 

Option D. Measurement of height and weight: Incorrect because these measurements are part of the CORE component and are fundamental to the initial risk factor assessment in STEPS.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of hypertension is being evaluated for safe antihypertensive treatment options during her pregnancy. Which of the following antihypertensives is generally not recommended for use during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol

 

  • Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is generally not recommended during pregnancy due to its potential adverse effects on both the mother and fetus.
  • Non-selective beta-blockers can restrict fetal growth and cause fetal bradycardia, hypoglycemia, and respiratory depression at birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha methyldopa: Often considered the first-line treatment for hypertension in pregnancy due to its long track record of safety and efficacy.

 

Option B. Hydralazine: Commonly used as a direct vasodilator in the management of hypertension during pregnancy, especially in acute settings.

 

Option D. Labetalol: A mixed alpha/beta-blocker, it is preferred over pure beta-blockers like propranolol due to its additional vasodilatory properties that make it safer and more effective during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antihypertensive to be avoided in pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

choices.text: Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells
Tumor cells in lymphatic channels
The number of mitoses per high power field

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging mass in her thigh. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma. To determine the malignant potential and prognosis of this tumor, which of the following histological criteria is most important?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The number of mitoses per high power field

 

  • The mitotic rate, measured as the number of mitoses per high power field (HPF), is the most important histological criterion for assessing the malignant potential of leiomyosarcomas.
  • A high mitotic rate is directly correlated with aggressive tumor behavior, higher grade, and worse prognosis.
  • It reflects the proliferative activity of the tumor cells, which is a key factor in determining the aggressiveness of the sarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells: Although invasion into blood vessels can indicate potential for metastasis and aggressive behavior, it is not the primary criterion used to assess the malignancy of leiomyosarcomas.

 

Option B. Lymphocyte infiltration: Lymphocyte infiltration can be a response to the tumor but does not directly correlate with the malignant potential or grading of leiomyosarcomas. It is more indicative of an immune response to the tumor.

 

Option C. Tumor cells in lymphatic channels: The presence of tumor cells in lymphatic channels can indicate lymphatic spread, but this is less common in leiomyosarcomas compared to other cancers and is not the main criterion for assessing malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mitotic rate, or the number of mitoses per high power field, is the most important histological criterion for determining the malignant behavior and prognosis of leiomyosarcomas.
  • A higher mitotic rate indicates a more aggressive and malignant tumor.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with headaches and seizures. MRI reveals a mass in the brain. A biopsy of the mass shows the presence of glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). Which of the following tumors is most likely to be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Astrocytoma

 

  • Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is an intermediate filament protein that is specifically expressed in astrocytes.
  • Astrocytomas are glial tumors derived from astrocytes, and they characteristically express GFAP.
  • The presence of GFAP in a brain tumor biopsy is highly indicative of an astrocytoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ependymoma: Ependymomas are tumors arising from ependymal cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. While they may occasionally express GFAP, it is not as characteristic or definitive as it is for astrocytoma.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastomas are primitive neuroectodermal tumors that primarily occur in the cerebellum. They do not typically express GFAP, as they are derived from neuronal progenitor cells rather than glial cells.

 

Option D. All of the above: While some ependymomas may express GFAP, medulloblastomas do not, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is specifically expressed in astrocytes, and its presence in a brain tumor biopsy is most indicative of an astrocytoma.
  • Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) is:
    • An intermediate filament protein
    • Specifically expressed in astrocytes, a type of glial cell
    • Used as a marker to identify tumors of astrocytic lineage

choices.text: Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic and is seeking advice on contraceptive methods that can be used after unprotected intercourse. Which of the following is NOT used as a post-coital contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Danazol

 

  • Post-coital contraceptive methods, also known as emergency contraceptives, are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure.
  • These methods include hormonal pills and intrauterine devices.
  • Danazol is not used as a post-coital contraceptive. It is a synthetic steroid used primarily in the treatment of endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease.
  • It does not have the necessary properties to prevent pregnancy when taken after intercourse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CuT200: The CuT200 is a copper intrauterine device (IUD) that can be inserted up to five days after unprotected intercourse. It is highly effective as an emergency contraceptive by creating a hostile environment for sperm and preventing fertilization.

 

Option C. RU486 (Mifepristone): RU486, also known as Mifepristone, can be used as an emergency contraceptive. It works by blocking progesterone receptors, thus preventing the continuation of a pregnancy. It is effective when used within a few days after unprotected intercourse.

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: These are also known as the Yuzpe regimen. When taken in high doses shortly after unprotected intercourse, they can prevent pregnancy by delaying ovulation, inhibiting fertilization, or preventing implantation.


 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Danazol is not used as a post-coital contraceptive. Emergency contraceptive methods include copper IUDs, Mifepristone, and combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills.

choices.text: Focal laser photocoagulation
Grid laser photocoagulation

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of decreased vision in the right eye. The visual acuity in the affected eye is 6/9. Fundoscopic examination reveals pre-retinal hemorrhages and neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the standard treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), especially with high-risk characteristics such as pre-retinal hemorrhages and neovascularization at the optic disc.
  • PRP works by reducing the ischemic drive for neovascularization by ablating peripheral retinal tissue, thereby preserving central vision.

 

                 Pan-retinal Photocoagulation

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

 

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is typically used to treat macular edema by targeting specific areas of leakage, rather than the widespread retinal ischemia seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is used for treating diffuse macular edema, not for managing proliferative diabetic retinopathy with neovascularization at the optic disc.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to treat retinal detachment, not proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It involves placing a silicone band around the eye to indent the sclera and relieve traction on the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics, such as pre-retinal hemorrhages and neovascularization at the optic disc, the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

Indications for PRP are:

 

  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
  • Poor compliance for follow up
  • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
  • Renal failure
  • One-eyed patient
  • Pregnancy

 

  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. On examination, he is stable with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15/15. His pupils are reactive to light. There is tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechiae. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) eFAST

 

  • The eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) examination is a rapid bedside ultrasound scan used in trauma settings to assess for the presence of free fluid (hemoperitoneum) in the abdomen, hemothorax, pneumothorax, and cardiac tamponade.
  • Given the patient's vital signs and physical findings, which include hypotension and signs of potential chest and abdominal trauma, an eFAST scan is the most appropriate immediate next step.
  • It can quickly identify life-threatening injuries that require urgent intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory Laparotomy: This invasive procedure is indicated if there is strong evidence of intra-abdominal injury requiring surgical intervention. However, without further diagnostic imaging to confirm such injuries, it is not the first step.

 

Option B. Intubation: The patient is currently stable with a GCS score of 15/15, indicating that he is fully conscious and has a patent airway. Intubation is not immediately necessary.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): While a CECT scan is useful for detailed imaging of injuries, it requires a more stable hemodynamic status and is typically performed after an initial assessment with eFAST. Given the patient's hypotension, a rapid bedside assessment is prioritized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of trauma with hypotension and signs of potential thoracoabdominal injury, an eFAST scan is a critical initial step to quickly identify life-threatening injuries and guide further management.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue. She is being evaluated for possible insulin secretion dysfunction. Blood tests confirm elevated blood glucose levels. Which of the following plays a crucial role in the release of insulin when blood glucose levels are elevated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ATP Sensitive K+ Channels

 

  • The release of insulin in response to elevated blood glucose levels is a complex and tightly regulated process. When blood glucose levels rise, glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through the GLUT2 transporter. The subsequent steps are as follows:
  1. Glycolysis and ATP Production: Inside the beta cells, glucose undergoes glycolysis and subsequent metabolic processes, leading to an increase in intracellular ATP.
  2. ATP Sensitive K+ Channels: The increase in the ATP/ADP ratio causes ATP-sensitive potassium (Kâº) channels to close. This closure depolarizes the beta cell membrane.
  3. Calcium Influx: Depolarization opens voltage-gated calcium channels, allowing Ca²âº to enter the cell.
  4. Insulin Secretion: The influx of Ca²âº triggers the exocytosis of insulin-containing granules, releasing insulin into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Receptor Phosphorylation: While important in many signaling pathways, receptor phosphorylation is not directly involved in the primary mechanism of glucose-mediated insulin release.

 

Option C. cAMP: cAMP is involved in various signaling pathways but does not play a primary role in glucose-mediated insulin release.

 

Option D. Carrier Modulators: These proteins do not play a central role in the direct mechanism of insulin release in response to elevated glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ATP-sensitive Kâº channels are crucial in the process of glucose-mediated insulin release.
  • The closure of these channels in response to increased intracellular ATP leads to cell membrane depolarization, calcium influx, and subsequent insulin secretion.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, deep rapid breathing, and a fruity odor on his breath. Laboratory investigations reveal the following results. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • Glucose: 550 mg/dL
  • Sodium: 122 mEq/L
  • Osmolality: 310 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones: ++++
  • Serum bicarbonate: 10 mEq/L
  • Arterial pH: 7.1
  • Arterial pCO2: 25 mmHg
  • Anion gap: Elevated
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)

 

  • DKA is characterized by the presence of hyperglycemia (glucose levels typically between 250-600 mg/dL), low serum bicarbonate (<15 mEq/L), low arterial pH (6.8-7.3), elevated anion gap, and the presence of significant ketones in the blood and urine.
  • Clinical features often include abdominal pain, Kussmaul respirations, and a fruity odor on the breath due to acetone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS): HHS typically occurs in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and is characterized by severe hyperglycemia (glucose levels of 600-1200 mg/dL), normal to slightly low serum bicarbonate, normal arterial pH (>7.3), high osmolality (330-380 mOsm/kg), and the absence or low levels of ketones. Patients often present with altered sensorium and coma.

 

Option C. Normal Metabolic State: The laboratory values and clinical presentation in this case are not consistent with a normal state.

 

Option D. Lactic Acidosis: Lactic acidosis is characterized by an elevated lactate level and often presents with metabolic acidosis. However, it typically does not present with significant hyperglycemia or elevated ketones unless it is secondary to another condition like DKA. The primary indicators in this case point towards DKA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is identified by high blood glucose, low serum bicarbonate, low arterial pH, elevated anion gap, and significant ketonemia.
  • It often presents with symptoms such as abdominal pain, deep rapid breathing (Kussmaul respirations), and a fruity odor on the breath.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl with a history of recurrent otitis media with effusion is scheduled for an adenoidectomy with grommet insertion. Postoperatively, she develops nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech. Which of the following is the most likely complication responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Velopharyngeal insufficiency

 

  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) is a condition where there is an inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter (the soft palate muscle that closes off the nasopharynx during speech and swallowing).
  • This results in nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech due to air escaping through the nose during phonation.
  • This complication can occur after adenoidectomy, particularly in patients with a predisposing anatomical weakness or submucous cleft palate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal stenosis: Nasopharyngeal stenosis involves the narrowing of the nasopharyngeal space, which can cause nasal obstruction and difficulty breathing through the nose, but it is unlikely to cause nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech.

 

Option C. Eustachian tube dysfunction: Eustachian tube dysfunction can lead to middle ear problems, such as otitis media with effusion or hearing loss. However, it does not cause nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech.

 

Option D. Middle ear effusion recurrence: While recurrence of middle ear effusion can occur postoperatively, it primarily causes hearing issues and discomfort but does not lead to nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) is the most likely complication responsible for nasal regurgitation of fluids and hypernasal speech following an adenoidectomy, due to inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter during swallowing and speaking.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a body found in an ancient tomb (located in a very hot and dry place) that is remarkably preserved. Considering the state of preservation, which characteristic best describes the odor of the body?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

  • A preserved body in hot and dry environment is likely to be due to mummification.
  •  A mummified body is typically odorless because the process of mummification involves dehydration or drying out of tissues, which prevents the typical decay processes that cause odors.
  • This lack of moisture inhibits bacterial growth, which is responsible for the generation of foul smells in decomposing bodies.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Pungent: Incorrect because pungent smells are usually strong and sharp, associated with chemical reactions, not typical of dry, mummified remains.
 

Option C. Putrid: Incorrect as putrid smells are associated with the decomposition of organic matter under moist conditions, which does not apply to mummified bodies.
 

Option D. Offensive: Incorrect since offensive odors generally arise from decaying tissue in the presence of moisture, which is not a condition found in mummification.

 

Educational Objective:


Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture and bacterial activity, contrasting with the odors associated with different stages of body decomposition under more typical environmental conditions.

questions.text: Which of these is a common opioid used in TIVA due to its short duration of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remifentanil

 

  • Remifentanil is a potent, ultra-short-acting opioid commonly used in Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset and quick offset, allowing for precise control over sedation levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol:  Propofol is a short-acting sedative-hypnotic agent used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, but it is not an opioid. It provides rapid onset and recovery but lacks analgesic properties.

 

Option C. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a potent opioid used in anesthesia and pain management. It has a relatively longer duration of action compared to remifentanil, making it less ideal for TIVA where rapid titration is needed.

 

Option D. Remimazolam: Remimazolam is a benzodiazepine used for sedation and procedural anesthesia, not an opioid. It offers quick onset and recovery but lacks the analgesic effects provided by opioids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Remifentanil is the opioid of choice for TIVA due to its ultra-short duration of action, enabling fine-tuned control over anesthesia depth and rapid recovery post-procedure.

choices.text: Passive filling of right atrium
Passive emptying of right atrium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure presents with worsening dyspnea and lower extremity edema. On physical examination, his jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated, and you observe a prominent 'c' wave. What does the 'c' wave of the JVP represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tricuspid bulge into right atrium

 

  • The 'c' wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • During this phase of the cardiac cycle, the right ventricle contracts while all the heart valves are closed, leading to an increase in intraventricular pressure.
  • This pressure causes the tricuspid valve to bulge slightly into the right atrium, creating the 'c' wave observed in the JVP.
  • The 'c' wave is a transient event and is part of the complex waveform seen in jugular venous pressure tracing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contraction of right atrium: This event is represented by the 'a' wave of the JVP, which occurs just before the 'c' wave. The 'a' wave reflects atrial contraction, leading to a brief increase in atrial pressure.

 

Option B. Passive filling of right atrium: This occurs during ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve is closed and venous blood returns to the right atrium, creating the 'v' wave. It is not related to the 'c' wave.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: This occurs when the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, allowing blood to flow passively from the right atrium to the right ventricle. This phase is represented by the 'y' descent in the JVP and is not related to the 'c' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 'c' wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a complaint of facial muscle weakness on one side of her face. She has a history of recurrent ear infections and mild hearing loss. On examination, you note paralysis of the muscles of facial expression on the affected side. Which of the following nerves, associated with the second pharyngeal (branchial) arch, is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial nerve

 

  • The second pharyngeal arch, also known as the hyoid arch, gives rise to several structures in the head and neck.
  • One of the key components derived from the second pharyngeal arch is the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).
  • The facial nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of facial expression, the stapedius muscle in the middle ear, and providing taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Additionally, the second pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the stapes bone in the middle ear, the styloid process, and part of the hyoid bone.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is associated with the first pharyngeal arch. It innervates the muscles of mastication and provides sensory innervation to the face, oral cavity, and nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is associated with the third pharyngeal arch, not the second. It provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle and sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue and the pharynx.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is associated with the fourth and sixth pharyngeal arches. It provides extensive innervation to structures in the neck, thorax, and abdomen, including the laryngeal muscles and the muscles involved in swallowing and phonation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch and is responsible for innervating the muscles of facial expression, as well as providing taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

choices.text: 600 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural areas in high performing states
600 INR to ASHA and 1400 INR to mother in rural areas in low performing states
400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban areas in high performing states
400 INR to ASHA and 600 INR to mother in urban areas in low performing states

questions.text: In the context of the Janani Suraksha Yojana, a program aimed at enhancing maternal health services in India, which of the following statements correctly describes the incentive distribution between ASHA workers and mothers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 600 INR to ASHA and 1400 INR to mother in rural areas in low performing states

 

  • This is correct. Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana, ASHA workers in rural areas of low performing states receive an incentive of 600 INR, and the mothers receive 1400 INR. This incentive structure is designed to encourage the use of health services for childbirth in regions that require significant improvements in maternal and infant health outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Janani Suraksha Yojana Incentives 

 

 

(LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)

 

(LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her guardian because of recurrent skin lesions and frequent episodes of bronchitis. The girl has been suffering from these issues since she was very young. During the examination, the physician notices several eczematous patches on her skin and a few healed abscesses. She also reports experiencing itching and discomfort due to the skin condition. Given the patient's history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

  • Job’s syndrome or Hyper-IgE syndrome: Rare, characterized by eczema, recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatocele), eosinophilia and high serum levels of IgE.

 

 

  • Mechanism: Due to a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis. Most cases are sporadic, but some familial cases have also been reported which may be:
  • Autosomal dominant cases: Linked to mutations in the STAT3 gene
  • Autosomal recessive cases: Due to mutations in DOCK8 gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: This condition involves high levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins and lacks the typical skin manifestations and elevated IgE seen in Hyper IgE syndrome.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. While it shares some symptoms with Hyper IgE syndrome, it does not typically present with high levels of IgE.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Primarily involves symptoms related to hormone secretion by carcinoid tumors, such as flushing and diarrhea, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases presenting with eczema, recurrent bacterial infections, and elevated levels of IgE and eosinophils, consider Hyper IgE syndrome as a differential diagnosis.
  • Early diagnosis and management are crucial for preventing severe complications associated with infections and for improving the quality of life.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is diagnosed with uterus didelphys during a routine pelvic examination. Which of the following is NOT likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Menorrhagia

 

  • Uterus didelphys is a congenital uterine anomaly where there is a complete duplication of the uterus, cervix, and sometimes the vagina.
  • This anomaly can lead to several complications related to pregnancy and childbirth due to the abnormal uterine structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preterm labor: Women with uterus didelphys are at increased risk of preterm labor due to the limited space for fetal growth and potential cervical incompetence.

 

Option C. Transverse lie: The abnormal shape and division of the uterus can prevent the fetus from aligning correctly for vaginal delivery, leading to malpresentations like transverse lie.

 

Option D. Abortion: The structural abnormalities of the uterus can interfere with normal implantation and pregnancy maintenance, increasing the risk of spontaneous abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding) is not typically associated with uterus didelphys, which is more likely to cause complications related to pregnancy and fetal positioning rather than menstrual abnormalities.

questions.text: A clinical oncologist is considering various chemotherapeutic agents for a patient diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Which of the following drugs is known to specifically inhibit DNA synthesis, impacting the proliferation of cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-Mercaptopurine

 

  • 6-Mercaptopurine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by interfering with purine nucleotide biosynthesis.
  • It is particularly effective during the S phase of the cell cycle, where DNA synthesis occurs, making it a critical agent in the treatment of certain leukemias.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Mitomycin: This drug functions as an alkylating agent, leading to DNA damage through cross-linking of DNA strands, which is different from direct inhibition of DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. Actinomycin: Known also as dactinomycin, this drug binds to DNA and inhibits RNA polymerase, which affects RNA synthesis more directly, though it can cause DNA damage by creating single-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Asparaginase: Works by depleting asparagine, an amino acid necessary for protein synthesis in certain cancer cells, thus indirectly affecting cell growth and survival without directly inhibiting DNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 6-Mercaptopurine is a critical drug in the management of certain types of leukaemia due to its specific mechanism of inhibiting DNA synthesis, making it essential in protocols designed to control rapid cell proliferation associated with cancer.

choices.text: Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by use of spectacles
Non-refractive esotropia; fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision
Mixed esotropia; esotropia for distance corrected by hypermetropia correction and residual esotropia for near corrected by +3 DS lens
Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by surgery

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with esotropia that is more pronounced when looking at near objects than when looking at distant objects. The child has no significant refractive error. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-refractive esotropia; fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision

 

  • Non-refractive esotropia is caused by an abnormally high accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio and may occur even in patients with no refractive error.
  • It is characterized by greater esotropia for near than for distance (with minimal or no deviation for distance).
  • This condition is fully corrected by adding +3 DS for near vision, which matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by use of spectacles: Refractive esotropia develops at the age of 2 to 3 years and is associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D). It affects both near and distance vision and is fully correctable by the use of spectacles.

 

Option C. Mixed esotropia; esotropia for distance corrected by hypermetropia correction and residual esotropia for near corrected by +3 DS lens: Mixed esotropia is caused by a combination of hypermetropia and a high AC/A ratio. Esotropia for distance is corrected by the correction of hypermetropia, and the residual esotropia for near is corrected by an additional +3 DS lens.

 

Option D. Refractive esotropia; fully correctable by surgery: Refractive esotropia is not typically treated with surgery but with spectacles.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Types of esotropia

choices.text: Decreased Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)
Decreased Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)
Normal/ Increased Total Lung Capacity (TLC)
Decreased Residual Volume (RV)

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Residual Volume (RV)

 

This is incorrect for COPD. Residual Volume is typically increased, not decreased, in COPD due to air trapping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): In COPD, there is a reduction in FVC due to the obstruction of airflow, which makes it difficult to completely expel air from the lungs.

 

Option B. Decreased Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1): FEV1 is significantly reduced in COPD due to the narrowed airways, which slow down the flow of air out of the lungs.

 

Option C. Normal/ Increased Total Lung Capacity (TLC): In COPD, TLC can be normal or increased due to hyperinflation of the lungs. This occurs because of air trapping in the alveoli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In COPD, pulmonary function tests typically show decreased FVC, decreased FEV1, a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, increased Residual Volume (RV), and normal or increased Total Lung Capacity (TLC) due to air trapping and hyperinflation.
  • Understanding these characteristic changes helps in diagnosing and differentiating COPD from restrictive lung diseases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the pulmonology clinic with complaints of a persistent dry cough, progressive shortness of breath, and recent unintentional weight loss. He reports a history of working in construction and significant exposure to dust and other environmental pollutants. A thorough workup, including imaging and lung biopsy, confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following pulmonary function test findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased FVC, increased FEV1/FVC

  • Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by scarring and stiffening of the lung tissue, which restricts lung expansion and reduces lung volumes.
  • This condition typically leads to a decrease in both forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1).
  • However, because FVC decreases more significantly than FEV1, the FEV1/FVC ratio is often increased or remains normal in restrictive lung diseases.
  • The forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) is also typically reduced in restrictive lung disease, but the reduction is proportional to the decrease in FVC, resulting in a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • This distinguishes restrictive lung diseases like pulmonary fibrosis from obstructive lung diseases, where the FEV1/FVC ratio is decreased due to a disproportionate reduction in FEV1.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased FVC, Decreased FEV1/FVC: This pattern is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), where the airflow limitation leads to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. It is not seen in restrictive lung diseases like pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Option B. Increased FVC, Increased FEV1/FVC: This finding is inconsistent with pulmonary fibrosis, as it suggests an improvement in lung volumes and function, which does not occur in restrictive lung diseases.

 

Option D. Increased FVC, Normal FEV1/FVC: This pattern is also incorrect for pulmonary fibrosis because restrictive lung diseases result in decreased, not increased, FVC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary function tests typically show decreased FVC and an increased or normal FEV1/FVC ratio, reflecting the restrictive nature of the disease.

choices.text: Congestive heart failure
History of stroke

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the CHADS2-Vasc score?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Age > 60 years

 

The CHADS2-Vasc score is a clinical prediction rule for estimating the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. The components of the CHADS2-Vasc score include:

 

  1. Congestive heart failure (C) - 1 point
  2. Hypertension (H) - 1 point
  3. Age ≥ 75 years (A) - 2 points
  4. Diabetes mellitus (D) - 1 point
  5. Stroke or transient ischemic attack (S2) - 2 points
  6. Vascular disease (V) - 1 point
  7. Age 65-74 years (A) - 1 point
  8. Sex category (female gender) (Sc) - 1 point

 

Age > 60 years is not a part of the CHADS2-Vasc score.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congestive heart failure: Congestive heart failure is part of the CHADS2-Vasc score and is assigned 1 point.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension is included in the CHADS2-Vasc score and is assigned 1 point.

 

Option C. History of stroke: A history of stroke or transient ischemic attack is included in the CHADS2-Vasc score and is assigned 2 points.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CHADS2-Vasc score includes Congestive heart failure, Hypertension, Age ≥ 75 years, Diabetes mellitus, Stroke or transient ischemic attack, Vascular disease, Age 65-74 years, and Female gender.
  • Age > 60 years is not included in this scoring system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the ‘triangle of safety’ for chest tube insertion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serratus anterior

 

  • The boundaries of the ‘triangle of safety’ are as follows-
  • Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi
  • Anteriorly- lateral border of pectoralis major
  • Inferiorly - 5th Intercostal space

 

 

Fig: Triangle of safety for Chest Tube placement

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "triangle of safety" is a guideline used in medical procedures to locate a safe area for chest interventions like needle thoracostomy, bordered by the lateral edge of the pectoralis major, the lateral edge of the latissimus dorsi, and a horizontal line at the level of the nipple.

questions.text:
A research team is conducting a field study to assess the prevalence of hepatitis B in a remote rural area. The team uses the HBsAg test kit depicted in the image, appreciating its quick turnaround time and ease of use for immediate results.

 

 

What is the principle of operation of the HBsAg test kit used in the field study? â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

  • The HBsAg test kit functions on the principle of immunochromatography. This method is particularly suited for field applications due to its simplicity and rapid provision of results.
  • The test involves the capillary action of a fluid sample through a membrane strip that contains immobilized antibodies specific to the hepatitis B surface antigen.
  • If HBsAg is present in the sample, it binds to these antibodies and a colored line appears, indicating a positive result.
  • This direct and visual confirmation is ideal for studies in remote locations where laboratory access is limited. The test also includes a control line to ensure the test is functioning correctly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Requires more sophisticated laboratory equipment and procedures, making it less ideal for rapid, field-based testing.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent dyes and a fluorescence microscope, which are not practical for field settings due to their complexity and equipment requirements.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Also requires specialized equipment for detecting light emissions, which is impractical in a field setting without proper laboratory facilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immunochromatography is an excellent choice for rapid diagnostic tests in field research due to its ease of use, rapid turnaround, and minimal equipment requirements, making it invaluable for assessing disease prevalence in remote or resource-limited settings.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents to the clinic concerned about a prominent structure on his right shoulder that becomes more noticeable during exercise or when lifting heavy objects. He denies any pain, redness, or swelling, and there is no history of trauma. On physical examination, a prominent, non-pulsatile linear structure is noted running along the deltopectoral groove. Which of the following structures is found in this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cephalic Vein

 

  • The cephalic vein is a superficial vein located in the upper limb, running along the deltopectoral groove between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles.
  • It becomes more prominent during activities that increase venous return, such as exercise or heavy lifting.
  • The absence of symptoms like pain, redness, or swelling and its anatomical location supports the identification of this structure as the cephalic vein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basilic Vein: Incorrect. The basilic vein runs along the medial aspect of the arm and does not pass through the deltopectoral groove, making it an unlikely candidate for the described presentation.

 

Option B. Axillary Artery: Incorrect. The axillary artery is a deep structure that lies beneath the pectoralis major muscle and is not visible as a superficial vein in the deltopectoral groove.

 

Option D. Radial Nerve: Incorrect. The radial nerve is a deep structure that runs along the posterior aspect of the arm and does not traverse the deltopectoral groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cephalic vein is a prominent superficial vein visible in the deltopectoral groove, particularly noticeable during physical exertion or in individuals with low subcutaneous fat.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia, presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent fever and localized swelling in his lower limbs. Blood samples are collected during the night to evaluate for possible parasitic infections, given his travel history and symptoms. Microscopic examination reveals microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two distinct nuclei at the tail tip. Which of the following species of microfilariae is suggested in the microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

  • Brugia malayi is a nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis and is characterized by microfilariae with a sheathed tail that contains two distinct nuclei at the tip—one terminal and one subterminal.
  • This structural feature distinguishes B. malayi from other filarial worms.
  • The organism exhibits a nocturnal periodicity, where microfilariae are present in peripheral blood mainly at night.
  • The sheathed nature of the microfilariae indicates that they retain their egg membranes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: This microfilaria also exhibits a sheathed appearance but differs in that its tail tip has no nuclei and ends in a pointed tail.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Exhibits a sheathed microfilaria with a column of nuclei extending into the blunt tail tip, not just two nuclei.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Identified by unsheathed microfilariae with a pointed tail tip that contains no nuclei, commonly found in the skin and eyes rather than blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of microfilariae of 3 important filarial worms

questions.text: Among the following options, which antimicrobial class is known for exhibiting a long post-antibiotic effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinolones

 

  • Quinolones, such as ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin, are well known for their significant post-antibiotic effect (PAE).
  • This effect refers to the persistent suppression of bacterial growth after the antibiotic levels have fallen below the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).
  • The PAE of quinolones is attributed to their mechanism of action, which involves inhibiting DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes critical for bacterial DNA replication and cell division.
  • This mechanism leads to sustained effects on bacterial replication even after the drug is no longer present at active concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: While macrolides do have a post-antibiotic effect, it is generally less pronounced than that observed with quinolones.

 

Option C. Beta-lactams: These antibiotics, including penicillins and cephalosporins, typically have a shorter PAE, especially against Gram-negative bacteria.

 

Option D. Oxazolidinones: This class, including linezolid, also has a post-antibiotic effect, but it is not as long as that seen with quinolones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Quinolones are notable for their long post-antibiotic effect, which can be particularly beneficial in treatment strategies that aim to reduce the frequency of dosing while maintaining effective bacterial suppression.
  • This characteristic is crucial for designing dosing regimens and understanding the clinical implications of antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Dr. Kapil, a healthcare administrator, is exploring various management strategies to enhance team performance and patient care in his hospital. He is particularly interested in incorporating a method that leverages behavioral sciences to motivate staff and align their personal goals with organizational objectives. Which management technique should Dr. Kapil implement to achieve this integration?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Management by objective

 

  • This is correct. Management by Objective (MBO) is a strategic management model that relies heavily on the principles of behavioral sciences.
  • Developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s, MBO involves setting specific measurable goals with each employee and then periodically reviewing the progress made.
  • The technique's effectiveness is rooted in its focus on aligning employees' personal achievements with organizational goals, thereby fostering a participatory environment and enhancing motivation through clear, agreed-upon objectives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making: Incorrect. While decision-making is a crucial aspect of management, it does not inherently rely on behavioral sciences as much as MBO. Decision making typically involves choosing between alternatives and does not necessarily focus on goal alignment or behavioral motivations.

 

Option B. Systems analysis: Incorrect. Systems analysis is more quantitative and focuses on the technical and procedural aspects of organizational operations, rather than on behavioral aspects and personal goal setting.

 

Option C. Network analysis: Incorrect. Network analysis deals with understanding relationships and flows between parts of a network, which can be used in organizational settings but does not specifically focus on behavioral science principles or individual goal alignment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Accurately identify the specific toxins produced by various adulterants mentioned below.

 

Adulterants:

  1. Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)
  2. Argemone mexicana (oil)
  3. Crotolaria seeds (Jhunjhunia)
  4. Aspergillus flavus/parasiticus
  5. Claviceps fusiformis
     

Toxins:

  1. Aflatoxin
  2. Sanguinarine
  3. Clavine alkaloids
  4. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
  5. BOAA (Beta-N-Oxalyl-L-alpha,beta-diaminopropionic acid)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-e, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a, 5-c

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus) is known to contain BOAA (Beta-N-Oxalyl-L-alpha,beta-diaminopropionic acid), a neurotoxin that can cause irreversible neurological disorders, known as neurolathyrism.
  2. Argemone mexicana (oil) is contaminated with Sanguinarine, a toxic alkaloid that leads to epidemic dropsy, characterized by severe edema and cardiovascular complications.
  3. Crotolaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) are a source of Pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which are hepatotoxic and can lead to hepatic veno-occlusive disease, potentially causing severe liver damage.
  4. Aspergillus flavus/parasiticus, a fungus, produces Aflatoxin, one of the most potent natural carcinogens known, primarily affecting the liver and leading to liver cancer.
  5. Claviceps fusiformis, a fungus that affects rye and other cereals, produces Clavine alkaloids, which are associated with ergotism that can cause severe vasoconstriction leading to gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: A two-year-old boy was referred to the dermatology outpatient department (OPD) with lesions resistant to atopic dermatitis therapy. Parents reported that he received treatment for desquamative skin lesions. He had no family history of skin disorders. On physical examination, his skin on the abdomen, face, and extremities with classical hair disorders as shown in the below mentioned images. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Netherton syndrome.

 

  • Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a triad of symptoms: ichthyosis, hair shaft abnormalities (such as trichorrhexis invaginata, also known as "bamboo hair"), and atopic diathesis (including eczematous dermatitis, elevated IgE levels, and recurrent infections). The patient's symptoms of intractable pruritus, dry skin, eczematous lesions resistant to typical treatments, and the presence of distinctive hair abnormalities strongly suggest Netherton syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichothiodystrophy: This condition involves brittle hair, intellectual disability, and ichthyosis but lacks the classical eczematous lesions and the specific hair abnormalities seen in Netherton syndrome.

 

Option C. Lamellar ichthyosis: This condition presents with large, dark, plate-like scales over the entire body but does not typically include the eczematous dermatitis or the hair abnormalities associated with Netherton syndrome.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis: While the boy has eczematous lesions, the presence of hair shaft abnormalities and the severity of symptoms make Netherton syndrome a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Netherton syndrome is characterized by the triad of ichthyosis, atopic diathesis, and hair shaft abnormalities (trichorrhexis invaginata).
  • It should be considered in children with severe eczema resistant to treatment, especially when hair abnormalities are present.

questions.text: Dr. Radhika, a pediatrician and public health researcher, is conducting a study to assess the impact of different nutritional programs on the growth of school children in three distinct regions. She has collected height measurements from children in each region and plans to analyze the data to determine if there are statistically significant differences in average heights among the groups. Given this scenario, which statistical test should Dr. Radhika use to evaluate the differences in average heights among the three groups of school children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ANOVA

 

  • This is correct. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is the appropriate statistical test to be use when comparing the average heights of school children across three different regions.
  • This test is designed to determine if there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups.
  • ANOVA will allow her to assess whether the variations in nutritional programs across the regions have different impacts on the children's growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: Incorrect. The chi-square test is used for categorical data, such as frequency counts, and is not suitable for comparing means of continuous data like heights.

 

Option B. T-test: Incorrect. The T-test is generally used when comparing the means between two groups only, not suitable for three or more groups.

 

Option D. Pearson correlation: Incorrect. The Pearson correlation is used to measure the strength of a linear association between two continuous variables.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ANOVA test (F-test/F-ratio): Comparing means (+ SD) in more than two different group of individuals
  • Chi-square test (χ2 - test): Comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two or more different group of individuals

 

Fischer’s test: Is a variant of Chi-square test when sample size is < 30

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive skin thickening on her fingers extending to her trunk, accompanied by Raynaud's phenomenon and difficulty swallowing. She also complains of shortness of breath on exertion. High-resolution CT of the chest shows interstitial lung disease. Which of the following serological markers is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies (Anti-Scl-70)

 

  • Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies (Anti-Scl-70) are associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which is characterized by widespread skin involvement and a higher likelihood of internal organ involvement, such as interstitial lung disease, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Anti-centromere antibodies are more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which primarily affects the hands and face.
 

Option B. Anti-histone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus and not specific to systemic sclerosis.
 

Option C. Rheumatoid factor can be positive in many autoimmune diseases, but it is not specifically associated with systemic sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies (Anti-Scl-70) is a serological marker associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and its relation to extensive skin involvement and internal organ manifestations.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than the left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to the circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with exertional chest pain and shortness of breath. She undergoes a coronary angiography to evaluate for coronary artery disease. During the procedure, the cardiologist examines the right coronary artery (RCA) in detail. Which of the following statements about the right coronary artery is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It gives rise to the circumflex coronary branch

 

  • The right coronary artery (RCA) has several key anatomical features and branches, but it does not give rise to the circumflex coronary branch. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery (LCA).
  • The RCA typically arises from the anterior (right) aortic sinus and supplies blood to the right atrium, right ventricle, and parts of the conduction system of the heart.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than the left coronary artery: This statement is true. Generally, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This statement is true. The right coronary artery originates from the anterior (right) aortic sinus.

 

Option D. Right conus artery is its first branch: This statement is true. The first branch of the right coronary artery is typically the right conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right coronary artery does not give rise to the circumflex coronary branch; instead, the circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with complaints of vaginal itching and dryness. Upon examination, she is diagnosed with atrophic vaginitis. What is the treatment of choice for her condition?
questions.solution:
