Ans. B) Topical estrogen

 

  • Atrophic vaginitis is a condition commonly seen in postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels, leading to thinning and inflammation of the vaginal walls.
  • Symptoms include vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis is topical estrogen, which helps replenish local estrogen levels, thereby alleviating symptoms by promoting the regeneration of the vaginal epithelium and increasing vaginal moisture and elasticity.
  • Topical estrogen can be administered in various forms, including creams, tablets, or rings, and has been shown to be highly effective in managing the symptoms of atrophic vaginitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not typically used for the treatment of atrophic vaginitis as they do not address the underlying cause, which is estrogen deficiency. Steroids may reduce inflammation but do not restore the vaginal epithelium or moisture.

 

Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may relieve itching temporarily but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis. They are not suitable as a primary treatment for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical estrogen is the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, addressing the underlying estrogen deficiency and effectively relieving symptoms such as vaginal dryness and itching.

questions.text: A Medical Officer is preparing to evaluate a suspect who may have prior knowledge of a crime scene, and the test to be used is based on the principle that this prior knowledge will influence the suspect's reactions. Which test is most suitable for detecting such influences based on the suspect's physiological responses?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polygraph

 

  • The Polygraph test, also known as a lie detector test, measures and records several physiological indices such as blood pressure, pulse, respiration, and skin conductivity while the subject is asked and answers a series of questions.
  • The principle behind this test is that deceptive answers will produce physiological responses that can be differentiated from those associated with non-deceptive answers.
  • This is because knowing the truth about the crime may involuntarily trigger distinct physiological responses when questioned, which the polygraph aims to detect.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Truth Serum: Incorrect because while truth serum (such as sodium thiopental) is used to make a person more likely to share information, it does not specifically measure reaction based on prior knowledge.
 

Option C. Hypnosis: Incorrect as hypnosis is used to retrieve deeper or suppressed memories but does not directly measure physiological reactions to knowledge of specific events.
 

Option D. Brain mapping: Incorrect because brain mapping (or functional MRI) observes brain activity patterns but is not specifically about the reaction to prior knowledge in the context mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The polygraph test is designed to capture changes in physiological responses that occur when a suspect with prior knowledge of the crime is questioned, leveraging the body's involuntary reactions to stress or deception related to their awareness of the crime details.

questions.text: A patient presented with skin lesions on his body as shown in the image. On evaluation, he has pain and swelling in the DIP joints. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psoriatic arthritis

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that occurs in patients with psoriasis, a skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches of skin.
  • Psoriatic arthritis can affect any joint, including the DIP joints, and often presents with asymmetric arthritis, enthesitis (inflammation at sites where tendons or ligaments attach to bone), and dactylitis (swelling of an entire finger or toe).
  • Psoriatic arthritis is strongly associated with psoriasis, and the presence of skin lesions in the image provided supports this diagnosis.
  • Additionally, involvement of the DIP joints, along with pain and swelling, is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reactive Arthritis: Reactive arthritis, also known as Reiter's syndrome, is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, typically the genitourinary or gastrointestinal tract. It is characterized by asymmetric arthritis, often affecting large joints such as the knees and ankles, as well as extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis and urethritis. Reactive arthritis is less commonly associated with involvement of the DIP joints. While it can present with joint pain and swelling, the presence of skin lesions (as shown in the image) and DIP joint involvement make other diagnoses more likely.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and the formation of bone spurs. It typically affects weight-bearing joints such as the hips and knees, but can also involve the hands, including the DIP joints. Osteoarthritis is more common in older individuals and is associated with joint pain and stiffness that worsen over time. While osteoarthritis can affect the DIP joints, the presence of skin lesions and the relatively young age of the patient make other diagnoses, such as inflammatory arthritis, more likely.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, often involving the small joints of the hands and feet. RA typically presents with joint pain, swelling, and stiffness, as well as systemic symptoms such as fatigue and morning stiffness. It can lead to joint deformities and erosive changes on imaging. RA typically affects the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints rather than the DIP joints. Additionally, while skin manifestations can occur in RA, they are less common and typically different from those seen in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The skin lesions seen in the given case are typical of psoriasis.
  • Psoriasis is associated with pain and swelling in the DIP joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • Thus, the given case is true for psoriatic arthritis.

choices.text: GBS typically presents with ascending paralysis.
Deep tendon reflexes are exaggerated in the initial days of symptom onset.
GBS is associated with autonomic dysfunction.
Campylobacter jejuni is a common preceding infection.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deep tendon reflexes are exaggerated in the initial days of symptom onset.

 

  • In Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS), deep tendon reflexes actually diminish or disappear within the initial days of symptom onset. This is a key diagnostic feature of GBS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GBS typically presents with ascending paralysis: GBS typically presents with symmetrical, ascending paralysis that begins in the lower limbs and progresses to involve the trunk and upper limbs. This characteristic pattern helps differentiate GBS from other neurological conditions.

 

Option C. GBS is associated with autonomic dysfunction: GBS can involve autonomic dysfunction, with or without sensory involvement. This can include symptoms such as fluctuations in blood pressure and heart rate, indicating the involvement of the autonomic nervous system.

 

Option D. Campylobacter jejuni is a common preceding infection: Campylobacter jejuni is a common preceding infection in cases of GBS. Other infections such as those caused by human herpes viruses and Mycoplasma pneumoniae can also be implicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is characterized by symmetrical, ascending paralysis and diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a headache and fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals glucose 60 mg/dL, protein 25 mg/dL, and WBC 3 cells/µL (70% lymphocytes, 30% monocytes/macrophages). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal CSF

 

  • The normal CSF findings include glucose levels of 40-85 mg/dL, protein levels of 15-45 mg/dL, and a WBC count of less than 5 cells/µL with 60-70% lymphocytes and 30% monocytes/macrophages.
  • The patient's CSF analysis matches these normal parameters, indicating no infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial Meningitis: Bacterial meningitis typically presents with CSF glucose levels less than 40 mg/dL, protein levels greater than 100 mg/dL, and a WBC count greater than 1000 cells/µL, predominantly polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs). These findings indicate a significant infection and inflammation.

 

Option C. Viral Meningitis: Viral meningitis usually shows normal glucose levels, protein levels of 20-80 mg/dL, and a WBC count of 25-500 cells/µL, predominantly lymphocytes. It indicates a less severe infection compared to bacterial meningitis.

 

Option D. Fungal Meningitis: Fungal meningitis often presents with decreased to normal glucose levels, protein levels of 150-300 mg/dL, and a WBC count of 40-600 cells/µL, with lymphocytes or PMNs depending on the specific organism. It indicates a chronic infection process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal CSF findings include glucose 40-85 mg/dL, protein 15-45 mg/dL, and WBC less than 5 cells/µL with a predominance of lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with generalized edema and proteinuria. Genetic testing reveals a mutation associated with Finnish-type nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following proteins is implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrin

 

  • Finnish-type nephrotic syndrome, also known as congenital nephrotic syndrome of the Finnish type, is primarily caused by mutations in the NPHS1 gene that encodes the protein nephrin.
  • Nephrin is a crucial component of the slit diaphragm in the kidney glomeruli, which plays an essential role in maintaining the filtration barrier.
  • Mutations in nephrin lead to a defective slit diaphragm, resulting in significant proteinuria and the clinical manifestations of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Podocin: Podocin is encoded by the NPHS2 gene and is also important for the structure and function of the slit diaphragm. However, mutations in podocin are associated with a different form of nephrotic syndrome called steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, not specifically the Finnish type.

 

Option C. Alpha actinin: Alpha actinin is a cytoskeletal protein involved in the structural integrity of the cell's actin network. While it plays a role in kidney function, mutations in this protein are not typically associated with Finnish-type nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. CD2 activated protein (CD2AP): CD2AP is involved in the signaling and structural integrity of the slit diaphragm. Mutations in CD2AP can lead to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), but they are not specifically associated with Finnish-type nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Finnish-type nephrotic syndrome is associated with mutations in the NPHS1 gene, leading to defects in the protein nephrin, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the kidney's filtration barrier.
  • This results in significant proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome.

choices.text: Can present with peripheral lymphadenopathy and intrabdominal mass.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Burkitt's lymphoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ki-67 of 40%

 

  • The Ki-67 index is a marker of proliferation. Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by a very high proliferation rate, with a Ki-67 index approaching 100%.
  • A Ki-67 index of 40% is not characteristic of Burkitt's lymphoma and would suggest a less aggressive malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Associated with EBV infection: This statement is true. Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly the endemic variant, is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection.

 

Option B. Can present with peripheral lymphadenopathy and intrabdominal mass: This statement is true. Burkitt's lymphoma can present with peripheral lymphadenopathy and commonly with abdominal masses, especially in the sporadic form.

 

Option D. Curable with chemotherapy: This statement is true. Burkitt's lymphoma is curable with aggressive chemotherapy regimens, despite its rapid growth and aggressive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive but potentially curable B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a very high proliferation rate (Ki-67 near 100%), association with EBV infection, and presentation with rapidly growing masses, including peripheral lymphadenopathy and abdominal involvement.
  • A Ki-67 index of 40% is not typical for this disease.

choices.text: Inhibits the release of acetylcholine
Release of noradrenaline at the synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors
Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors

questions.text: A patient being treated for muscle spasticity is prescribed a medication (Botox) known for its specific neuromuscular action. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • Botulinum toxin (Botox) functions by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter responsible for triggering muscle contractions.
  • It achieves this by cleaving SNARE proteins, which are essential for the fusion of neurotransmitter-containing vesicles with the neuron's membrane.
  • This disruption prevents acetylcholine from being released into the neuromuscular junction, effectively reducing muscle activity and preventing contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at the synaptic cleft: This statement is incorrect as botulinum toxin does not affect noradrenaline release.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly interact with nicotinic receptors; its action is at the level of neurotransmitter release.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Incorrect, as botulinum toxin does not stimulate but rather inhibits the action at synapses by preventing acetylcholine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary mechanism of botulinum toxin is the inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, making it an effective treatment for reducing muscle activity and improving aesthetic concerns like wrinkles or for medical conditions associated with muscle spasticity.

questions.text: Dr. Lalit is examining a dataset to understand the distribution of cholesterol levels among patients in a longitudinal health study. The distribution of the data appears as shown in the image. Based on this distribution, how do the mean, median, and mode of the cholesterol levels compare?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mean > Median > Mode

 

  • This is correct. In a right-skewed distribution, the tail of the distribution extends to the right, indicating that the mean is pulled in the direction of the tail.
  • This results in the mean being greater than the median, and the median being greater than the mode.
  • The mean is affected most by the outliers and high values typically found in the tail of the distribution, whereas the mode represents the highest frequency of data which is less affected by outliers and typically occurs before the peak of the median and mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mean = Median = Mode: Incorrect. In a normal distribution (not skewed), the mean, median, and mode are equal, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Mode > Median > Mean: Incorrect. This arrangement would be more typical of a left-skewed (negatively skewed) distribution, where the tail extends to the left.

 

Option D. Median > Mode > Mean: Incorrect. This order does not typically occur in any standard distribution format and reverses the relationship seen in a right-skewed distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Right skew curve (Photograph): Mean > Median > Mode
  • In Left skew curve: Mean < Median < Mode
  • In Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with a fever and a distinctive rash. Upon further examination, the pediatrician orders a urine test, which reveals cells displaying an "owl's eye" appearance. Based on these clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

  • The "owl's eye" appearance in cells is characteristic of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, typically seen in the urine or tissue biopsy under microscopy.
  • This viral inclusion shows a large, intranuclear inclusion body surrounded by a clear halo, giving it an owl's eye appearance.
  • CMV can cause a range of symptoms in children, including fever and rash, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or congenitally infected infants.

 

 

Additional Information: 

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: Incorrect because Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily causes infectious mononucleosis, which typically presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, but does not feature the "owl's eye" appearance in cells.
 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus: Incorrect as Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections are characterized by vesicular lesions rather than cells with an "owl's eye" appearance.
 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii: Incorrect because Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite, causes toxoplasmosis and does not produce the "owl's eye" appearance in cells; its diagnosis is typically confirmed through serological testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "owl's eye" appearance in cellular examinations is a diagnostic indicator of Cytomegalovirus infection, particularly relevant in pediatric cases presenting with symptoms like fever and rash.
  • Recognizing this key diagnostic feature can guide appropriate clinical management and treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is preferred for strangulated rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Altemeier procedure

 

  • In the Altemeier procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full thickness resection performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse.
  • Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by either a handsewn or stapled anastomosis.
  • This is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiersch’s operation: In this perineal approach procedure, a steel wire, or silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. It has become largely obsolete owing to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis and obstructed defecation, but may be used to augment perineal repair in cases of severe pelvic floor weakness.

 

Option B. Mesh rectopexy: The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position. Many variations have been described, including inserting a sheet of polypropylene mesh.

 

Option C. Delorme procedure: The rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, so that the rectal muscle is concave towards the anal canal. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Altemeier procedure is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

questions.text: In 1977, a research team analyzed the health records of the 1935 freshman cohort at a large academic institution to evaluate whether their heights and weights at university entry could predict the later occurrence of Coronary Heart Disease (CHD). What study design is exemplified by this investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retrospective cohort

 

  • This is a retrospective cohort study because it involves looking back at historical data (physical examination records from 1935) to assess the relationship between certain exposures (height and weight at university admission) and subsequent outcomes (development of CHD by 1977).
  • The study does not manipulate variables but observes existing data across different times, making it retrospective in nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-sectional study: Incorrect because cross-sectional studies assess both exposure and outcome at a single point in time, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Concurrent cohort: Incorrect as this study design would involve assessing the exposure and outcome during the same time period; however, in this scenario, the data spans several decades.

 

Option D. Clinical trial: Incorrect because clinical trials involve the intervention of the researchers to assign treatments, which does not occur in this study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exposure and outcome in analytical studies:

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia was started on drug A. After beginning treatment with drug A, the patient's psychotic symptoms improved; however, he developed gynecomastia, infertility, tremors and rigidity. Which drug is most likely to be 'drug A’?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risperidone

 

  • Risperidone is effective in managing psychotic symptoms but can lead to several side effects due to its dopamine antagonism.
  • These side effects include hyperprolactinemia, which can result in gynecomastia (breast enlargement in males) and infertility.
  • Additionally, risperidone can cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as tremors and rigidity, particularly at higher doses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another atypical antipsychotic known for its efficacy in treating schizophrenia. It is associated more with weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and sedation. Olanzapine is less likely to cause hyperprolactinemia and EPS compared to risperidone.

 

Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine is used primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia due to its superior efficacy but has a unique side effect profile, including agranulocytosis, seizures, and sialorrhea. It is not typically associated with hyperprolactinemia or EPS.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole acts as a partial agonist at dopamine D2 receptors and has a lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and EPS compared to risperidone. It may cause akathisia but is less likely to cause gynecomastia and infertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Risperidone can improve psychotic symptoms in schizophrenia but may cause side effects such as gynecomastia, infertility, and extrapyramidal symptoms like tremors and rigidity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer has developed thrombocytopenia as a complication of her treatment. To manage this condition, which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oprelvekin (IL-11)

 

  • Oprelvekin, an interleukin-11 analog, is specifically used to treat thrombocytopenia (a decrease in platelets) caused by chemotherapy.
  • Oprelvekin works by stimulating the bone marrow to produce more platelets, thereby reducing the risk of bleeding associated with low platelet counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filgrastim: This medication is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) that is primarily used to treat neutropenia (low levels of neutrophils) rather than thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Erythropoietin: Commonly used to treat anemia, especially in patients with chronic kidney disease or those suffering from anemia due to chemotherapy, erythropoietin stimulates the production of red blood cells, not platelets.

 

Option D. Amifostine: This drug provides protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy, particularly against cisplatin-induced renal toxicity, and is not used to treat low platelet counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients experiencing thrombocytopenia as a result of chemotherapy, oprelvekin (IL-11) is a targeted and effective treatment option to increase platelet production and mitigate the associated risks of bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass. An abdominal CT scan reveals an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta. The attending physician explains to medical students the anatomical structures passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Which of the following structures does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vagal trunk

 

  • The vagal trunks (anterior and posterior) pass through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra, not the aortic opening of the diaphragm.
  • The esophageal hiatus is an opening in the diaphragm that allows the esophagus and vagus nerves to pass through from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.
  • Therefore, the vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening, making it the correct

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azygous Vein: The azygous vein is a major vein that drains blood from the thoracic wall and upper lumbar region into the superior vena cava. It passes through the aortic hiatus along with the aorta and thoracic duct.

 

Option B. Thoracic Duct: The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body, responsible for draining lymph from the lower body, left upper limb, and left side of the head and neck into the venous system. It also passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Option D. Aorta: The aorta is the main artery that carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the rest of the body. It passes through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of the T12 vertebra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vagal trunk passes through the esophageal hiatus, not the aortic opening of the diaphragm, which instead accommodates the aorta, azygous vein, and thoracic duct.

choices.text: Females have an equal incidence to males
Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/litre

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a liver mass discovered during a routine ultrasound. She has no history of liver disease or cirrhosis. Further imaging and biopsy confirm the diagnosis of fibrolamellar carcinoma. Which of the following statements about fibrolamellar carcinoma is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/litre

 

  • Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/litre: This statement is incorrect. Fibrolamellar carcinoma typically does not present with significantly elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels.
  • Unlike conventional hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), where AFP levels can be markedly elevated, AFP levels in fibrolamellar carcinoma are generally normal or only mildly elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has a good prognosis: This statement is true. Fibrolamellar carcinoma generally has a better prognosis compared to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, partly because it often occurs in younger patients without underlying liver disease and is more amenable to surgical resection.

 

Option B. Not associated with liver cirrhosis: This statement is true. Unlike conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma is typically not associated with liver cirrhosis or significant underlying liver disease.

 

Option C. Females have an equal incidence to males: This statement is true. The incidence of fibrolamellar carcinoma is roughly equal between males and females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fibrolamellar carcinoma of the liver is a distinct type of liver cancer that typically affects young individuals without cirrhosis, has a better prognosis than conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, and is not associated with significantly elevated serum AFP levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is scheduled for a hysteroscopic polypectomy to remove uterine polyps. This procedure will use bipolar electrocautery. Which of the following agents is ideal for uterine cavity distention during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal saline

 

  • Hysteroscopic procedures, such as polypectomy, require the uterine cavity to be distended to allow for better visualization and access.
  • When bipolar electrocautery is used, it is crucial to choose an appropriate distending medium that is both safe and effective.
  • Normal saline is an ideal agent in this scenario because it is an isotonic, non-conductive fluid that does not interfere with the electrical conductivity of the bipolar electrocautery.
  • It also reduces the risk of complications such as fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycine: Glycine is often used as a distention medium in monopolar electrocautery because it is non-conductive. However, it is not suitable for bipolar electrocautery due to its conductive properties, which can interfere with the procedure and increase the risk of complications.

 

Option B. 70% dextrose: 70% dextrose is not a common choice for uterine distention in hysteroscopic procedures. It can cause significant fluid shifts and hyperglycemia, making it unsuitable for this purpose.

 

Option D. CO2: CO2 is used for distention in laparoscopy but is not suitable for hysteroscopic procedures because it does not provide adequate distention of the uterine cavity and can cause gas embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its safety, isotonic nature, and non-conductive properties.

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter
Lissamine dye - visualized under green filter
Lissamine dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualized under green filter

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of eye irritation and blurred vision in his right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist applies a specific dye to the patient's eye and visualizes it under a particular filter. The image is shown below. What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter

 

  • The most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter.
  • Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter.
  • It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fluorescein dye is used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and is visualized under a cobalt blue filter, which emits a bright green fluorescence.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hymenolepis diminuta

 

  • This is correct because Hymenolepis diminuta, commonly known as the rat tapeworm, is primarily transmitted through the ingestion of infected arthropods like beetles, not through rat fleas.
  • This tapeworm is often found in rodents but does not involve fleas in its lifecycle.

 

Rat flea

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Murine typhus: Incorrect as Murine typhus, caused by Rickettsia typhi, is indeed transmitted by rat fleas, which act as vectors for this bacterial disease.

 

Option B. Pneumonic plague: Incorrect regarding the mode of transmission. While rat fleas transmit the bacterium Yersinia pestis responsible for bubonic plague, pneumonic plague is a secondary form developed from bubonic or septicemic plague and is typically spread from person to person through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C.  Chiggerosis: Incorrect since Chiggerosis, while typically associated with mite infestations, can also be linked to areas or vectors that involve rat fleas, though it is not the primary disease transmitted by rat fleas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RAT FLEA (XENOPSYLLA)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman comes in for routine prenatal care and the doctor advises for a thyroid profile test. Which of the following thyroid profile components is altered throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

  • During pregnancy, there is an increase in thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) due to elevated estrogen levels.
  • This leads to an increase in the total levels of thyroid hormones, including total T3 and total T4.
  • However, the free (unbound) levels of T3 and T4 generally remain within the normal range due to homeostatic mechanisms.
  • The total T3 level is, therefore, altered throughout pregnancy, reflecting the increased production and binding capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: The free T3 level usually remains within the normal range during pregnancy because the body adjusts to maintain homeostasis despite the increased total thyroid hormone levels.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: Similarly, the free T4 level generally stays within the normal range during pregnancy due to the regulatory mechanisms that balance thyroid hormone production and metabolism.

 

Option D. TSH level: TSH levels can fluctuate during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, due to the influence of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which can mildly stimulate the thyroid. However, overall, the TSH levels are maintained within the trimester-specific reference ranges and do not consistently remain altered throughout pregnancy like the total T3 levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During pregnancy, total T3 and total T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) levels, while free T3 and free T4 levels generally remain stable.
  • Total T3 level is specifically altered throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the outpatient department with a one-day history of loose stools. On examination, signs of dehydration are present. The child is treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS). The administration of ORS facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A)  SGLT1 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1):

 

  • SGLT1 is a transporter protein located in the brush border of the small intestine. It is responsible for the co-transport of glucose and sodium from the lumen of the intestine into the enterocytes.
  • When ORS, which contains glucose and sodium, is administered to a dehydrated child, the glucose component is absorbed into the intestinal cells via SGLT1.
  • This absorption process is coupled with the uptake of sodium ions, creating an osmotic gradient that promotes water absorption.
  • This mechanism is crucial in rehydrating the patient effectively by replenishing both fluids and electrolytes lost due to diarrhoea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 2): This transporter is primarily found in the renal proximal tubules of the kidneys. Its main function is to reabsorb glucose from the glomerular filtrate back into the blood, preventing glucose loss in urine. It does not play a role in the intestinal absorption of glucose and is therefore not involved in the action of ORS in treating dehydration.

 

Option C. GLUT4 (Glucose Transporter Type 4): GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found in adipose tissue and muscle cells. It facilitates the uptake of glucose into cells in response to insulin, playing a key role in glucose homeostasis. However, it is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen, making it irrelevant to the mechanism of ORS.

 

Option D. Na-Ca Transporter (Sodium-Calcium Exchanger): This transporter is involved in the exchange of sodium and calcium ions across cell membranes, primarily in cardiac and smooth muscle cells. It plays a role in cellular calcium homeostasis and cardiac contractility. It does not participate in glucose absorption in the intestines and therefore is not relevant to the action of ORS in rehydration therapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The administration of oral rehydration solution (ORS) facilitates glucose absorption through the SGLT1 transporter in the small intestine, which is crucial for effective rehydration by enhancing the uptake of both sodium and water.

choices.text: The RDA is established by a panel of experts based on scientific research.
The RDA meets the dietary needs of every individual in the population.
The RDA is typically set above the minimal nutritional requirement to cover variations in needs.
The RDA is derived from the Estimated Average Requirement (EAR).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The RDA meets the dietary needs of every individual in the population.

 

  • This is false because while the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) aims to cover the nutritional needs of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular age and gender group, it does not necessarily cater to every single individual, especially those with unique health conditions or exceptional nutritional requirements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The RDA is established by a panel of experts based on scientific research:  True, The RDA is determined by a panel of nutrition and health experts who base their recommendations on extensive scientific research.

 

Option C. The RDA is typically set above the minimal nutritional requirement to cover variations in needs: True, The RDA often includes a margin to ensure the nutritional sufficiency for different conditions, including periods of growth, illness, or higher metabolic demand, making it higher than the minimal nutritional requirements.

 

Option D. The RDA is derived from the Estimated Average Requirement (EAR): True, The RDA is indeed based on the Estimated Average Requirement (EAR), which is the average daily nutrient intake level estimated to meet the requirement of half the healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA): Is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

choices.text: Both A and C

questions.text: Identify the procedure for which the instrument given below is used:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural anesthesia

 

  • The instrument shown is an epidural Tuohy needle, which is used specifically for administering epidural anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal anesthesia and Option C. Lumbar puncture most commonly use Quincke babcock needle

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The needle shown above is specifically designed for administering epidural anesthesia.

choices.text: Constant Km and increased Vmax
Constant Km and decreased Vmax
Decreased Km and decreased Vmax
Decreased Km and increased Vmax

questions.text: A biochemistry student is studying the effects of various types of enzyme inhibition on enzyme kinetics. She learns about non-competitive inhibition and its impact on enzyme activity. Which of the following statements is true regarding non-competitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constant Km and decreased Vmax

 

  • Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, which is known as an allosteric site.
  • This binding alters the enzyme's structure and function, reducing its catalytic activity. In non-competitive inhibition, the maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) is decreased because the inhibitor affects the enzyme regardless of the concentration of the substrate.
  • However, the Km (Michaelis constant), which reflects the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate, remains unchanged because the inhibitor does not compete with the substrate for the active site.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constant Km and increased Vmax: Non-competitive inhibition does not increase Vmax; it decreases it.

 

Option C. Decreased Km and decreased Vmax: Km remains constant in non-competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Decreased Km and increased Vmax: Neither Km decreases nor Vmax increases in non-competitive inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

  • In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, leading to a constant Km and a decreased Vmax, reflecting reduced enzyme activity regardless of substrate concentration.

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
The fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with groin pain after lifting heavy objects at work. On physical examination, tenderness is noted in the inguinal region. The attending physician discusses the anatomical structures related to inguinal hernias with the medical students, specifically the iliopubic tract. Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

 

  • The iliopubic tract is a fibrous band that extends from the iliac crest to the pubic tubercle.
  • It is an important anatomical landmark in the inguinal region, especially in relation to inguinal hernias.
  • The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out laterally and blend with the fascia iliaca, which covers the iliacus muscle.
  • This structure is significant in surgical procedures involving the inguinal region, as it helps delineate the boundaries of the inguinal canal and hernia repairs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia but rather a distinct fibrous structure associated with the inguinal region.

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract actually lies posterior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament), not anterior.

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is incorrect. While the iliopubic tract is related to the pubic tubercle, it does not insert in front of the conjoint tendon. The conjoint tendon is a structure formed by the fusion of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, and it lies medially to the iliopubic tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The iliopubic tract is a fibrous band in the inguinal region that fans out laterally and blends with the fascia iliaca.
  • It is crucial in understanding the anatomy of the inguinal region, particularly in the context of inguinal hernias.

choices.text: Choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia- Sturge Weber syndrome
Retinal hemangiomas – Von hippel lindau syndrome
B/L Lisch nodules, eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- Neurofibromatosis – 2
Iris coloboma, Retinal astrocytoma – Tuberous sclerosis

questions.text: Choose the incorrect option:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B/L Lisch nodules, eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- Neurofibromatosis – 2

 

  • Bilateral Lisch nodules and eyelid plexiform neurofibromas are actually characteristic of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2). NF2 is more commonly associated with posterior subcapsular cataract and retinal hamartomas, but not Lisch nodules or eyelid plexiform neurofibromas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia - Sturge Weber syndrome

  • Sturge Weber syndrome is associated with ocular manifestations such as choroidal hemangioma and iris heterochromia. These features are typical and consistent with the syndrome.

 

Option B. Retinal hemangiomas – Von Hippel Lindau syndrome

  • Von Hippel Lindau syndrome commonly presents with retinal hemangiomas. This is a key ocular manifestation of the syndrome, making this option correct.

 

Option D. Iris coloboma, Retinal astrocytoma – Tuberous sclerosis

  • Tuberous sclerosis typically presents with ocular manifestations such as atypical iris coloboma and retinal astrocytoma. These features are indicative of the condition, confirming the accuracy of this option.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia- Sturge Weber syndrome
  • Retinal hemangiomas – Von hippel lindau syndrome
  • B/L Lisch nodules, eyelid plexiform neurofibroma- Neurofibromatosis – 1
  • Iris coloboma, Retinal astrocytoma – Tuberous sclerosis

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with the respective odor of urine

 

Column A

1. Isovaleric acidemia

2. Phenylketonuria

3. Tyrosinemia

4. MSUD

 

Column B

a. Maple syrup

b. Sweaty feet

c. Boiled cabbage

d. Mousy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a

 

  • 1-b: Isovaleric acidemia is associated with a distinctive "sweaty feet" odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.
  • 2-d: Phenylketonuria often presents a "mousy" odor in the urine, which results from phenylalanine breakdown products.
  • 3-c: Tyrosinemia can result in a urine odor resembling "boiled cabbage" due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.
  • 4-a: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is named after the characteristic "maple syrup" odor of the urine caused by the accumulation of certain amino acids.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Primary direct inguinal hernia with a 3 cm defect is labelled as PM2. This nomenclature is according to which classification system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) European Hernia Society

 

  • The European Hernia Society's classification system is the most recent and is based on whether the hernia is primary or recurrent, the location (lateral, medial, or femoral), and the size of the defect measured in fingerbreadths.
  • The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of:
    • Primary or recurrent (P or R);
    • Lateral, medial or femoral (L, M or F);
    • Defect size in fingerbreadths (assumed to be 1.5 cm), with three sizes of one fingerbreadth or less, between one and three fingerbreadths and three or more fingerbreadths.

 

E.g., A primary indirect inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gilbert: Gilbert's classification is an older system that classifies inguinal hernias based on their anatomic position and the integrity of the inguinal canal floor.

 

Option B. Nyhus:  The Nyhus classification, which is also one of the older systems, is based on the presence of a hernia sac, the condition of the internal ring, and the presence or absence of a posterior wall defect.

 

Option C. Rives-Stoppa:  This is not a classification system for hernias but rather a technique for ventral hernia repair using a large sublay mesh.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The European Hernia Society's classification is the most recent system for classifying groin hernias, which includes primary or recurrent status, location of the hernia, and the size of the defect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman experiences postpartum hemorrhage following the delivery of her baby. To manage this condition, the healthcare provider considers administering PGF2 alpha. What is the maximum dose of PGF2 alpha used for treating postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

  • Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is a significant cause of maternal morbidity and mortality.
  • Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2 alpha) is one of the medications used to manage this condition by stimulating uterine contractions and reducing bleeding.
  • The recommended dose of PGF2 alpha is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly, and it can be repeated every 15 to 90 minutes if necessary.
  • However, the total cumulative dose should not exceed 2 mg.
  • This limit is set to prevent potential side effects and ensure the safety of the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum cumulative dose of PGF2 alpha for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg.

choices.text: Paralytic ileus - Put a NG tube

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting 3 years following an open appendectomy. Abdominal examination reveals hyper-peristalsis. X ray abdomen showed the following. What is the likely pathology and the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adhesive obstruction - CECT abdomen

 

  • Adhesive obstruction is the MC complication (late) of appendicectomy. X ray shows mechanical obstruction- step ladder pattern of air fluid levels.
  • Next step in mechanical obstruction is CECT abdomen to identify etiology/site of obstruction and presence of bowel ischemia.
  • Adhesive obstruction occurs as a late complication of abdominal surgery, such as appendectomy, due to the formation of scar tissue (adhesions) that cause mechanical obstruction of the intestine.
  • Patients typically present with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension.
  • The presence of a step ladder pattern of air-fluid levels on X-ray suggests a mechanical obstruction, consistent with adhesive obstruction.
  • Therefore, obtaining a CECT abdomen is the next step in management to further evaluate the etiology, site, and severity of the obstruction, as well as to assess for signs of bowel ischemia or other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paralytic ileus - Put a NG tube: Paralytic ileus is characterized by decreased bowel motility without mechanical obstruction. Patients typically present with decreased or absent bowel sounds and lack of peristalsis. Inserting a nasogastric (NG) tube for decompression may be indicated to relieve abdominal distension and vomiting. However, in this case, the presence of a step ladder pattern of air-fluid levels on X-ray suggests a mechanical obstruction rather than paralytic ileus.

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus - CECT abdomen: Paralytic ileus is characterized by generalized decreased bowel motility due to various causes such as surgery, inflammation, or neurological dysfunction. It typically presents with diffuse abdominal distension, absence of peristalsis, and lack of bowel sounds. In this scenario, however, the X-ray findings indicate a mechanical obstruction with a step ladder pattern of air-fluid levels, which is not consistent with paralytic ileus. Therefore, obtaining a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) abdomen, while useful in certain clinical scenarios to assess for complications or underlying pathology, may not be the most appropriate next step given the suggestive findings of mechanical obstruction.

 

Option D. Adhesive obstruction â€“ laparotomy: While adhesive obstruction may ultimately require surgical intervention, such as laparotomy, for definitive management, it is essential to first obtain imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of the obstruction. A CECT abdomen provides valuable information about the underlying pathology, location of obstruction, and presence of complications such as bowel ischemia. Therefore, proceeding directly to laparotomy without prior imaging may not be warranted and could potentially lead to unnecessary surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While all options involve aspects of management for bowel obstruction, the presence of a step ladder pattern of air-fluid levels on X-ray suggests mechanical obstruction, likely due to adhesive obstruction.
  • The next appropriate step is to obtain a CECT abdomen to further evaluate the etiology and extent of the obstruction before considering surgical intervention.

choices.text: CSF PCR for viral DNA
CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a one-day history of high fever, altered mental status, severe headache, neck rigidity, and new-onset seizures. He also reports having had oral herpes flare-ups in the past. Given the clinical presentation and history, HSV encephalitis is suspected, and a lumbar puncture is performed to obtain CSF for definitive diagnostic testing. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

 

  • The gold standard for diagnosing HSV encephalitis is the demonstration of HSV DNA in the CSF by PCR.
  • This method is highly specific and provides rapid results, which are essential for the timely initiation of antiviral therapy.
  • HSV-1, the typical cause of encephalitis, has properties like latency in the trigeminal ganglia and a transmission mode through direct contact with mucosa or abraded skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM in CSF: Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

 

Option B. Tzanck smear of CSF: Rapid, fairly sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method, but prepared from the lesions, preferably from the base of vesicles and stained with 1% aqueous solution of toluidine blue ‘0’ for 15 seconds, not CSF.

 

Option D. CSF culture on chick embryo lines: HSV-1 does not grow well in chick embryo fibroblast cultures, making this method inefficient for the confirmation of HSV encephalitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For suspected HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the diagnostic test of choice due to its high specificity and sensitivity.
  • Other investigations that can help include:
  • CSF examination    
  • CSF culture
  • Serological studies
  • MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

choices.text: Acyclovir and induction of labor
Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery
Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida presents at 36 weeks of gestation with painful vulvar ulcers. She has no history of similar lesions in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

  • The presence of multiple painful vesicular lesions at 36 weeks’ gestation is highly suggestive of a primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
  • HSV infection in late pregnancy, especially with active lesions, poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can be severe or even fatal.
  • The best management in this scenario includes administering acyclovir to help reduce viral load and performing an elective Cesarean section to prevent the transmission of the virus to the newborn during vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate, induction of labor would still pose a high risk of neonatal herpes transmission if active lesions are present at the time of delivery.

 

Option B. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Administering antivirals is important, but allowing a normal vaginal delivery with active HSV lesions would significantly increase the risk of neonatal herpes.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Allowing spontaneous vaginal delivery in the presence of active HSV lesions carries a high risk of transmitting the virus to the newborn, leading to potentially severe neonatal herpes infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the case of a primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with active lesions in late pregnancy, the best treatment option is to administer antiviral therapy such as acyclovir and to plan an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes transmission.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of Crohn's disease presents with fatigue, jaundice, and pruritus. Liver function tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase levels. Which of the following is NOT a common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemolytic anemia

 

  • Crohn's disease, an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), is often associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations, affecting various organs outside the gastrointestinal tract.
  • However, Hemolytic anemia is not typically associated with Crohn's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a known, though less common, extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease, particularly in cases with extensive colonic involvement.

 

Option B. Erythema nodosum: Erythema nodosum is a common dermatologic manifestation in Crohn's disease, often presenting as painful, red nodules on the legs.

 

Option C. Uveitis: Uveitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the eyes and is a recognized extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis, erythema nodosum, and uveitis are common extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease.
  • Hemolytic anemia, however, is not typically associated with Crohn's disease.

choices.text: Grey kit for scrotal swelling with Azithromycin and Cefixime
Green kit for vaginal discharge with Secnidazole and Fluconazole
Red kit for herpetic genito-ulcerative disease with Acyclovir
Blue kit for non-herpetic genito-ulcerative disease with Azithromycin and Benzathine penicillin

questions.text: Identify the mismatched option out of the following option of the color-coded STI kit and its intended syndrome or treatment contents:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blue kit for non-herpetic genito-ulcerative disease with Azithromycin and Benzathine penicillin

 

  • This is incorrect as the blue kit for non-herpetic genito-ulcerative disease in a patient allergic to penicillin should contain Azithromycin and Doxycycline, not Benzathine penicillin. Benzathine penicillin is inappropriate for patients allergic to penicillin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grey kit for scrotal swelling with Azithromycin and Cefixime: Grey kit contains Azithromycin and Cefixime, appropriate for treating urethral, anorectal, cervical discharge, or scrotal swelling.

 

Option B. Green kit for vaginal discharge with Secnidazole and Fluconazole: Green kit includes Secnidazole and Fluconazole, suitable for treating vaginal discharge due to causes like trichomoniasis, candidiasis, or bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option C. Red kit for herpetic genito-ulcerative disease with Acyclovir: Red kit with Acyclovir is used for managing herpetic genito-ulcerative disease, focusing on herpes simplex virus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

STI color coded kits are as follows:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with bronchial asthma, regularly using inhalational steroids, reports to his physician complaining of white patchy lesions on his tongue and inside his cheeks. He is concerned about these symptoms, which appeared shortly after starting his new medication regimen. Given these symptoms, what is the most appropriate antifungal medication to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

  • The patient's symptoms are indicative of oral candidiasis, a common complication in individuals using inhalational steroids due to the immunosuppressive effect of steroids and their tendency to alter normal oral flora.
  • Clotrimazole, an antifungal medication from the azole group, is effective for treating this condition as it inhibits ergosterol synthesis, a crucial component of the fungal cell membrane.
  • It is commonly used topically for the treatment of oral candidiasis and is available in lozenge form, which is suitable for oral infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: This drug targets dermatophytes by disrupting microtubule function and is primarily used for tinea infections of the scalp, skin, and nails but is ineffective against Candida species.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Acts by inhibiting squalene epoxidase in the fungal cell, disrupting ergosterol biosynthesis. It is primarily used for nail onychomycosis and dermatophyte infections, not for oral candidiasis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: A systemic antifungal that inhibits fungal DNA and RNA synthesis. It is typically used in severe systemic fungal infections and is not indicated for oral candidiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For asthma patients experiencing oral candidiasis due to inhalational steroid use, clotrimazole is the recommended treatment.
  • It is effective, easy to use, and targets the pathogenic yeast directly in the oral cavity, relieving symptoms and eradicating the infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, diagnosed with both HIV and chronic hepatitis B, is being evaluated for antiviral therapy options. Which antiviral drug, known to have dual activity against both HIV and hepatitis B, would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emtricitabine

 

  • Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against both HIV and hepatitis B virus (HBV).
  • This dual antiviral activity makes it particularly valuable in treating patients co-infected with both viruses.
  • Emtricitabine is often used in combination with other antiretrovirals to provide a potent antiviral regimen for HIV, while also managing HBV replication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enfuviritide: This drug is a fusion inhibitor specific to HIV and does not have efficacy against HBV.

 

Option B. Abacavir: Another NRTI effective against HIV but does not have activity against HBV.

 

Option D. Ritonavir: Primarily used as a booster for other protease inhibitors in the treatment of HIV; it does not have activity against HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Emtricitabine is effective in the treatment of both HIV and chronic hepatitis B, making it a crucial option for patients co-infected with these viruses.

 

Mnemonic for the drug have dual activity against HIV and HBV –

L: Lamivudine

E: Emtricitabine

T: Tenofovir

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents for evaluation of infertility. Imaging studies reveal a septum in her uterine cavity. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

  • Hysteroscopic and septoplasty is the preferred method for managing a uterine septum in a patient with infertility.
  • This minimally invasive procedure allows direct visualization and precise resection of the septum within the uterine cavity.
  • It has the advantage of a shorter recovery time and lower complication rates compared to open surgical procedures.
  • The goal of septoplasty is to restore the normal uterine cavity shape, which can improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and Metroplasty: While laparoscopy is a minimally invasive procedure, it is not typically used for the resection of a uterine septum. Metroplasty via laparoscopy is more commonly associated with the correction of other uterine anomalies, such as a bicornuate uterus.

 

Option C. Laparotomy and Metroplasty: Laparotomy, an open surgical procedure, and metroplasty are more invasive and are generally reserved for more complex uterine anomalies. They are not first-line treatments for a uterine septum due to the increased morbidity compared to hysteroscopic approaches.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not indicated for a uterine septum, especially in a patient desiring future fertility. This option would eliminate the possibility of pregnancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most appropriate management for a uterine septum in a patient with infertility is hysteroscopic septoplasty.
  • This minimally invasive procedure effectively corrects the uterine anomaly with lower risks and a quicker recovery, improving the chances of a successful pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for performing a dilatation and curettage (D&C) in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in the presence of active pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • Performing a D&C in a patient with PID can exacerbate the infection, potentially leading to severe complications such as sepsis, spread of the infection, or damage to the reproductive organs.
  • PID needs to be treated and resolved before considering D&C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectopic pregnancy: While D&C is not used to treat ectopic pregnancy, the presence of an ectopic pregnancy is not a direct contraindication for the procedure. Ectopic pregnancy requires specific management, typically with methotrexate or surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis is not a contraindication for D&C. The procedure can be performed if indicated for other reasons, such as abnormal uterine bleeding.

 

Option C. Menstrual irregularities: Menstrual irregularities themselves are not a contraindication for D&C. In fact, D&C can be performed as a diagnostic or therapeutic procedure for menstrual irregularities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in patients with active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing severe complications.
  • PID should be treated and resolved before considering D&C.

choices.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

 

  • Closed reduction involves manipulating the displaced hip joint back into its normal position without surgery.
  • Once reduction is achieved, the stability of the hip joint is assessed through physical examination and imaging studies.
  • Closed reduction may be considered as the initial management step for traumatic hip dislocations, especially in the acute setting.
  • However, the decision to proceed with closed reduction depends on various factors, including the stability of the reduction, the presence of associated injuries, and the patient's overall condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT and 3D Reconstruction: Computed tomography (CT) imaging, often with three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction, provides detailed anatomical information about the hip joint and surrounding structures. It can help assess the extent of injury, including associated fractures, displacement, and involvement of intra-articular structures. CT with 3D reconstruction is commonly performed in patients with traumatic hip injuries to further evaluate the extent of the injury and guide treatment planning. It can provide valuable information for surgical decision-making, especially in cases where closed reduction may not be feasible or sufficient.

 

Option C. High Weight Skeletal Traction: High weight skeletal traction involves applying traction to the injured limb using a system of pulleys and weights to stabilize the fracture or dislocation and temporarily relieve pain.  High weight skeletal traction may be used as a temporary measure to stabilize the hip joint and provide pain relief while awaiting definitive management, such as surgery or closed reduction. However, it is typically not the next step in management following a traumatic hip dislocation without further evaluation.

 

Option D. Open Reduction and Posterior Pillar of Acetabulum Reconstruction: Open reduction involves surgically accessing the hip joint to manipulate the displaced bones back into their normal position. In cases of acetabular fractures involving the posterior pillar, surgical reconstruction may be necessary to restore the normal anatomy of the hip joint. Open reduction with posterior pillar reconstruction is indicated in cases of complex acetabular fractures associated with hip dislocation or instability. However, the decision to proceed with this surgical intervention would typically be based on the findings of thorough imaging studies, including CT scans, and a comprehensive assessment of the patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given case is a traumatic posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • The initial treatment of choice is the closed reduction of the dislocation followed by investigation and assessment of the reduction and the surrounding tissues for deciding on the further treatment process.

choices.text: Disorder of sleep arousal
Person will have full consciousness
Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion
There may be neurological conditions associated

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents because they are concerned about his sleep behavior. They report that over the past few months, he has been getting out of bed during the night and walking around the house, and unresponsive to their attempts to communicate with him.  What is the false statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness

 

  • The child's symptoms suggest sleepwalking (somnambulism), a type of parasomnia, which is a disorder of sleep arousal.
  • Sleepwalking involves getting out of bed and walking around during sleep, and the person is usually unresponsive to attempts to communicate and has no memory of the event.
  • We arrived at this answer because one key characteristic of sleepwalking is the lack of full consciousness during the episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: This is true. Sleepwalking is classified as a disorder of sleep arousal, occurring during the transition from deep sleep to lighter stages of sleep.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: This is true. Episodes often end with the person awakening in a state of confusion or simply returning to bed without full awareness of the episode.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: This is true. Sleepwalking can be associated with various neurological or developmental conditions, though it can also occur in otherwise healthy individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep.
  • Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of recurrent bacterial infections is evaluated for possible immunodeficiency. Laboratory tests reveal normal immunoglobulin levels but an abnormality in the phagocytosis process of his polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs). After the complement and antibody bind to the surface of encapsulated bacteria, which of the following components is crucial for the effective phagocytosis by PMNs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudopod extension

 

  • After opsonization, which involves the binding of antibodies and complement to the surface of encapsulated bacteria, the phagocytosis process by polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) involves the extension of pseudopods.
  • Pseudopods are protrusions of the cell membrane that extend around the bacteria to engulf and internalize them into phagosomes.
  • This process is critical for the ingestion of the bacteria following the initial binding and recognition steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fc and C3b: While the binding of Fc receptors to the Fc portion of antibodies and complement receptors to C3b is crucial for opsonization, it is the subsequent pseudopod extension that physically engulfs the bacteria, leading to phagocytosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory Burst: The respiratory burst is an antimicrobial mechanism that occurs after the bacteria have been engulfed, where reactive oxygen species are produced to kill the ingested pathogens. It does not play a direct role in the initial engulfment process.

 

Option D. Receptor-mediated Endocytosis: This process involves the uptake of specific molecules via receptors on the cell surface. While related to the internalization of substances, it is not specific to the phagocytosis of opsonized bacteria by PMNs in the context described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • After opsonization by antibodies and complement, the effective phagocytosis of encapsulated bacteria by polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) involves the extension of pseudopods, which are cellular protrusions that engulf and internalize the bacteria.

choices.text: Resection of proximal jejunum

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma of pancreatic head underwent surgery. All of the following are done in the procedure shown below except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Caudate lobectomy

 

  • The procedure shown is Whipple’s procedure.
  • The operation has three distinct phases:
  • exploration and assessment;
  • Resection
  • Reconstruction.
  • Structures removed-
  • Head of pancreas
  • Duodenum, proximal jejunum (Option B)
  • Common bile duct
  • Gallbladder (Option D)
  • Distal stomach (removed in original Whipple’s but can be preserved in surgeries done these days)
  • Lymph nodes
  • Reconstruction- in this order-
  • Pancreaticojejunostomy
  • Choledochojejunostomy/hepaticejejunostomy (Option A)
  • Duodenojejunostomy / Gastrojejunostomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Whipple’s procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, proximal jejunum, common bile duct, gallbladder, and sometimes part of the stomach.
  • Reconstruction involves pancreaticojejunostomy, choledochojejunostomy, and gastrojejunostomy or duodenojejunostomy.

choices.text: Percentage of children under 5 suffering from malnutrition

questions.text: Dr Ishan is analyzing global health data to prepare a policy brief on nutritional interventions. In reviewing the Global Hunger Index (GHI), he notes several indicators that measure hunger's impact on populations. Dr. Ishan seeks to clarify which indicator does not contribute to the GHI calculations. Which of the following is not used in compiling the Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infant mortality rate

 

  • The Global Hunger Index does not include the infant mortality rate as part of its indicators.
  • The GHI specifically uses the under-5 mortality rate, which encompasses the broader category of child deaths under five years old, not just infants.
  • This wider scope helps provide a more comprehensive measure of the health impacts of malnutrition and hunger in young children.

 

To capture the multidimensional nature of hunger, GHI scores are based on the following indicators:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Under-5 mortality rate: Incorrect. The under-5 mortality rate is indeed a part of the GHI reflecting the mortality among children under five years of age due to nutritional and other health-related factors.

 

Option C. Percentage of undernourished population: Incorrect. The percentage of the undernourished population is a key component of the GHI, indicating the breadth of hunger within a community or nation.

 

Option D. Percentage of children under 5 suffering from malnutrition: Incorrect. The percentage of children under 5 suffering from malnutrition including indicators such as wasting and stunting, is crucial for the GHI's assessment of the depth of hunger's impact on the most vulnerable populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - India, Global Hunger Index GHI 2021: Score 27.5, Serious level of hunger (Rank 101st out of the 116 countries)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who has been employed at a paint manufacturing factory for the past two decades, presents with complaints of persistent joint pain, difficulty sleeping, chronic fatigue, constipation, and recurrent headaches. Laboratory findings reveal that he has anemia. Which enzyme is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ferrochelatase

 

  • This patient’s clinical presentation is indicative of chronic lead poisoning, commonly seen in individuals with prolonged exposure to lead-based paints. Lead poisoning interferes with several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, with ferrochelatase being one of the most notably affected enzymes.
  • Ferrochelatase catalyzes the final step in heme synthesis, where iron is inserted into protoporphyrin IX to form heme.
  • Lead inhibits this enzyme, leading to the accumulation of protoporphyrin and subsequent anemia due to defective heme synthesis.
  • The symptoms such as joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, and headache, alongside anemia, align with chronic lead exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: This enzyme is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III in the heme synthesis pathway. Deficiency in this enzyme leads to congenital erythropoietic porphyria, which presents differently with photosensitivity and disfiguring skin lesions, not the symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option C. ALA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in heme synthesis, converting glycine and succinyl-CoA to delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). Mutations or deficiencies in ALA synthase lead to X-linked sideroblastic anemia, presenting with microcytic anemia, which is not consistent with the patient's history and symptoms related to chronic lead exposure.

 

Option D. Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase: Also known as hydroxymethylbilane synthase, this enzyme is involved in the conversion of porphobilinogen to hydroxymethylbilane.
