Deficiency in this enzyme results in acute intermittent porphyria, characterized by abdominal pain, neuropathies, and psychiatric symptoms, which do not align with this patient’s chronic presentation of lead poisoning symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic lead exposure in industrial settings, such as paint manufacturing, can inhibit ferrochelatase, leading to anemia and a constellation of symptoms including joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, and headache.

questions.text: A 19-year-old Girl presents with a six-month history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea. On examination, she has a palpable pelvic mass on the left side and signs of ascites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

 

  • The clinical presentation of prolonged low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea, along with the physical findings of a pelvic mass and ascites, strongly suggest a diagnosis of genital tuberculosis.
  • Tuberculosis can involve the fallopian tubes and ovaries, forming a tubo-ovarian mass.
  • The systemic symptoms of fever and weight loss are also consistent with tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroids typically cause heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain but are less likely to present with systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and ascites.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy usually presents with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, rather than chronic systemic symptoms like low-grade fever and weight loss. It typically results in an adnexal mass, not ascites.

 

Option D. Ovarian malignancy: While ovarian malignancy can present with a pelvic mass and ascites, it is less common in an 18-year-old. Additionally, the systemic symptoms of low-grade fever and weight loss are more suggestive of an infectious process like tuberculosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The combination of prolonged systemic symptoms (low-grade fever, weight loss), abdominal pain, amenorrhea, a pelvic mass, and ascites in an 18-year-old girl strongly suggests tuberculosis with a tubo-ovarian mass.
  • This diagnosis is supported by the characteristic clinical presentation and findings.

choices.text: Increased Capillary Permeability due to Inflammation or Injury
Elevated Hydrostatic Pressure within the Capillaries
Impaired Lymphatic Drainage leading to Inadequate Lymph Flow
Enhanced Levels of Plasma Proteins exerting Increased Oncotic Pressure

questions.text: A 52-year-old male was admitted to the general medicine inpatient ward with severe breathlessness and generalized body swelling. Considering the multifactorial aspects of edema development, which of the following factors is LEAST likely to significantly contribute to the pathogenesis of edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enhanced Levels of Plasma Proteins exerting Increased Oncotic Pressure

 

  • Enhanced levels of plasma proteins exerting increased oncotic pressure is the least likely factor to contribute to the development of edema.
  • Oncotic pressure is primarily generated by plasma proteins, mainly albumin, which draw water into the capillaries from the interstitial spaces, helping to maintain fluid balance.
  • Increased oncotic pressure would actually counteract the formation of edema by reducing fluid leakage from the capillaries.
  • Therefore, in the context of edema development, increased plasma protein levels are protective rather than contributory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Capillary Permeability due to Inflammation or Injury: This factor significantly contributes to the development of edema. When capillary permeability is increased, proteins and fluids can leak into the interstitial space, causing swelling. Conditions such as infections, allergic reactions, and injuries can increase capillary permeability, leading to edema.

 

Option B. Elevated Hydrostatic Pressure within the Capillaries: This factor is a major contributor to edema. Elevated hydrostatic pressure forces fluid out of the capillaries and into the interstitial space. This can occur in conditions like congestive heart failure, where increased venous pressure raises capillary hydrostatic pressure, promoting fluid leakage and swelling.

 

Option C. Impaired Lymphatic Drainage leading to Inadequate Lymph Flow: This factor also significantly contributes to edema. The lymphatic system is responsible for draining excess fluid from the interstitial space. Impaired lymphatic drainage, due to conditions such as lymphatic obstruction or damage, leads to fluid accumulation and edema. This can be seen in lymphedema, often resulting from surgical removal of lymph nodes or radiation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enhanced levels of plasma proteins exerting increased oncotic pressure are least likely to significantly contribute to the pathogenesis of edema, as they help to draw fluid back into the capillaries and maintain fluid balance, opposing the development of edema.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a history of hypertension, episodes of palpitations, and neck swelling. Genetic testing reveals a mutation consistent with Sipple Syndrome. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Sipple Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperthyroidism

 

  • Sipple Syndrome, also known as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2 (MEN2), typically includes medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Hyperthyroidism is not a characteristic feature of this syndrome.
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma, which arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid, is a hallmark of MEN2 but does not cause hyperthyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pheochromocytoma: This adrenal gland tumor is a common feature of MEN2 and can cause episodic hypertension due to catecholamine secretion.

 

Option B. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a key component of MEN2 and arises from the calcitonin-secreting C cells of the thyroid.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism: Primary hyperparathyroidism, often due to hyperplasia or adenomas of the parathyroid glands, is another feature of MEN2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sipple Syndrome (MEN2) is characterized by the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.
  • Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of this syndrome.

 

Mutation:

 

  • MEN 2A is associated with a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene
  • Screening and prophylactic thyroidectomy may be done in relatives with the mutation

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, working in flood relief efforts, develops severe abdominal cramps, noticeable yellowing of the skin, redness in the eyes, and notices blood in his urine, which started about a week ago. Given his environmental exposure to potentially contaminated water and the clinical presentation, which diagnostic test would be most appropriate to confirm the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

  • The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the preferred diagnostic tool for leptospirosis, particularly relevant in this scenario where the patient has been exposed to potentially contaminated water during flood relief activities.
  • Leptospirosis, caused by the bacterium Leptospira interrogans, can present with symptoms such as jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria, matching the patient's symptoms.
  • MAT detects antibodies against Leptospira in the patient's serum, providing a definitive diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Widal test:  Incorrect, as it is specifically used for identifying typhoid fever, which is characterized by a slow-onset fever and gastrointestinal disturbances, not primarily by the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction:  Incorrect, it tests for rickettsial infections, presenting with symptoms like fever, rash, and headaches, but not typically jaundice or hematuria.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test:  Incorrect, this tests for infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, which does not align with the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Microscopic Agglutination Test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in individuals exposed to water contaminated with the Leptospira bacteria.
  • Recognizing and confirming leptospirosis early allows for timely treatment, which is vital in preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a 5-year history of increasing dyspnea. On physical examination, breath sounds are decreased in all lung fields. A chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm and increased lucency in all lung fields. Pulmonary function tests show a markedly decreased FEV1 and mildly reduced FVC. His younger brother has similar symptoms. What is the likely mechanism of his pulmonary pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduced anti-elastase activity

 

  • The presentation of dyspnea, decreased breath sounds, flattened diaphragm, and increased lung lucency on X-ray, along with markedly decreased FEV1 and mildly reduced FVC on pulmonary function tests, is indicative of emphysema.
  • The familial occurrence suggests a genetic cause, such as alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency.
  • AAT deficiency leads to reduced anti-elastase activity, allowing unopposed elastase to break down elastic fibers in the lungs, causing emphysema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Neutrophil Proteases: While increased neutrophil proteases can damage lung tissue, the primary issue in this case is the lack of inhibition due to AAT deficiency. The reduced anti-elastase activity allows these proteases to cause significant damage.

 

Option B. Prior Infection with TB: Tuberculosis can cause chronic lung damage, but it typically results in fibrosis and granulomas rather than diffuse emphysematous changes seen in this patient.

 

Option D. CFTR Gene Mutation: Cystic fibrosis (CF) results from CFTR gene mutations and typically presents with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and pancreatic insufficiency. The findings in this case are more consistent with emphysema due to AAT deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to reduced anti-elastase activity, causing unopposed elastase activity and resulting in early-onset emphysema.
  • This genetic disorder should be considered in patients with early-onset emphysema and a family history of similar symptoms.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Î±1-antitrypsin is a serine protease inhibitor made in the liver.
  • Its role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, an enzyme that digests elastin in alveolar walls.
  • In AAT deficiency, there's reduced anti-elastase activity, leading to uncontrolled elastin breakdown â†’ alveolar wall destruction â†’ panacinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the psychiatric clinic complaining that others can hear what he is thinking. He is distressed and believes this is happening constantly. Which of the following best fits the above description?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thought broadcasting

 

  • The patient's complaint that others can hear his thoughts fits the description of thought broadcasting, a type of disorder of possession of thought, where an individual believes their thoughts are being broadcasted or transmitted to others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: This is another type of disorder of possession of thought, where an individual believes that thoughts are being placed into one's mind by an external force. The patient believes the thoughts are not his own but are inserted by someone else.

 

Option B. Thought withdrawal: This refers to another type of disorder of possession of thought, where an individual believes that thoughts are being removed from one’s mind by an external force. The patient feels that his thoughts are being taken away.

 

Option D. Thought echo: Also known as "audible thoughts," this involves hearing one's thoughts spoken aloud shortly after thinking them. It’s an auditory hallucination where the person hears their own thoughts repeated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thought broadcasting is a type of disorder of possession of thought where an individual believes their thoughts are accessible to others without their consent.

questions.text: What will be the management in the case of a 6-month-old baby with the following presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manipulation & cast

 

  • The image provided shows the feet of a baby, and they appear to be in a position consistent with clubfoot (talipes equinovarus).
  • For a 6-month-old baby with clubfoot, the most appropriate initial management is non-surgical, involving manipulation and casting. This is typically done using the Ponseti method.
  • Manipulation and casting involve manually manipulating the affected limb to correct alignment followed by immobilization in a cast to maintain the corrected position. 
  • This approach is generally preferred in infants due to their rapid growth and development, as it allows for gradual correction of the deformity without the need for invasive surgery.
  • Gentle manipulations are performed to gradually correct the deformities, followed by the application of a cast to hold the correction. This is repeated weekly. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triple Arthrodesis: Triple arthrodesis is a surgical procedure that involves fusing three joints in the foot: the subtalar joint, the talonavicular joint, and the calcaneocuboid joint. It is typically performed to correct severe deformities or instability in the foot and ankle, such as those associated with severe flatfoot deformity or certain types of arthritis. Triple arthrodesis is a complex surgical procedure that is generally reserved for older children or adults with significant severe, rigid, and painful foot deformities or functional impairments that haven't responded to other treatments. It is not typically considered as a primary treatment option for infants, especially at 6 months of age, unless there are exceptionally severe deformities or abnormalities present, which would be rare at this age. 

 

Option B. Osteotomy: Osteotomy is a surgical procedure that involves cutting and reshaping bones to correct deformities, improve alignment, or alleviate pressure on affected joints. Osteotomy may be considered in older children or adolescents with bone deformities or growth abnormalities that require surgical correction. However, it is less commonly performed in infants, especially at 6 months of age, due to the immaturity of the skeletal system and the potential risks associated with surgery in such young patients. 

 

Option C. Postero-medial soft tissue procedure: Postero-medial soft tissue procedures involve surgical techniques aimed at addressing soft tissue abnormalities or contractures in the posterior and medial aspects of a joint, such as the ankle or foot. These procedures may include tendon lengthening, tendon transfers, or release of tight ligaments or fascia. Some babies with clubfoot may eventually require a limited posterior release (especially a percutaneous Achilles tenotomy) as part of the Ponseti method, or a more extensive soft tissue release if Ponseti fails, but it is not the initial management for a 6-month-old. The initial approach is always non-surgical manipulation and casting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a child of 6 months of age with clubfoot deformity, the treatment of choice is the manipulation of the foot followed by cast application. 
  • The other options are used for older children or adolescents.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a 4-year-old boy with a medical history of recurrent fungal skin infections and frequent upper respiratory tract infections starting from early infancy. The child's immune response is suspected to be compromised. Which vaccine is contraindicated in this patient due to his medical condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles, Mumps, Rubella (MMR) vaccine

 

  • This is correct because the MMR vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, which poses a risk to immunocompromised individuals like this child.
  • His history of recurrent infections suggests an underlying immunodeficiency, making live vaccines potentially dangerous as they may cause the diseases they are designed to prevent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inactivated polio vaccine: Incorrect- IPV is an inactivated vaccine which does not contain live organisms and is therefore safe for immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. Diphtheria, Tetanus, acellular Pertussis: Incorrect- The DTaP vaccine contains diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and acellular pertussis:  all of which are either inactivated or acellular, making them safe for use in patients with compromised immune systems.

 

Option D. Tetanus toxoid vaccine: Incorrect- The tetanus toxoid vaccine: containing inactivated toxin, is also safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

questions.text: Dr. Roma is conducting a research study to analyze the association between different treatment methods and patient recovery rates. She decides to use the chi-square test to evaluate the data collected from various patient groups. As she prepares her analysis plan, she reviews the essentials required for the chi-square test. Which of the following is NOT required for performing a chi-square test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Means in different groups

 

  • This is correct. The chi-square test is used to compare categorical variables and assess whether differences between observed and expected frequencies are statistically significant.
  • It primarily deals with proportions or frequencies within categories, not means.
  • Therefore, calculating means in different groups is not necessary when using the chi-square test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Null hypothesis: Incorrect. A null hypothesis is essential for the chi-square test, as it typically states that there is no association between the variables being studied, which the test then seeks to either reject or fail to reject.

 

Option B. Degrees of freedom: Incorrect. Degrees of freedom are crucial in determining the chi-square test's critical value from the chi-square distribution table, which is necessary to interpret the test's results.

 

Option D. Proportions in different groups: Incorrect. Proportions in different groups are fundamental to the chi-square test, as it analyzes the differences between observed and expected proportions (or frequencies) across categorical groups.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chi-square test (χ2 – TEST):

 

  • Is a ‘non-parametric test’ of significance
  • Is used to ‘test significance of association between 2 or
  • more QUALITATIVE characteristics’
  • Is used for non – Normal (non–Gaussian) distributions
  • Applications of Chi-square test:

 

1. Test of proportions

2. Test of association

3. Test of goodness of fit.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting and respiratory distress. His BP was found to be 80/40 mm Hg and pulse rate of 115/min. The following chest X-ray was recorded in ER. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscous perforation

 

Management of Peritonitis 

 

  • General care of patient 
  • Correction of fluid & electrolyte imbalance 
  • Insertion of nasogastric drainage tube & urinary catheter 
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy 
  • Analgesia 
  • Vital system support 
  • Operative (laparotomy) treatment of cause 
  • Remove or divert cause 
  • Peritoneal lavage Â± drainage 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tension pneumothorax: This would manifest as absent lung markings on the affected side, tracheal deviation, and mediastinal shift on the chest X-ray. The current X-ray does not show these signs.

 

Option C. Normal findings: The presence of free air under the diaphragm is an abnormal and significant finding, indicating pathology.

 

Option D. Pyloric stenosis: This is a condition typically seen in infants causing projectile vomiting and is not associated with free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on the chest X-ray, combined with the patient's severe abdominal symptoms and signs of shock, strongly indicates a hollow viscous perforation.

choices.text: Average life span at birth
Disease frequency at a single point in time

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing various health statistics to evaluate the burden of disease in a community. Which of the following metrics is not used to assess mortality rates directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disease frequency at a single point in time

 

  • Disease frequency at a single point in time, also known as prevalence, is not a direct indicator of mortality.
  • It measures the total number of cases of a disease within a population at a specific time, encompassing both new and existing cases, and does not directly relate to death statistics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total life years lost (YPLL): This indicator focuses on the years that are lost due to premature mortality, emphasizing the impact of diseases that cause early death and is a direct measure of mortality.

 

Option B. Average life span at birth (Life expectancy): This is a primary mortality indicator that estimates the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates continue to apply. It is used globally to assess the overall health status of populations.

 

Option C. Death rate in infants (Infant Mortality Rate): This rate measures the number of infant deaths per 1,000 live births within their first year of life, directly reflecting the effectiveness of healthcare during and after pregnancy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

MORTALITY INDICATORS

 

  • Crude Death Rate, Age specific death rates, Disease-specific Mortality Rate
  • Expectation of Life
  • IMR, MMR, U5MR, Child Mortality Rate
  • Case fatality rate, Proportional Mortality Rate
  • Years of potential life years lost

choices.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, salt and pepper retinopathy – Rubella
Periventricular calcifications, microcephaly- Toxoplasmosis
Vesicular lesions, microcephaly – Herpes simplex virus
Chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications – CMV

questions.text: Choose the incorrect option:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periventricular calcifications, microcephaly- Toxoplasmosis

 

  • Toxoplasmosis typically presents with:
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications: Unlike periventricular calcifications seen in CMV, toxoplasmosis affects the entire brain.
    • Hydrocephalus
  • Incorrect Feature:
    • Periventricular calcifications and microcephaly are not typically seen in toxoplasmosis but are characteristic of CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sensorineural hearing loss, salt and pepper retinopathy – Rubella

  • Rubella is known for causing a variety of congenital anomalies, particularly affecting the sensory organs. The most characteristic features include:
  • Sensorineural hearing loss and Salt and pepper retinopathy

       

Option C: Vesicular lesions, microcephaly – Herpes simplex virus

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections in neonates often present with:
  • Vesicular lesions and Microcephaly from severe CNS involvement by HSV.
     

Option D: Chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications – CMV

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is well-known for causing:
    • Periventricular calcifications
    • Chorioretinitis
       

Educational Objective:

  • Rubella: Sensorineural hearing loss and salt-and-pepper retinopathy.
  • Toxoplasmosis: Chorioretinitis and diffuse intracranial calcifications.
  • HSV: Vesicular lesions and microcephaly.
  • CMV: Periventricular calcifications and microcephaly.

choices.text: Performing a cervical Pap smear on a 40-year-old woman during a routine health visit.
Conducting neonatal screening for hypothyroidism immediately after birth.
Screening immigrants for infectious diseases upon entry to a new country.
Checking a 40-year-old man for diabetes through a routine urine sugar test.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta is consulting with a public health team on the implementation of various screening programs aimed at improving community health outcomes. She emphasizes the differences between prescriptive and prospective screening strategies to ensure the team understands when each approach is applicable. Which of the following scenarios exemplifies prospective screening, where the primary aim is disease control for the benefit of the broader community?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Screening immigrants for infectious diseases upon entry to a new country.

 

  • This is correct. Prospective screening, such as screening immigrants for infectious diseases, is conducted primarily for public health benefits, aiming to control disease spread within the community.
  • This form of screening is typically mandated or requested by public health authorities to maintain the health security of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performing a cervical Pap smear on a 40-year-old woman during a routine health visit: Incorrect. A cervical Pap smear is an example of prescriptive screening aimed at the individual's benefit by detecting early signs of cervical cancer.

 

Option B. Conducting neonatal screening for hypothyroidism immediately after birth: Incorrect. Neonatal screening for conditions like hypothyroidism is also prescriptive: focusing on early detection and treatment to benefit the screened newborn.

 

Option D. Checking a 40-year-old man for diabetes through a routine urine sugar test: Incorrect. Urine sugar screening in adults:  is another form of prescriptive screening intended for individual diabetes management rather than broader public health control.

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: A transplant specialist is selecting an immunosuppressive agent for a patient undergoing renal transplantation to prevent organ rejection. The drug of choice targets a specific immune cell receptor. Which of the following is the target of basiliximab used in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD 25

 

  • Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets the alpha subunit of the IL-2 receptor on activated T lymphocytes, known as CD 25.
  • By binding to CD 25, Basiliximab blocks the IL-2 mediated activation of lymphocytes, which is a critical pathway in the immune response leading to organ rejection.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. CD 11a: This is not the correct ans as CD 11a pertains to another molecule involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration, targeted by drugs like efalizumab.

 

Option C. TNF: Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is targeted by drugs such as infliximab and adalimumab, which are used primarily in inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, not in the context of organ transplant immunosuppression.

 

Option D. IL-2: While basiliximab indirectly affects IL-2 signaling by targeting its receptor, it does not directly antagonize IL-2 itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basiliximab is used in the perioperative period of organ transplantation to prevent acute rejection. It works by inhibiting IL-2 signaling, crucial for the proliferation and activity of immune cells that can cause graft rejection.
  • This targeted approach helps in maintaining the viability and function of the transplanted organ while minimizing the overall immunosuppressive burden on the patient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with light-headedness, bloating and diarrhea occurring 15 minutes after meals. He had a Billroth II reconstruction two months ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early dumping

 

  • Occurs shortly after eating, usually within 15 to 30 minutes. It is caused by rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to symptoms like lightheadedness, abdominal fullness, nausea, diarrhea, and tachycardia. This matches the scenario described, where the patient experiences symptoms soon after meals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Late dumping: Happens 1 to 3 hours after eating and is associated with hypoglycemia due to an exaggerated insulin response. Symptoms include weakness, sweating, and palpitations. It does not match the immediate post-meal timeframe mentioned.

 

Option C. Post vagotomy diarrhea: This can occur after gastric surgery like vagotomy and not Billroth 2, due to altered motility but typically does not cause lightheadedness or is related to meal timing.

 

Option D. G-J ulceration: Gastrojejunal ulceration can cause symptoms like pain, but it is less likely to cause immediate postprandial symptoms like lightheadedness or diarrhea unless there is significant bleeding or obstruction, which is not described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Early dumping syndrome is a complication that can occur after gastric surgery, such as a Billroth II reconstruction, and is characterized by symptoms of lightheadedness, bloating, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and diarrhea shortly after eating. These symptoms are due to the rapid transit of food into the small intestine, causing fluid shifts and autonomic reactions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On physical examination, she has eruptive xanthomas on her skin. Laboratory studies reveal elevated plasma concentrations of chylomicrons and triacylglycerols. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type I hyperlipoproteinemia

 

Option C:

 

  • Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency or familial hyperchylomicronemia, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an inability to properly metabolize chylomicrons due to a deficiency in lipoprotein lipase or its cofactor, apolipoprotein C-II.
  • This results in elevated plasma concentrations of chylomicrons and triacylglycerols.
  • Patients often present with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas.
  • The condition is typically diagnosed in childhood but can present later in life with these characteristic symptoms and laboratory findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV hyperlipoproteinemia: This condition, also known as familial hypertriglyceridemia, is characterized by elevated levels of very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) and triacylglycerols but not chylomicrons. It typically presents with mild to moderate hypertriglyceridemia and is not associated with the severe symptoms seen in Type I hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Option B. Type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia: This condition, also known as familial combined hyperlipidemia, involves elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and VLDL. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease but does not typically present with elevated chylomicrons or the specific symptoms of pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas.

 

Option D. Type V hyperlipoproteinemia: This condition is characterized by elevated levels of both chylomicrons and VLDL. While it does present with elevated triacylglycerols, it differs from Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in its broader lipid profile. Patients may have similar symptoms but the primary distinguishing feature is the simultaneous elevation of VLDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency, is characterized by elevated plasma concentrations of chylomicrons and triacylglycerols, leading to recurrent pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmia is being evaluated for medication-induced QT prolongation, a condition that increases the risk of torsades de pointes. Which of the following medications is most likely to cause QT prolongation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinidine

 

  • Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic drug known for its potential to prolong the QT interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • This effect can increase the risk of developing torsades de pointes, a type of life-threatening ventricular tachycardia.
  • The mechanism involves the inhibition of potassium channels, which delays repolarization of the cardiac action potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Mainly affects the central nervous system and is used for bipolar disorder. It does not typically cause QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Adenosine: This is a short-acting drug used to manage supraventricular tachycardias. It primarily acts by slowing conduction through the AV node and does not prolong the QT interval.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Often used as a treatment rather than a cause of prolonged QT intervals, magnesium can help stabilize cardiac membranes and is used therapeutically in cases of torsades de pointes associated with magnesium deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Quinidine is significant for its ability to prolong the QT interval, necessitating careful monitoring when used in patients with or at risk of arrhythmias.
  • Always consider the impact of antiarrhythmic drugs on the ECG and monitor accordingly to prevent arrhythmogenic side effects.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) was prescribed a new anticoagulant. Two days following the initiation of the therapy, he presented with painful skin lesions on his toes, as depicted in the image.

 

 

Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

  • The patient's symptoms are indicative of Warfarin-induced skin necrosis, a rare but serious complication known as "purple toe syndrome.
  • " This condition is characterized by painful, necrotic lesions that typically occur early in the course of warfarin treatment.
  • It is thought to be caused by a rapid depletion of protein C, which creates a transient hypercoagulable state, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Not typically associated with skin necrosis as an initial adverse effect; more commonly linked to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Dabigatran: A direct thrombin inhibitor that does not typically cause skin necrosis.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Part of the new oral anticoagulants (NOACs) that also do not commonly cause skin necrosis as seen with warfarin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis, although rare, should be promptly recognized as a potential early complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It necessitates immediate discontinuation of warfarin and switching to an alternative anticoagulation treatment to prevent further progression of necrotic lesions.
  • This complication underscores the importance of careful monitoring during the initiation of warfarin therapy, especially in patients with known or suspected protein C deficiency.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with endometrial carcinoma. Her mother died of endometrial cancer at age 50, and her 42-year-old brother was recently diagnosed with colon cancer. You suspect a familial cancer syndrome. Which gene in this family is most likely to be mutated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MSH2

 

  • The history of endometrial carcinoma in the patient, endometrial cancer in her mother, and colon cancer in her brother is suggestive of Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, HNPCC).
  • Lynch syndrome is caused by mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes, most commonly MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.
  • MSH2 is one of the key genes associated with this syndrome. Individuals with Lynch syndrome have an increased risk of various cancers, including colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, gastric, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. WT-1: The WT-1 gene is associated with Wilms' tumor, a pediatric kidney cancer. It is not linked to Lynch syndrome or the familial pattern of endometrial and colon cancer seen in this case.

 

Option B. APC: The APC gene is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), another hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome. FAP is characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of colorectal polyps and an increased risk of colorectal cancer. It is not typically associated with endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. p53: The p53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This syndrome increases the risk of various cancers, including breast cancer, sarcomas, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinoma. While p53 mutations can lead to a wide range of cancers, the combination of colon and endometrial cancer is more characteristic of Lynch syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer, HNPCC) is associated with mutations in mismatch repair genes, most commonly MLH1 and MSH2.
  • The presence of endometrial and colon cancer in the same family strongly suggests a mutation in one of these genes, such as MSH2.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male from Bihar comes with complaints of hypopigmented macules over the trunk and face. The nerves and sensations are tested to be normal, and no scaling is visible in the lesions. The patient gives a history of prolonged fever 2 years back for which he was treated. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Miltefosine.

 

  • The presentation of hypopigmented macules without nerve involvement, combined with a history of prolonged fever, is suggestive of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL).
  • This condition occurs as a sequela of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India.
  • PKDL typically presents with macular, papular, or nodular skin lesions that develop months to years after the successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The absence of nerve involvement and scaling helps differentiate it from leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multidrug therapy for leprosy: Leprosy often presents with hypopigmented or erythematous patches with loss of sensation and may include nerve thickening, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: This is an antifungal and also used for treating visceral leishmaniosis but not for PKDL.

 

Option C.  Sodium stibogluconate: This is an antimonial used for treating leishmaniasis but is not the drug of choice for PKDL in regions where miltefosine is available and effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) can occur after treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, particularly in endemic areas.
  • Miltefosine is the drug of choice for treating PKDL.

questions.text: A neonate is born at 38 weeks of gestation with clear amniotic fluid. At 1 minute after birth, the infant is observed to have a heart rate of 90 bpm, slow and irregular breathing, some flexion of the extremities, a grimace response to suction, and a blue body with pink extremities. What is the APGAR score for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • Heart Rate (Pulse): A heart rate of less than 100 bpm scores 1 point.
  • Respiratory Effort: Slow and irregular breathing scores 1 point.
  • Muscle Tone: Some flexion of extremities scores 1 point.
  • Reflex Irritability: A grimace response to suction scores 1 point.
  • Color: A blue body with pink extremities scores 1 point.

 

The total APGAR score is calculated as follows:
1 (Heart Rate) + 1 (Respiratory Effort) + 1 (Muscle Tone) + 1 (Reflex Irritability) + 1 (Color) = 5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The APGAR score is a quick assessment of a newborn's condition at 1 and 5 minutes after birth, evaluating five criteria: heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and color.
  • Each criterion is scored from 0 to 2, with a maximum total score of 10.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a wellness visit. The mother reports that the child's right testicle cannot be felt within the scrotum. On examination, the right testicle is palpable in the inguinal canal and does not descend into the scrotum with gentle pressure. Which of these is not a usual complication of undescended testes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct inguinal hernia

 

  • Direct inguinal hernia is not a typical complication associated with undescended testes.
  • These patients are more likely to have an associated indirect inguinal hernia due to a patent processus vaginalis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular torsion: It is a potential complication of undescended testes due to the abnormal position of the testis, which may predispose it to rotate on the spermatic cord.

 

Option B. Increased risk of trauma: to the testis is observed when the testis is located in the inguinal canal where it can be more susceptible to injury.

 

Option D. Seminoma: is a type of testicular cancer that can occur with greater frequency in men with a history of undescended testes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is not a usual complication of undescended testes, whereas an indirect inguinal hernia, associated with a patent processus vaginalis, is frequently observed in these patients.

choices.text: Increased urea and urate levels
Increased urate and lactate levels
Increased level of alkaline phosphatase

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic man presents with joint pain and swelling, and is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Which of the following biochemical changes is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

  • Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to increased levels of urate and lactate in the blood. Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, leading to increased conversion of pyruvate to lactate and decreased excretion of uric acid.
  • The elevated lactate levels contribute to lactic acidosis, which competes with uric acid for excretion in the kidneys, resulting in hyperuricemia.
  • This biochemical environment promotes the formation of urate crystals, leading to gouty arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This statement is incorrect because chronic alcohol consumption actually increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio due to the metabolism of alcohol in the liver.

 

Option B. Increased urea and urate levels: While urate levels are increased, urea levels are not typically elevated in gout. Urea levels are more closely related to protein metabolism and renal function, and are not directly influenced by the mechanisms causing gout.

 

Option D. Increased level of alkaline phosphatase: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase are usually associated with liver or bone disease, not specifically with gout or alcohol consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic alcohol consumption increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, leading to elevated levels of urate and lactate, which can contribute to the development of gouty arthritis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of persistently high blood glucose levels. He mentions that he had his last meal at 8 pm the previous night and recorded his blood glucose at 7 am the next morning, which was 180 mg/dL. Which metabolic process is the most likely source of his elevated blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic glycogenolysis

 

  • The elevated blood glucose level in this patient the morning after a meal suggests that the glucose is being sourced from internal metabolic processes rather than dietary intake, given the overnight fast.
  • Hepatic glycogenolysis is the process by which glycogen stored in the liver is broken down into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream.
  • This process is particularly active during fasting states to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • Since the patient has not eaten for approximately 11 hours, hepatic glycogenolysis is the primary source of glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis also involves the breakdown of glycogen, but the glucose produced is used locally within muscle cells for energy and not released into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Dietary glucose: Dietary glucose would have been utilized or stored shortly after the meal. Given the time elapsed since the last meal, it is unlikely to be the source of the elevated glucose levels observed the next morning.

 

Option C. Hepatic gluconeogenesis: While hepatic gluconeogenesis (the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources) does contribute to blood glucose, it typically becomes more significant after prolonged fasting when glycogen stores are depleted. In an overnight fast, hepatic glycogenolysis is the predominant source of glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • After an overnight fast, elevated blood glucose levels are primarily maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis, which breaks down stored liver glycogen to release glucose into the bloodstream.

questions.text: A healthcare provider is reviewing infection control procedures at a hospital training session. The discussion includes various diseases and the appropriate isolation precautions required to prevent their transmission in a healthcare setting. The provider emphasizes the importance of correctly categorizing the diseases based on their transmission routes to ensure patient and staff safety. Contact-based isolation is primarily employed for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus)

 

  • Contact-based isolation is used for patients who are infected with or are carriers of organisms that can be transmitted by direct contact with the patient or by contact with items in the patient's environment.
  • MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus) is a prime example of an organism requiring contact precautions due to its ability to spread via direct contact and its resistance to standard antibiotic treatments.
  • This makes stringent hygiene and isolation practices essential to control its spread within healthcare facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: Employed under droplet-based isolation when it is the respiratory type, due to the potential for droplet spread during coughing or sneezing.

 

Option C. Mumps: Also managed under droplet precautions because the virus can be transmitted through respiratory droplets from an infected person.

 

Option D. Asthma: This is not infectious and does not require transmission-based precautions, as it is a chronic lung condition triggered by various environmental factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:
  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

choices.text: C type of lectin receptor

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with severe pain and swelling in his big toe. He has a history of hyperuricemia and is diagnosed with gout. The inflammation in gout is mediated by pattern recognition receptors that detect uric acid crystals. Which of the following receptors is responsible for detecting uric acid crystals in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NOD like receptor

 

  • NOD-like receptors are a family of intracellular pattern recognition receptors that play a critical role in the innate immune response.
  • In gout, NLRs, specifically NLRP3, are involved in detecting uric acid crystals.
  • The activation of NLRP3 leads to the formation of the inflammasome, which subsequently activates caspase-1 and results in the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β.
  • This inflammatory cascade contributes to the intense inflammation and pain experienced in gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GPCR (G Protein-Coupled Receptors): GPCRs are a large family of cell surface receptors that detect molecules outside the cell and activate internal signal transduction pathways. They are not directly involved in the detection of uric acid crystals or the inflammatory response in gout.

 

Option B. C type of lectin receptor: These receptors are primarily involved in recognizing carbohydrate structures on pathogens and are important in the immune response to fungal and bacterial infections. They do not play a significant role in the detection of uric acid crystals.

 

Option D. Toll like receptor (TLR): TLRs are another family of pattern recognition receptors that detect microbial components such as lipopolysaccharides, flagellin, and nucleic acids. Although TLRs play a role in the innate immune response, they are not directly responsible for the detection of uric acid crystals in gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In gout, NOD-like receptors, particularly NLRP3, are responsible for detecting uric acid crystals.
  • Activation of NLRP3 leads to the formation of the inflammation  resulting in the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and the characteristic inflammation and pain of gout.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of high fever and diarrhea containing streaks of blood. The symptoms began abruptly two days ago, and his parents are concerned about dehydration due to frequent bowel movements. The pediatrician decides to send a stool sample to the laboratory to identify the potential bacterial pathogen causing these symptoms. Which enrichment medium should be used to isolate the causative organism from this child's stool sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

  • The clinical presentation of fever, bloody stools, and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery, likely caused by Shigella.
  • Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for the isolation of dysentery-causing bacteria such as Shigella and Salmonella.
  • This medium helps suppress the growth of commensal gut flora while allowing the pathogenic bacteria to survive and proliferate, facilitating their subsequent identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: Primarily used for the culture of anaerobic bacteria, which is not typically implicated in dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: Used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases of cholera, which presents with watery rather than bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: A general enriched medium used for cultivating a wide range of fastidious organisms, but not specific for the selective enrichment of dysentery-causing bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenite F broth is the preferred choice for enriching stool cultures suspected of containing dysentery-causing organisms like Shigella, due to its ability to suppress normal flora while promoting the growth of pathogens.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

• Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.

• Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.

• Alkaline peptone water - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to a regional healthcare center with a history of being bitten while hiking in a forest area. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound has now become red with the appearance of blisters. The casualty medical officer is considering the type of creature responsible based on the clinical presentation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viper

 

  • Vipers are known for their hemotoxic venom, which can cause extensive swelling, pain, bleeding, and blistering at the wound site.
  • The venom affects the blood's ability to clot, leading to continued bleeding, which is consistent with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Cobra: Cobra venom is primarily neurotoxic, not hemotoxic. It affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis, respiratory failure, and other neurologic symptoms, rather than causing bleeding and blistering.


Option C. Wasp bite: Wasp bites can cause pain, swelling, and redness but are unlikely to cause profuse bleeding or blister formation unless there is an allergic reaction, which presents differently.


Option D. Scorpion: Scorpion stings can lead to severe pain, numbness, and sometimes convulsions or cardiac effects, depending on the species, but they do not typically cause bleeding or blistering as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient present with pain, prolonged bleeding, and blistering at a bite site, a viper bite should be considered due to the hemotoxic nature of the venom, which disrupts blood clotting and damages tissues at the site of the bite.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, is at 14 weeks of gestation and comes for her routine antenatal checkup. The obstetrician recommends a uterine artery Doppler ultrasound. What is the primary purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

  • A uterine artery Doppler ultrasound is an important diagnostic tool used in early pregnancy to assess the blood flow in the uterine arteries.
  • Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as high resistance or the presence of notching, can indicate poor placental perfusion.
  • This is strongly associated with the development of early-onset preeclampsia, a condition characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to another organ system, often the kidneys, occurring before 34 weeks of gestation.
  • Identifying abnormal uterine artery blood flow early allows for closer monitoring and management to prevent severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal growth restriction: While uterine artery Doppler can help identify pregnancies at risk for fetal growth restriction, its primary role is in the early detection of placental insufficiency leading to conditions like preeclampsia. Fetal growth restriction is often a consequence of such insufficiency, but the Doppler is not primarily used to diagnose this condition directly.

 

Option C. Placenta accreta: Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta attaches too deeply into the uterine wall. This condition is usually diagnosed through ultrasound and MRI rather than a uterine artery Doppler. The Doppler ultrasound focuses on blood flow and is not the appropriate tool for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Option D. Late-onset preeclampsia: Late-onset preeclampsia occurs after 34 weeks of gestation. While uterine artery Doppler can be suggestive of future preeclampsia risk, its primary utility is in predicting early-onset preeclampsia. Late-onset preeclampsia has different etiological factors and might not show the same early Doppler abnormalities as early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary purpose of a uterine artery Doppler ultrasound at 14 weeks of gestation is to detect early-onset preeclampsia by assessing placental blood flow and identifying high resistance or notching in the uterine arteries.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoes a successful vaginal delivery. Following the delivery, the obstetrician notices that the episiotomy, intended to facilitate the delivery, has extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External anal sphincter

 

  • An episiotomy is a surgical incision made in the perineum—the area between the vaginal opening and the anus—to enlarge the vaginal opening for childbirth.
  • Sometimes, despite careful incision, the episiotomy can extend inadvertently, causing further injury to surrounding structures.
  • In this case, the extension of the episiotomy beyond the perineal body likely affects the external anal sphincter, as it lies posterior to the perineal body.
  • Damage to the external anal sphincter can result in significant complications, including fecal incontinence.
  • Therefore, the external anal sphincter is the structure most at risk of injury when the episiotomy extends posteriorly beyond the perineal body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischiocavernosus: The ischiocavernosus muscle is located in the perineal region but is more lateral, associated with the clitoral crura in females. It is less likely to be injured in a posterior extension of an episiotomy, as it is not in the direct line of extension.

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus: The bulbospongiosus muscle surrounds the vaginal orifice and the vestibule, contributing to the constriction of the vaginal opening. While it is part of the perineal muscles, it lies anterior to the perineal body and is therefore less likely to be affected by a posterior extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C. Urethral sphincter: The urethral sphincter encircles the urethra and is located anteriorly in the perineum. An injury to the urethral sphincter from an episiotomy would be unusual unless the episiotomy extends anteriorly, which is not the case in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An episiotomy that extends beyond the perineal body posteriorly is most likely to injure the external anal sphincter, posing risks for fecal incontinence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in active labor. The fetus is in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the head. Which of the following diameters is engaged in this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

  • In the vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, the chin is tucked towards the chest, and the smallest diameter of the head presents to the birth canal.
  • The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter, measuring approximately 9.5 cm, is the diameter engaged in this presentation.
  • This allows for the most favorable passage through the maternal pelvis, facilitating a smoother delivery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suboccipito-frontal diameter: The suboccipito-frontal diameter measures approximately 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is moderately flexed, not completely flexed. This diameter is larger than the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter and presents when the fetal head is slightly extended.

 

Option B. Occipito-frontal diameter: The occipito-frontal diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is present when the fetal head is in a military or neutral position. This diameter is larger than both the suboccipito-bregmatic and suboccipito-frontal diameters and is not engaged in the vertex presentation with complete flexion.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position: Occipito-posterior position refers to the orientation of the fetal head in the maternal pelvis, with the back of the fetal head towards the maternal sacrum. It is a positional term and not a description of the presenting diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter, measuring approximately 9.5 cm, is the engaged diameter, facilitating the most favorable passage through the birth canal.

questions.text: A clinician administers an intravenous drug to a patient at 8 AM with an initial plasma concentration of 200 mg/L. The drug has a half-life of 4 hours and follows first-order kinetics. What will be the plasma concentration of the drug at 8 PM on the same day?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25 mg/L

 

Explanation

 

Given:

 

  • Initial concentration (Câ‚€): 200 mg/L
  • Half-life (t½): 4 hours
  • Duration from 8 AM to 8 PM: 12 hours

 

To calculate the plasma concentration at 8 PM after 12 hours, we use the property of half-lives in first-order kinetics, where the drug concentration decreases by half with each half-life. Here's the calculation:

 

  • After 1 half-life (4 hours, 12 PM): 200 /2=100 mg/L
  • After 2 half-lives (8 hours, 4 PM): 100 /2=50 mg/L
  • After 3 half-lives (12 hours, 8 PM): 50/2=25 mg/L

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug follows first-order kinetics where the rate of drug elimination is proportional to the drug concentration in the plasma; here the drug concentration decreases by half with each half-life.

questions.text: An infectious disease specialist is evaluating the mechanism of action of various antiviral drugs (as shown below). Based on the known mechanisms of antiviral drugs, which part of the diagram is most likely to represent the action of baloxavir marboxil?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

  • Baloxavir marboxil functions by inhibiting cap-dependent endonuclease, an enzyme critical for the initiation of viral mRNA synthesis.
  • This mechanism is pivotal for the replication of influenza viruses, as it hampers the virus's ability to hijack the host's cellular machinery to begin synthesis of its own proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A: might represent entry inhibitors or fusion inhibitors, affecting the virus’s ability to enter the host cell.

 

Option B. B: could be indicative of processes interfering with the virus's ability to uncoat or replicate its genome inside the host cell.

 

Option D. D: likely involves the release phase of the virus lifecycle, possibly related to neuraminidase inhibitors or other mechanisms that prevent virus budding and release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Baloxavir marboxil is a novel antiviral drug that targets the cap-dependent endonuclease activity of influenza viruses, offering a unique approach to inhibiting viral replication by preventing the proper processing of viral mRNA necessary for protein synthesis.
  • This mechanism is distinct from those of other common antivirals, making it a valuable tool in the treatment of influenza.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient complains of a painless mass above his left knee, which is gradually growing in size. X-ray reveals the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondromas are the most common benign bone tumors.
  • They typically present as painless, slow-growing masses near the ends of long bones, such as the knee, and are often detected in adolescents or young adults.
  • They consist of bony projections covered by cartilage and usually arise from the growth plate (epiphyseal cartilage) during bone growth.
  • Given the patient's age, the location of the mass above the knee, and the slow-growing nature of the lesion, osteochondroma is a likely diagnosis.
  • X-rays typically show a bony outgrowth with a distinct bony stalk (pedicle) arising from the surface of the affected bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in adolescents and young adults. It typically presents as a painful mass, often with associated swelling and decreased range of motion. Osteosarcomas usually arise in the metaphyseal region of long bones, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. While osteosarcoma is an important consideration in a young patient with a bone mass, the fact that the mass is painless and slowly growing makes osteochondroma a more likely diagnosis. However, further evaluation with imaging studies and possibly a biopsy may be warranted to rule out osteosarcoma definitively.

 

Option C. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells within the bone marrow, leading to lytic bone lesions and the production of monoclonal proteins. It typically presents with symptoms such as bone pain, anemia, kidney dysfunction, and hypercalcemia. Multiple myeloma is uncommon in adolescents and is more commonly seen in older adults. While it can present with lytic bone lesions, the clinical presentation and age of the patient make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a highly aggressive malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and young adults. It often presents with bone pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. Ewing's sarcoma commonly arises in the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, such as the femur or tibia. While Ewing's sarcoma is a consideration in a young patient with a bone mass, the painless nature of the mass and the gradual growth make osteochondroma a more likely diagnosis. However, further evaluation with imaging studies and possibly a biopsy may be needed to differentiate between the two.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given case and x-ray image of the 16-year-old patient describes the presence of osteochondroma.
  • Since the mass is painless, it confirms it to be an osteochondroma.

questions.text: A neurologist is reviewing a case of a patient who has developed unusual hair growth on the face and neck after starting a new medication for epilepsy. Based on the pattern of hair growth seen in the patient, which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

  • Phenytoin is well-documented for causing hypertrichosis, which is an increase in hair growth, particularly on the face and neck, as seen in the image provided.
  • This side effect is one of the more cosmetic, yet distressing effects associated with this medication, which is used primarily in the management of epilepsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: While valproate can cause weight gain and hair loss, it is not typically associated with increased facial hair growth.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Known for its neurological side effects, such as mood changes and irritability, levetiracetam does not commonly cause changes in hair growth.

 

Option D. Lamotrigine: This drug can cause skin rash and other serious skin reactions but does not typically affect hair growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirsutism is caused by:

 

  • Phenytoin
  • Cyclosporine
  • Minoxidol

choices.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of glaucoma presents to the clinic for follow-up. The ophthalmologist decides to adjust the patient's medication to better control intraocular pressure. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog used to lower intraocular pressure. It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug activated during its passage through the cornea, where it stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • These enzymes increase uveoscleral outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not primarily increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing trabecular meshwork outflow. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors decrease intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production, not by increasing uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of chronic nausea, vomiting, and intermittent abdominal pain. She is diagnosed with a disorder affecting gastrointestinal motility. During her hospital stay, she undergoes several tests to determine the underlying cause of her symptoms. The results point towards an abnormality in the cells responsible for initiating the Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER) in the gastrointestinal tract. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for the initiation of the BER?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cajal’s Cells

 

  • The Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER) is crucial for coordinating the contractions of the smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract. These rhythmic electrical impulses are generated by specific pacemaker cells.
  • Cajal’s cells are specialized pacemaker cells located in the smooth muscle layers of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • They generate and propagate the slow waves that form the BER, which are essential for the coordination of smooth muscle contractions and effective gastrointestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Botzinger Complex: This is a cluster of neurons in the medulla oblongata involved in respiratory rhythm generation, not in the motility of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Cells of Ito: These hepatic stellate cells are found in the liver and are involved in liver function and fibrosis, but they do not play a role in the BER of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Brunner’s Cells: These are glands located in the duodenum that secrete an alkaline mucus to protect the duodenal lining, but they are not involved in initiating the BER.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Interstitial Cells of Cajal (Cajal’s Cells) are responsible for the initiation and propagation of the Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER) in the gastrointestinal tract, coordinating the smooth muscle contractions necessary for proper gastrointestinal motility.

choices.text: Accumulation of lipid in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes
Accumulation of glycogen in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes
Accumulation of iron in the hepatic parenchyma
Accumulation of iron in the Kupffer cells

questions.text: A 41-year-old obese, non-alcoholic woman presents with mild right-sided abdominal pain. Physical examination is normal. Blood tests reveal mildly elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT) with normal total and direct bilirubin levels. An ultrasound shows a few hyperechoic regions in the liver. If a liver biopsy is performed, which finding is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of lipid in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes

 

  • The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), a condition commonly associated with obesity.
  • NAFLD is characterized by the accumulation of fat within the liver cells (hepatocytes).
  • The mild elevation in liver enzymes and the presence of hyperechoic regions on ultrasonography are indicative of fatty infiltration in the liver.
  • If a liver biopsy were performed, it would most likely show the presence of lipid droplets within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of glycogen in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes: While glycogen storage diseases can lead to the accumulation of glycogen in hepatocytes, this condition is less likely given the patient’s obesity and typical presentation suggestive of fatty liver disease.

 

Option C. Accumulation of iron in the hepatic parenchyma: This finding is characteristic of hemochromatosis, a condition involving excessive iron deposition in the liver and other tissues. Hemochromatosis typically presents with a different clinical picture, including signs of iron overload rather than obesity and fatty liver.

 

Option D. Accumulation of iron in the Kupffer cells: This occurs in conditions such as hemosiderosis, which involves iron storage in macrophages (Kupffer cells) and can be secondary to frequent blood transfusions or certain anemia’s. The patient’s presentation is more consistent with NAFLD rather than iron overload conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is characterized by the accumulation of lipid in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes, often associated with obesity and mild elevations in liver enzymes.
  • This condition can be identified through imaging and confirmed by liver biopsy showing lipid infiltration in hepatocytes.

choices.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus venosus
Flap closure of foramen ovale

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks of gestation has been taking indomethacin (25 mg TDS) for the management of polyhydramnios. If she goes into labor now, what fetal abnormality is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

  • Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is used to manage polyhydramnios by reducing fetal urine production.
  • However, one of the potential adverse effects of indomethacin on the fetus is the premature closure or constriction of the ductus arteriosus.
  • The ductus arteriosus is a vital fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs.
  • Its premature closure can result in significant fetal cardiovascular complications, including right ventricular hypertrophy, pulmonary hypertension, and heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patent ductus arteriosus: Indomethacin is actually used to treat patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants because it promotes the closure of the ductus arteriosus. Therefore, indomethacin is not associated with causing PDA.

 

Option C. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: Indomethacin does not affect the ductus venosus, which shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, bypassing the liver. Premature closure of the ductus venosus is not a known complication of indomethacin use.

 

Option D. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale is an opening between the right and left atria that normally closes after birth. Indomethacin does not typically affect the foramen ovale during fetal life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indomethacin use in pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, can lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus, which can cause significant cardiovascular complications such as right ventricular hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension.

choices.text: Administer both human tetanus immunoglobulin and restart the tetanus vaccine series
Administer human tetanus immunoglobulin only
Administer a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid
Restart the full tetanus toxoid vaccination series

questions.text: A 24-year-old male visits the clinic with a clean, non-bleeding laceration on his arm. He reports that his last tetanus vaccine was administered 7-8 years ago, following a complete vaccination schedule. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s wound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid

 

  • For a patient who has a clean, non-bleeding wound and whose last tetanus vaccine was administered 7-8 years ago following a complete vaccination schedule, the most appropriate management is to administer a single booster dose of tetanus toxoid.
  • This recommendation is based on guidelines that suggest a tetanus booster should be given if the last dose was administered more than 5 years ago for a clean, minor wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administering both human tetanus immunoglobulin and restarting the tetanus vaccine series: This is not indicated for patients with clean wounds who have received a full vaccination series within the past 10 years. This approach is more suited for patients with either unknown vaccination status or severe, contaminated wounds.

 

Option B. Administering human tetanus immunoglobulin only: This is not necessary for patients with a complete vaccination history and a clean wound, as the risk of tetanus infection is low.

 

Option D. Restarting the full tetanus toxoid vaccination series: This is not required for patients who have received their full course within the last 10 years. A booster is sufficient to extend protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and an inability to pass urine or stools. These symptoms are indicative of poisoning, and the medical officer needs to identify the likely poison and its appropriate antidote based on the clinical presentation. Which of the following combinations of poison and antidote is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

  • Datura poisoning typically presents with symptoms characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity, such as irritability, restlessness, dry and hot skin, and urinary retention.
  • The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic poisoning is Physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that can cross the blood-brain barrier and counteract the effects of anticholinergic agents like Datura by increasing the level of acetylcholine.

 

Note - Trumpet shape flower – Datura

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect because Pralidoxime is used to treat organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Incorrect as Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside itself and not an antidote. Yellow oleander toxicity mimics that of digoxin and requires different management strategies, such as activated charcoal and possibly Digoxin-specific antibody fragments, not Digoxin itself.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect because Physostigmine is used for anticholinergic poisoning, not for poisoning by cardiac glycosides like those found in yellow oleander.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for evaluation of a swelling on the right side of the head, present since birth. The swelling has not increased in size and is firm to the touch. An X-ray of the skull is obtained and shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cephalhematoma

 

  • Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that occurs due to birth trauma.
