  • It is characterized by a collection of blood between the periosteum and the skull bone, usually appearing as a firm swelling that is confined to one bone and does not cross suture lines.
  • This is because the periosteum is tightly bound to the edges of the bones, limiting the spread of blood.
  • The X-ray will show a localized swelling on the skull, which matches the description and imaging in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subgaleal Hematoma: This condition involves bleeding between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull. It can spread widely and cross suture lines, often leading to a diffuse swelling of the scalp. This is more serious due to potential for significant blood loss, which is not consistent with the localized, firm swelling described and seen in the X-ray.

 

 

Option B. Caput Succedaneum: This is a diffuse, edematous swelling of the scalp tissue caused by pressure during birth. It crosses suture lines and typically resolves within a few days postpartum. The swelling in caput succedaneum is soft and not confined to one bone, unlike the case described.

 

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is a congenital condition where brain tissue herniates through a defect in the skull. It would present as a bony defect with protruding brain tissue on imaging, which is not seen in this X-ray.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cephalhematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage typically caused by birth trauma, presenting as a firm, localized swelling that does not cross suture lines and is confined to a single bone.

choices.text: Dorsalis Pedis Artery lies beneath the Deep Fascia along the Lateral Border of Dorsum of Foot
Close to its Termination it is crossed by the Tendon of Extensor Hallucis Longus
It gives rise to the First Dorsal Metatarsal Artery before Termination
It lies Medial to Tendon of Extensor Hallucis Longus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, known hypertensive, diabetic, and a smoker for the past 30 years, visited the surgery OPD with an ulcer on the dorsum of the foot close to the great toe. The unit chief asked one of the students to look for dorsalis pedis artery pulsation in this patient. Which of the following statements pertaining to this case is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It gives rise to the First Dorsal Metatarsal Artery before Termination

 

  • The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot.
  • It runs along the dorsum of the foot towards the space between the first and second toes. Before its termination, it gives off the first dorsal metatarsal artery, which supplies the adjacent sides of the first and second toes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsalis Pedis Artery lies beneath the Deep Fascia along the Lateral Border of Dorsum of Foot: This statement is incorrect. The dorsalis pedis artery lies superficial to the deep fascia and runs along the medial aspect of the dorsum of the foot.

 

Option B. Close to its Termination it is crossed by the Tendon of Extensor Hallucis Longus: This statement is incorrect. The dorsalis pedis artery runs alongside the tendon of the extensor hallucis longus and is not crossed by it.

 

Option D. It lies Medial to Tendon of Extensor Hallucis Longus: This statement is incorrect. The dorsalis pedis artery actually lies lateral to the tendon of the extensor hallucis longus on the dorsum of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dorsalis pedis artery gives rise to the first dorsal metatarsal artery before its termination, which is an important landmark in the anatomical identification of this artery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with weakness and palpitations. An ECG is performed and is shown below. Identify the electrolyte abnormality associated with the ECG findings.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

 

  • Hyperkalemia causes characteristic ECG changes which include tall, peaked T waves, a prolonged PR interval, widening of the QRS complex, and in severe cases, a sine wave pattern due to the merging of the QRS and T waves.
  • The ECG provided shows these specific findings, which are indicative of elevated potassium levels in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia typically presents with flattened or inverted T waves, the presence of U waves, ST depression, and a prolonged QT interval. These features are not observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Hypercalcemia: Hypercalcemia is characterized by a shortened QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration. The ECG changes in hypercalcemia do not match the findings in the provided ECG.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia leads to a prolonged QT interval due to lengthening of the ST segment. These changes are not consistent with the ECG shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperkalemia is an important electrolyte disturbance to recognize on an ECG. Key features include tall, peaked T waves, prolonged PR intervals, widening of the QRS complex, and in severe cases, a sine wave pattern.
  • Prompt recognition and treatment are critical to prevent potentially fatal arrhythmias.

choices.text: Search, rescue, and first aid

questions.text: In a disaster setting, a medical team utilizes a method to rapidly evaluate injured individuals to prioritize those who need urgent care based on their potential for survival and the severity of their injuries. This process is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Triage

 

  • This is the correct answer. Triage is the systematic process used during disasters to assess and categorize injured individuals based on the urgency of their medical needs and the likelihood of survival with immediate intervention.
  • This method helps in optimizing resource allocation when resources are limited, ensuring that those who are most likely to benefit from immediate care receive it first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Search, rescue, and first aid: This involves the initial steps in a disaster response, including locating, rescuing, and providing basic first aid to victims. While essential, it does not involve the systematic prioritization of care based on the likelihood of survival.

 

Option C. Tagging: This is a component of triage where each patient is given a tag that indicates their triage status, which helps in further management and tracking. Tagging itself is not the process of prioritizing care based on medical need.

 

Option D. Disaster mitigation: Refers to measures designed to reduce or prevent the risk of disasters and to mitigate their impacts on communities. It is not related to the immediate medical assessment of injured individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Triage system: Most commonly uses FOUR color code system:
    • Red (Highest Priority): Immediate resuscitation or limb/lifesaving surgery in next 6 hours
    • Yellow (High Priority): Possible resuscitation or limb/lifesaving surgery in next 24 hours
    • Green (Low Priority): Minor illness/ambulatory patients
    • Black (Least Priority): Dead and moribund patients

choices.text: Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 2
Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 3
Oral hairy leukoplakia & WHO stage 3
Oral hairy leukoplakia & WHO stage 2

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual with CD 4 count < 300 / microlitre presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO staging?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral hairy leukoplakia & WHO stage 3

 

  • This is correct. Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, corrugated plaques on the lateral aspects of the tongue and is associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection in HIV-positive individuals.
  • It is classified under WHO stage 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 2: This is incorrect. Oral candidiasis is characterized by white, creamy plaques that can be scraped off, and it is classified under WHO stage 2 in HIV.

 

Option B. Oral candidiasis & WHO stage 3: This is incorrect. While oral candidiasis can progress to WHO stage 3 if persistent and untreated, the image shows features more consistent with oral hairy leukoplakia.

 

Option D. Oral hairy leukoplakia & WHO stage 2: This is incorrect. Oral hairy leukoplakia is not classified under WHO stage 2. It is a stage 3 condition due to its association with significant immunosuppression in HIV patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral hairy leukoplakia is a white, corrugated lesion commonly seen on the lateral tongue in HIV-positive patients and is classified as a WHO stage 3 condition.
  • It is an indicator of significant immunosuppression and often requires prompt management.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, Obesity and end stage renal disease. Her laboratory results show the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

 

 

  • Calcium: Increased
  • PTH: Increased
  • Phosphate: Increased
  • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP): Increased
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

 

  • Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs in the context of long-standing secondary hyperparathyroidism, typically in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
  • In these patients, prolonged stimulation of the parathyroid glands due to chronic hypocalcemia (secondary hyperparathyroidism) eventually leads to autonomous parathyroid hyperplasia and hyperfunction, resulting in tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
  • The laboratory findings in tertiary hyperparathyroidism include:
  1. Increased Calcium: The parathyroid glands secrete excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) autonomously, leading to hypercalcemia.
  2. Increased PTH: The parathyroid glands are hyperplastic and continue to secrete high levels of PTH despite elevated calcium levels.
  3. Increased Phosphate: In CKD and ESRD, phosphate excretion is impaired, leading to hyperphosphatemia.
  4. Increased Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP): Elevated ALP levels are indicative of increased bone turnover and activity, often seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Given the patient's history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), the presence of increased calcium, increased PTH, increased phosphate, and increased ALP is consistent with tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary hyperparathyroidism: Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by autonomous overproduction of PTH due to a parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia. This condition typically presents with increased calcium and PTH but usually has normal or decreased phosphate levels, not increased phosphate as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Secondary hyperparathyroidism: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs due to chronic hypocalcemia, often secondary to CKD. It is characterized by increased PTH and phosphate with normal or low calcium levels. This patient's hypercalcemia is not consistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency typically leads to low calcium and phosphate levels, with secondary increases in PTH. This patient's laboratory findings of increased calcium, phosphate, and PTH are not consistent with vitamin D deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tertiary hyperparathyroidism develops in patients with chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease who have had prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • It is characterized by autonomous overproduction of PTH, resulting in hypercalcemia, increased phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of painful urination and a yellowish discharge from the urethra. He admits to having unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. A Gram stain of the urethral discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

  • The presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci in the urethral discharge strongly suggests an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, commonly known as gonorrhea.
  • Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is the recommended first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonococcal infections due to its efficacy in eradicating the pathogen.
  • It is typically administered as a single intramuscular dose of 250 mg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin: Not effective against gonorrhea; primarily used for chlamydial infections and other bacterial infections.

 

Option B. Azithromycin: Often used as a co-treatment for chlamydial infections in the setting of gonorrhea but not as effective as monotherapy for gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G: Historically used for treating gonorrhea, but widespread resistance has made it an ineffective option in most geographical areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

questions.text: Match the descriptions in Column A with the appropriate type of rhinitis in Column B.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a-4, b-1, c-3, d-2

 

A) Describes rhinitis medicamentosa, characterized by the prolonged use of nasal decongestants (a-4).

 

B) Describes allergic rhinitis, an IgE-mediated response to allergens (b-1).

 

C) Describes atrophic rhinitis, characterized by pale mucosa, crusting, and anosmia (c-3).

 

D) Describes vasomotor rhinitis, which results from autonomic imbalance and parasympathetic overactivity (d-2).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the different types of rhinitis and their distinguishing clinical features to accurately diagnose and manage conditions such as rhinitis medicamentosa, allergic rhinitis, atrophic rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient presents with a history of chronic constipation for which she has used various over-the-counter laxatives. She undergoes a colonoscopy, and the images show distinctive mucosal changes. Based on the colonoscopy images shown, which laxative is most likely to have caused the observed mucosal changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Senna

 

  • The colonoscopy images provided display characteristics of melanosis coli, a condition often associated with the chronic use of stimulant laxatives such as senna. Melanosis coli is characterized by a dark pigmentation of the colon mucosa, which is evident in some of the images. This condition is harmless and usually reversible, but it distinctly points to the use of certain types of laxatives.
  • This is a stimulant laxative that increases the motility of the colon by irritating the mucosa and enhancing intestinal peristalsis. Chronic use of senna is well-known to cause melanosis coli, which is what the images suggest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bran: This is a bulk-forming laxative and generally does not cause mucosal changes. It aids in constipation by increasing fecal mass and stimulating bowel movements naturally.

 

Option B. Psyllium: Also a bulk-forming laxative, psyllium increases stool bulk and facilitates passage without causing significant mucosal changes.

 

Option D. Methylcellulose: Another bulk-forming agent, methylcellulose works similarly to psyllium and bran and does not typically lead to changes in colon mucosa appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanosis coli is a benign condition associated with the prolonged use of stimulant laxatives like senna, Cascara Sagrada and Bisacodyl.
  • It presents with characteristic dark pigmentation of the colon mucosa and is reversible upon cessation of the causative agent.
  • Also they should not be used for more than 10 days due to the risk of developing atonic colon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing. He has a history of intermittent abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals a right-sided heart murmur. Laboratory tests are ordered, and results show elevated levels of urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoid syndrome

 

  • Carcinoid syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome caused by the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances from carcinoid tumors, which are most commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The hallmark of carcinoid syndrome includes symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing.
  • These symptoms result from the secretion of serotonin and other substances by the tumor.
  • Serotonin is metabolized into 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is then excreted in the urine.
  • Therefore, elevated urinary 5-HIAA is a key diagnostic marker for carcinoid syndrome.
  • The presence of a right-sided heart murmur is also indicative of carcinoid heart disease, which occurs due to the fibrotic effects of serotonin on the heart valves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albinism: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a deficiency in melanin production, leading to hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. It does not involve abnormalities in serotonin metabolism or elevated urinary 5-HIAA levels.

 

Option B. Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inherited metabolic disorder resulting from a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This enzyme is crucial for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Patients with PKU accumulate phenylalanine, leading to intellectual disability if untreated. PKU is diagnosed by elevated phenylalanine levels in the blood and does not cause elevated urinary 5-HIAA.

 

Option D. Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid. This acid is deposited in connective tissues, causing ochronosis and urine that darkens upon standing. Elevated urinary 5-HIAA is not a feature of alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is a key diagnostic marker for carcinoid syndrome, which presents with symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing due to excessive serotonin production.

questions.text:
Identify the components of Revised Trauma Score?

 

  1. Pulse rate
  2. Respiratory rate
  3. Patient age
  4. Glasgow coma scale
  5. Systolic BP
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b, d, e

 

  • The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiological scoring system, with the intent to provide an assessment of the severity of a trauma patient's condition.

 

b. Respiratory rate d. Glasgow Coma Scale e. Systolic BP

 

These three parameters are used to calculate the RTS, which can help to predict the patient's chances of survival. Each component is given a score, and the sum of these scores is used to determine the overall RTS.

 

Other trauma scoring systems include:

 

  1. Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS): Codes injuries on a scale from 1 (minimally severe) to 6 (presumably fatal).
  2. Injury Severity Score (ISS): Ranges from 3-75, and is the summation of the squares of the highest AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions.
  3. Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS): Includes factors like the energy causing injury, limb ischemia, shock, and patient age.
  4. TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score): Combines the ISS, RTS, the mechanism of injury, and the patient's age to estimate survival.

 

This means that the correct components of the Revised Trauma Score are the respiratory rate, Glasgow Coma Scale, and systolic blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) as a tool for assessing the severity of trauma, which includes the patient's respiratory rate, Glasgow Coma Scale score, and systolic blood pressure.
  • Lower RTS scores correlate with higher injury severity and potentially lower chances of survival.

choices.text: Increase in thickness of the mucosa
Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. She is suspected of having celiac disease, and a duodenal biopsy is performed. The histological features of celiac disease include all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in thickness of the mucosa

 

  • In celiac disease, the mucosa does not increase in thickness. In fact, the mucosa often appears thinner due to villous atrophy, which is a hallmark of the disease.
  • The villi in the small intestine are blunted or completely flattened, reducing the overall surface area and resulting in a thinner mucosal layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crypt hyperplasia: This is a common histological feature of celiac disease. The crypts of Lieberkühn become elongated and hyperplastic as a response to the chronic inflammatory process.

 

Option C. Increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes: An increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) is one of the characteristic histological findings in celiac disease. These lymphocytes are part of the immune response to gluten.

 

Option D. Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria: The lamina propria in patients with celiac disease often shows an increase in inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. This inflammation contributes to the damage and atrophy of the villi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Celiac disease is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes, and increased inflammatory cells in the lamina propria, but not by an increase in the thickness of the mucosa.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man undergoes parotid gland surgery for the removal of a benign tumor. The surgeon needs to identify the facial nerve trunk to avoid damaging it during the procedure. Which of the following anatomical landmark or technique is NOT used for the identification of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

  • The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is located in the neck and is not used as a landmark for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgery.
  • The omohyoid muscle is more relevant in neck dissection procedures and is not anatomically close to the facial nerve trunk, which lies in the parotid region.

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde Dissection from Distal Branch: This technique involves identifying the distal branches of the facial nerve and tracing them back to the main trunk. It is a common technique used in parotid surgeries to ensure the preservation of the facial nerve.

 

Option B. Tragal Pointer: The tragal pointer is an important landmark used in parotid surgery. It is a cartilaginous projection anterior to the tragus of the ear and points towards the location of the facial nerve trunk.

 

Option D. Posterior Belly of Digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another anatomical landmark used in the identification of the facial nerve trunk. The facial nerve trunk is located just superior to this muscle in the parotid region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as a landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgery, while the tragal pointer, retrograde dissection from distal branches, and the posterior belly of the digastric muscle are key landmarks and techniques utilized in this context.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lower backache undergoes a health screening. His digital rectal examination is notable for a hard, nodular prostate. Which of these levels of Serum PSA is suggestive of advanced Ca Prostate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 35 to 100 ng/ml

 

  • The finding of a PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and >35 ng/mL is almost diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer, in the absence of active urinary tract infection. A decrease in PSA to the normal range following hormonal ablation is a good prognostic sign.
  • Serum PSA level is not significantly altered by DRE:
  • Can be significantly altered by a UTI
  • After an infective episode, takes 6 weeks to return to baseline values
  • Is artificially lowered, up to two times, in men taking 5α-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PSA level greater than 35 ng/mL is highly suggestive of advanced prostate cancer in the absence of an active urinary tract infection or other causes of PSA elevation.
  • Further investigation, including biopsy, is usually warranted to confirm the diagnosis and stage the disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a history of chronic dyspepsia and postprandial fullness. The radiograph shown below was taken as part of his diagnostic workup. Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Barium meal

 

  • The radiograph shows a barium study where the stomach and duodenum are outlined with barium contrast.
  • A barium meal is an imaging procedure where the patient ingests a barium sulfate solution, which coats the lining of the upper gastrointestinal tract, including the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.
  • This allows for detailed radiographic examination of these structures.
  • The image clearly shows the stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum), characteristic of a barium meal study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium Swallow: This procedure specifically examines the esophagus. The radiograph in question shows the stomach and duodenum, indicating that the investigation goes beyond the esophagus.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This is a continuation of the barium meal study that follows the passage of barium through the entire small intestine. The radiograph provided does not show the complete small intestine, but rather focuses on the stomach and duodenum, typical of a barium meal study.

 

Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure involves the introduction of barium sulfate into the colon via the rectum to visualize the large intestine. The radiograph does not show the large intestine, thus ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A barium meal study involves ingesting barium sulfate to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, including the stomach and duodenum, which is demonstrated in the radiograph provided.

questions.text: A young woman on oral contraceptives presents with right upper quadrant pain. A CT scan of the abdomen is performed, and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic adenoma

 

  • The image given is of hepatic adenoma which is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills.
  • Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors, predisposed in patients on OCPs and glycogen storage disorders with a predilection for hemorrhage.
  • They are enhancing lesions on the arterial phase.
  • Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors that are commonly associated with the use of oral contraceptives in young women.
  • These tumors are typically well-circumscribed and can vary in size.
  • They often present with right upper quadrant pain or may be discovered incidentally during imaging for other reasons.
  • The CT scan findings in this patient, combined with her history of oral contraceptive use, strongly suggest a hepatic adenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular Carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a primary malignant tumor of the liver. It is often associated with underlying liver disease such as cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis B and C infections. While HCC can present with a liver mass, it is less likely in a young woman without underlying liver disease or risk factors, and the history of oral contraceptive use points more towards a benign lesion like a hepatic adenoma.

 

Option B. Metastatic Infiltrates: Metastatic liver disease refers to the spread of cancer to the liver from other primary sites. It is more common in patients with a known history of malignancy. The patient's age, absence of known primary cancer, and the association with oral contraceptive use make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option D. Haemangiomas: Hemangiomas are the most common benign liver tumors. They are typically asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. Hemangiomas have characteristic imaging features such as peripheral nodular enhancement with centripetal filling on delayed imaging, which helps differentiate them from hepatic adenomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors frequently associated with oral contraceptive use in young women, presenting as well-circumscribed lesions on imaging studies.

choices.text: Citrus fruit consumption increases the risk of skin cancer.
Citrus fruit consumption decreases the risk of skin cancer.
The findings are insufficient to prove a causal link between citrus fruit consumption and skin cancer reduction.
A risk ratio close to 1 implies that citrus fruit consumption has no effect on skin cancer risk.

questions.text: A population-based study evaluates the effect of consuming citrus fruits on the occurrence of skin cancer. The study results show a risk ratio of 0.84 for skin cancer in individuals who regularly consume citrus fruits compared to those who do not. What conclusion can be drawn from this risk ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Citrus fruit consumption decreases the risk of skin cancer.

 

  • This is correct as the risk ratio of 0.84 indicates that individuals who regularly consume citrus fruits have a reduced incidence of skin cancer compared to those who do not consume them.
  • This suggests a protective association between citrus fruit intake and the risk of developing skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrus fruit consumption increases the risk of skin cancer:  Incorrect. A risk ratio below 1 suggests a decrease, not an increase, in risk associated with the exposure.

 

Option C. The findings are insufficient to prove a causal link between citrus fruit consumption and skin cancer reduction: Incorrect. Although causality cannot be definitively established from a single observational study, the risk ratio itself is indicative of a significant association.

 

Option D. A risk ratio close to 1 implies that citrus fruit consumption has no effect on skin cancer risk: Incorrect. While 0.84 is indeed close to 1, it still represents a statistically significant decrease in risk, indicating a protective effect rather than no effect.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department with a painful lesion on his forearm that developed several days after cleaning out an old barn. The lesion started as a small bump and progressed to look like as shown in the image. The patient reports a mild fever and feeling unwell. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of the lesion observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

  • The patient's lesion, characterized by a black eschar with a prominent inflammatory ring, is indicative of cutaneous anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis.
  • This presentation is typically referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • Bacillus anthracis is known to be contracted through contact with contaminated animal products, which fits the patient's history of exposure in a barn.
  • Cutaneous anthrax is the most common form of the disease and, while it can be severe, it is often localized if treated promptly.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Image A and B: Gram-stain of B. anthracis:

 

A. Direct smear shows gram-positive, large rectangular bacilli and pus cells;

B. Culture smear-shows gram-positive bacilli with non-bulging spores (bamboo stick appearance)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: While capable of causing skin infections, typically presents with different clinical features, such as ecthyma gangrenosum in immunocompromised individuals, not the black eschar typical of anthrax.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, characterized by swollen and painful lymph nodes, not primarily skin lesions with black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can manifest in ulceroglandular form with skin ulcers and swollen glands, but lacks the black eschar seen in anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bacillus anthracis should be suspected in patients presenting with black eschar lesions, especially those with a history of exposure to potentially contaminated animal products.
  • Early identification and treatment are critical to prevent systemic complications of anthrax.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic urticaria being treated with steroids presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of his respiratory symptoms. He reports a persistent nocturnal cough that has been troubling him for several weeks. Laboratory tests reveal a significant elevation in eosinophils. During a diagnostic bronchoscopy, a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and the specimen shows the presence of larvae as depicted in the image.

 

 

Identify the causative organism based on the BAL findings.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including the use of immunosuppressive therapy (steroids), nocturnal cough, eosinophilia, and the identification of rhabditiform larvae in the BAL, is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • Strongyloides are ovoviviparous nematodes that typically infect humans through skin contact with contaminated soil.
  • The larvae migrate to the intestines, where they can mature into adults and perpetuate autoinfection by penetrating intestinal or perianal skin to re-enter the bloodstream, leading to a widespread infection, particularly in immunocompromised hosts. Respiratory symptoms can arise when larvae migrate through the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli.

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ï»¿ï»¿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ï»¿ï»¿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ï»¿ï»¿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma caninum: This causes cutaneous larva migrans, often manifesting as creeping eruption due to skin penetration, not typically associated with respiratory symptoms or found in BAL specimens.

 

Option B. Capillaria philippinensis: Infection with this organism leads to severe diarrhea and malabsorption; it does not typically present with respiratory symptoms or eosinophilia in BAL.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, which primarily causes enteric symptoms like nocturnal itching around the anus, not respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strongyloides stercoralis should be considered in patients with eosinophilia and worsening pulmonary symptoms, especially if immunosuppressed.
  • Identification of rhabditiform larvae in clinical specimens such as BAL can confirm the diagnosis. Ivermectin is the preferred treatment for strongyloidiasis, addressing both intestinal and disseminated infections effectively.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with blisters and persistent oral ulcers for the past month. Recently, she developed blisters on her back, most of which burst spontaneously. Physical examination reveals ulcers on her palate and buccal mucosa, and numerous erythematous erosions with a few intact flaccid bullae on her upper back. Gentle pressure on an intact area of skin causes the top layer to slough off. Immunofluorescence examination of a skin biopsy shows an Immunoglobulin-G pattern as seen below. Which of the following is the most likely target of these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desmogleins

 

  • This patient's presentation is indicative of pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder.
  • Key clinical features of pemphigus vulgaris include painful oral ulcers and flaccid bullae on the skin that easily rupture, leading to erosions.
  • A critical diagnostic clue is the positive Nikolsky sign, where gentle pressure on the skin causes the epidermis to separate.
  • The pathophysiology of pemphigus vulgaris involves autoantibodies directed against Desmogleins, which are components of desmosomes.
  • Desmosomes are structures that provide adhesion between keratinocytes in the epidermis.
  • The immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies in pemphigus vulgaris bind to desmogleins, disrupting cell adhesion and leading to the formation of intraepidermal bullae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemidesmosomes: Hemidesmosomes anchor the basal cells of the epidermis to the basement membrane. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes are seen in bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Basement membrane antigens: Antibodies targeting components of the basement membrane are also associated with bullous pemphigoid. In this condition, blisters are typically tense rather than flaccid.

 

Option D. Proteins in dermal papillae: This option is incorrect as antibodies against proteins in the dermal papillae are found in dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition characterized by grouped vesicles and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by autoantibodies against Desmogleins, leading to flaccid bullae and mucosal involvement.
  • A positive Nikolsky sign is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A team of clinical researchers is planning a study to determine the effectiveness of a new cardiovascular drug in reducing mortality and morbidity in patients with chronic heart failure. The study aims to establish the drug's efficacy and safety in a large, diverse population. Based on the phases of clinical trials, which phase would this study most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase 3

 

  • Phase 3 of a clinical trial is often referred to as an efficacy trial because it is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger and more diverse patient population compared to earlier phases.
  • These trials typically involve several hundred to several thousand participants and are usually randomized and controlled, often comparing the new intervention against a placebo or an existing standard treatment.
  • The goal is to confirm the therapeutic benefits observed in Phase 2 trials and to gather sufficient evidence to demonstrate that the drug's benefits outweigh its risks.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Phase 1: Trials focus primarily on assessing the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients, not efficacy.

 

Option B.  Phase 2:  Trials aim to evaluate both safety and preliminary efficacy but do so in a relatively smaller patient population and are not definitive efficacy trials.

 

Option D. Phase 4:  Trials are post-marketing studies that monitor long-term safety and effectiveness in the general population after a drug has been approved for use.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly after exercise. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of muscle enzymes, indicating muscle damage. Further evaluation reveals that she has a metabolic disorder affecting the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria. Which molecule is primarily responsible for transporting fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carnitine

 

  • The primary molecule responsible for transporting long-chain fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane is carnitine.
  • Fatty acids must be transported into the mitochondria for β-oxidation, which is essential for energy production, especially in muscle cells.
  • Carnitine plays a crucial role in this process by forming acyl-carnitine complexes, which can be shuttled across the inner mitochondrial membrane via the carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.
  • Once inside the mitochondria, the fatty acids are released and converted back to their CoA derivatives for β-oxidation. Defects in this transport system can lead to muscle weakness and fatigue due to the impaired ability to utilize fatty acids for energy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyl carrier protein: This protein is involved in the synthesis of fatty acids in the cytoplasm, not in the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria. It carries the growing fatty acid chain during the synthesis process.

 

Option B. LCAT (Lecithin–cholesterol acyltransferase): LCAT is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of lipoproteins in the blood, specifically in the conversion of free cholesterol into cholesteryl ester for transport in high-density lipoproteins (HDL). It does not play a role in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria.

 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: While cholesterol transporters are involved in the movement of cholesterol within cells and across membranes, they are not involved in the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria for β-oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria, where they undergo β-oxidation for energy production.
  • Defects in carnitine-mediated transport can lead to muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly after exercise, due to the impaired ability to utilize fatty acids for energy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her first trimester presents to her obstetrician with concerns about an infection she believes she gets from her child (see picture). The mother is concerned about the impact of the infection on her pregnancy. Which viral infection, contracted during early pregnancy, is known to mimic erythroblastosis fetalis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection can mimic erythroblastosis fetalis, particularly when a pregnant woman is infected during early pregnancy.
  • This condition is characterized by severe fetal anemia, leading to heart failure and hydrops fetalis, similar to the effects of erythroblastosis fetalis, which is typically caused by blood group incompatibility between the mother and fetus.
  • Parvovirus B19 is also associated with several other clinical presentations, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), transient aplastic crisis, and pure red cell aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV: While HSV can cause serious congenital infections, it does not typically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: Known for causing infectious mononucleosis, EBV has not been associated with conditions mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: This family of viruses, including enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, generally causes respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms, not conditions that mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnant women, Parvovirus B19 infection should be considered if symptoms similar to those of erythroblastosis fetalis are observed, as it can lead to severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.
  • Proper prenatal care and monitoring are crucial for early detection and management of potential complications from this infection.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease is undergoing a renal function evaluation. As part of the assessment, various substances are measured to determine their renal clearance rates. Which of the following substances is expected to have the highest renal clearance rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAH (Para-aminohippuric acid)

 

  • Renal clearance refers to the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of a particular substance by the kidneys per unit time.
  • The clearance rate of different substances varies depending on their filtration, reabsorption, and secretion in the nephron.
  • PAH (Para-aminohippuric acid) has the highest renal clearance rate among the substances listed because it is both freely filtered by the glomerulus and actively secreted by the renal tubules.
  • Consequently, nearly all of the PAH that enters the kidneys is excreted in the urine.
  • PAH clearance is often used to estimate renal plasma flow, as its clearance rate approaches the total renal plasma flow when secreted maximally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine: Creatinine is freely filtered and minimally secreted by the renal tubules. Its clearance rate is used to estimate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), but it is still lower than that of PAH due to the lack of significant tubular secretion.

 

Option B. Inulin: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, making its clearance rate equivalent to the GFR. However, its clearance rate is lower than that of PAH because it is not secreted by the renal tubules.

 

Option D. Urea: Urea is freely filtered by the glomerulus and partially reabsorbed by the renal tubules, resulting in a lower clearance rate compared to inulin, creatinine, and PAH.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • PAH (para-aminohippuric acid) has the highest renal clearance rate because it is both freely filtered and actively secreted by the renal tubules, making it an effective marker for estimating renal plasma flow.

choices.text: Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is responsible for the proofreading of mRNA during translation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase

 

  • Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases are the enzymes responsible for attaching the correct amino acid to its corresponding tRNA molecule.
  • This process includes a crucial proofreading step to ensure high fidelity in protein synthesis.
  • The enzyme first activates the amino acid and then transfers it to the corresponding tRNA.
  • If an incorrect amino acid is attached, the synthetase can hydrolyze the incorrect aminoacyl-tRNA before it is used in translation, thereby ensuring the accuracy of protein synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA polymerase: This enzyme is involved in the transcription of DNA into RNA. It does not play a role in the proofreading of mRNA during translation.

 

Option C. Leucine zipper: This is a structural motif involved in the dimerization and DNA binding of certain transcription factors. It is not involved in the proofreading process during translation.

 

Option D. DNA polymerase: This enzyme is responsible for synthesizing new strands of DNA during DNA replication. It has proofreading capabilities to correct errors during DNA synthesis but is not involved in the translation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases are crucial for ensuring the accuracy of protein synthesis by proofreading and correcting errors during the attachment of amino acids to their corresponding tRNA molecules.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a complaint of a foul-smelling, bloody vaginal discharge mixed with mucus. Physical examination reveals a necrotic growth in the cervix extending into the lateral parametrium. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chemoradiation

 

  • The patient presents with advanced cervical cancer characterized by necrotic growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement.
  • This stage of cervical cancer often extends beyond the cervix and may involve surrounding tissues, necessitating a multimodal treatment approach.
  • Lateral parametrium involvement indicate that Cancer is in Stage 2B, for which treatment is Chemoradiation.
  • Chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy, is the standard of care for locally advanced cervical cancer.
  • Chemotherapy sensitizes the cancer cells to radiation, enhancing the effectiveness of the treatment and improving local control and survival rates.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT:

 

• Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1

• Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chemotherapy: While chemotherapy alone can be part of the treatment for cervical cancer, it is typically used in metastatic disease or as a palliative treatment. In cases of locally advanced disease with parametrium involvement, chemoradiation is preferred because it provides better local control and survival benefits compared to chemotherapy alone.

 

Option C. Surgery: Surgical options, such as radical hysterectomy, are generally reserved for earlier stages of cervical cancer (up to stage IB1). For advanced stages with parametrium involvement, surgery alone is not sufficient and is not typically recommended due to the extent of disease spread and the higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option D. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation, is used as part of the overall radiation treatment but is not sufficient as a standalone therapy for advanced cervical cancer. It is often combined with external beam radiation therapy as part of the chemoradiation regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced cervical cancer involving the lateral parametrium, chemoradiation is the standard treatment approach, combining the benefits of both chemotherapy and radiation to improve treatment outcomes.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 40 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with complaints of lower abdominal pain. She reports that she has been experiencing contractions for the past 3 hours. Which of the following findings would confirm that she is in active labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • Active labor is characterized by regular, painful uterine contractions that result in progressive cervical dilatation and effacement.
  • The transition from early labor to active labor is typically marked by cervical dilatation of more than 5 cm and complete effacement.
  • This stage indicates that the labor is progressing and the cervix is opening adequately to allow for the passage of the baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of membranes: Rupture of membranes, also known as the breaking of the water, can occur before or during labor but does not alone confirm active labor. It is one of the signs of labor onset but not a definitive indicator of active labor.

 

Option B. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: When the fetal head is 5/5 palpable, it indicates that the head is still high in the pelvis, suggesting that labor may not be very advanced. In active labor, the fetal head is usually lower and engaged in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This pattern of contractions is not sufficient to confirm active labor. Active labor is characterized by more frequent and longer-lasting contractions that are strong enough to cause cervical changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active labor is confirmed by the presence of more than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement, indicating significant progression of labor and readiness for delivery.

questions.text: A 19-year-old obese man presents to the clinic with a progressively darkening rash on the back of his neck over the past six months (see image). The patient has a history of insulin resistance and is at risk for developing type 2 diabetes. A skin biopsy of this lesion is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperkeratosis

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition often associated with obesity and insulin resistance, characterized by dark, velvety patches of skin, typically in body folds and creases.
  • The biopsy of these lesions usually reveals hyperkeratosis, which is the thickening of the stratum corneum.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spongiosis: This indicates intercellular edema in the epidermis, commonly seen in eczema and not characteristic of acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option B. Acantholysis: This is the loss of connections between keratinocytes, often seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, not acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Hypergranulosis: This is the increased thickness of the stratum granulosum, often seen in lichen planus, not in acanthosis nigricans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans, associated with obesity and insulin resistance, is characterized by hyperkeratosis on biopsy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of vaginal discomfort and the presence of thick, white vaginal secretions. She reports no history of similar symptoms and has not used any antibiotics recently. A sample of the discharge is obtained for laboratory analysis to identify the causative agent. Which of the following media is most appropriate for the rapid identification of the likely species causing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

  • CHROMagar is particularly useful for the rapid identification of different species of Candida, which are common causes of vaginal candidiasis.
  • This medium utilizes chromogenic substrates that, when metabolized by the enzymes specific to different Candida species, change color, allowing for easy differentiation.
  • Candida albicans, for instance, typically produces green colonies on this medium.
  • The ability of CHROMagar to provide visual differentiation within 1-4 days of incubation makes it a valuable tool in clinical settings for prompt diagnosis and treatment planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Used primarily for the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans, not Candida species.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: An anaerobic medium suitable for the growth of obligate anaerobes. Here, the supplements include Vit. K and hemin

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Candida albicans on SDA shows creamy white colonies; but it lacks the specificity like how CHROMagar differentiate between species based on colony color.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHROMagar is the preferred medium for identifying Candida species in clinical specimens due to its rapid and distinct color differentiation of species, crucial for effective treatment of candidiasis.
  • Diagnosis of Candida

 

 

    1. Candida albicans—gram-positive oval budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae;
    2. Candida albicans on SDA shows creamy white colonies;
    3. CHROMagar showing colonies of various Candida species producing different colors (e.g. light-green color by C. albicans, red arrow);
    4. Candida albicans shows positive germ tube test (arrow showing);
    5. Candida albicans shows thick walled chlamydospores (arrow showing)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of tingling sensations and needle-like pain in her limbs. She also experiences numbness, episodes of decreased visual acuity, and spastic paralysis. Her symptoms worsen with heat exposure, such as during hot showers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiple sclerosis

 

  • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.
  • Patients with MS commonly present with paresthesia (tingling sensations, pins, and needles), hypesthesia (numbness), optic neuritis (decreased visual acuity and color perception), and unilateral or bilateral limb weakness.
  • Other symptoms include spastic paralysis, gait disturbances, positive Babinski's sign, facial weakness, vertigo, hearing loss, bladder dysfunction, Lhermitte's sign (shooting pain down the back on neck movement), and Uhthoff's sign (worsening of neurological symptoms with heat exposure, such as hot showers).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extramedullary spinal cord compression: Patients with extramedullary spinal cord compression usually present with back pain aggravated in the supine position, tingling or electric sensation along the back and upper and lower limbs upon flexion or extending the neck. Loss of pain, vibration, and proprioception is common. Extensor plantar reflex may be seen in significant compression, and deep tendon reflexes may be brisk.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: Patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) present with fasciculations, muscle cramps, distal weakness and atrophy, bulbar palsy (dysarthria, dysphagia, respiratory compromise), spasticity, increased reflexes, flexor spasms, and pseudobulbar effects (inappropriate laughing, crying, yawning).

 

Option D. Subacute combined degeneration: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients with SACD present with loss of vibration sense and proprioception, paresthesia, unsteady gait due to sensory ataxia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy (can present as blurring of vision), and psychiatric manifestations such as irritability, severe dementia, or frank psychosis. SACD myelopathy is diffuse rather than focal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis presents with paresthesia, hypesthesia, optic neuritis, limb weakness, spastic paralysis, and symptoms worsened by heat exposure (Uhthoff's sign).

questions.text: Identify the condition in which this murmur is heard:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary regurgitation

 

  • Pulmonary regurgitation is a condition where the pulmonary valve does not close properly, causing blood to flow back into the right ventricle from the pulmonary artery. This results in an early diastolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncomplicated Mitral stenosis: The murmur of mitral stenosis is a mid diastolic rumbling murmur with a presystolic accentuation heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position.

 

Option B. Mitral valve prolapse: It is often associated with a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur heard best at the apex.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, best heard at the right second intercostal space and often radiating to the carotids. The murmur is typically described as a crescendo-decrescendo or diamond-shaped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pulmonary regurgitation is identified by a decrescendo diastolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border.

choices.text: She is likely to develop shingles.
She is vulnerable to contracting chickenpox.
She possesses immunity against shingles.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student is evaluated for potential exposure to chickenpox after a classmate is diagnosed with the disease. She is unsure of her vaccination status and undergoes serologic testing for varicella-zoster virus, which returns negative. What does this imply about her susceptibility to varicella-related conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) She is vulnerable to contracting chickenpox.

 

  • This is correct. The negative serologic test indicates the absence of varicella-zoster virus IgG antibodies, meaning she has not been previously exposed to the virus nor has she been vaccinated against it. Consequently, she is susceptible to contracting chickenpox for the first time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is likely to develop shingles:  Incorrect, Shingles typically develops in individuals who have had chickenpox in the past as the virus reactivates. A negative antibody test suggests that she has never been infected with the varicella-zoster virus, thus she is not at risk for shingles currently.

 

Option C. She possesses immunity against chickenpox: Incorrect, the negative test result explicitly shows she does not have immunity to chickenpox, as she lacks the necessary antibodies.

 

Option D. She possesses immunity against shingles: Incorrect, without prior infection or vaccination (as evidenced by the absence of antibodies), there is no immunity against shingles either.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Varicella Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG):

 

  • Given within 72 hours of exposure
  • Dose: 1.25–5.0 mL intramuscularly
  • Reserved for:
    • Immunosuppressed contacts of acute cases
    • Newborn contacts

choices.text: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a long history of intermittent purulent ear discharge, hearing loss, and occasional vertigo. On otoscopic examination, there is a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida and granulation tissue in the attic region. A CT scan of the temporal bone shows erosion of the ossicles and extension into the mastoid antrum. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mastoidectomy with cholesteatoma removal

 

  • This is the appropriate treatment for attico-antral type chronic otitis media.
  • The presence of a retraction pocket, granulation tissue, ossicular erosion, and extension into the mastoid antrum indicates cholesteatoma, which requires surgical intervention to remove the disease and prevent complications like intracranial spread or hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion is typically used for acute otitis media or otitis media with effusion. It is not appropriate for attico-antral type of chronic otitis media, which involves cholesteatoma and requires more extensive surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Conservative management with topical antibiotics: While topical antibiotics can help manage secondary infections, they are not sufficient for treating cholesteatoma, which is the underlying cause in attico-antral type chronic otitis media. Surgical removal of the cholesteatoma is necessary to prevent further complications.

 

Option D. Systemic antibiotics and observation: Systemic antibiotics may temporarily address secondary bacterial infections but do not treat the underlying cholesteatoma. Observation alone is inadequate for this condition, as it can lead to serious complications if not surgically managed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Attico-antral type chronic otitis media, characterized by cholesteatoma and erosion of ossicles, requires surgical management with mastoidectomy and cholesteatoma removal to prevent further complications and preserve hearing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female planning a cruise vacation seeks medication to prevent motion sickness during her trip. Which of the following drugs is commonly used for the prophylaxis of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

  • Promethazine is an antihistamine with strong antiemetic and anticholinergic properties, making it highly effective for preventing and treating motion sickness.
  • It acts on the central nervous system to reduce the symptoms of nausea and vertigo associated with motion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetirizine: This is a second-generation antihistamine mainly used for allergy symptoms. It is less sedating and generally not used for motion sickness due to its limited efficacy in this condition.

 

Option C. Misolastine: This drug appears to be a misspelling or incorrect reference, as it is not recognized as a standard medication.

 

Option D. Loratadine:  Another second-generation antihistamine primarily used for allergic conditions. Like cetirizine, it does not have significant antiemetic effects and is not suitable for motion sickness prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Promethazine is the drug of choice among the options for the prophylaxis of motion sickness due to its effectiveness in reducing nausea and vertigo symptoms.
  • This makes it a suitable choice for travelers prone to motion sickness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old hospital employee presents to the clinic with complaints of tingling and numbness in his hands and feet. He also notes that his scalp has become dry and scaly. He has been undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis with anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) for the past 4 months. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Vitamin B6

 

  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency is commonly associated with the use of isoniazid, a key drug in the treatment of tuberculosis.
  • Isoniazid can interfere with the metabolism of vitamin B6, leading to a deficiency.
  • Symptoms of vitamin B6 deficiency include peripheral neuropathy, which manifests as tingling and numbness in the extremities.
  • Additionally, a deficiency in vitamin B6 can result in dermatitis, characterized by dry and scaly skin, which explains the patient's scalp condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Deficiency in vitamin B12 typically leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms such as numbness and tingling, but it is less commonly associated with dry and scaly skin. Furthermore, vitamin B12 deficiency is not specifically linked to the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2: Also known as riboflavin, deficiency in vitamin B2 can cause symptoms such as sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), inflammation and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue), and a moist, scaly skin inflammation (seborrheic dermatitis). However, it is not typically linked to peripheral neuropathy or tuberculosis treatment.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1: Deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine) leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which can include symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it is not specifically associated with dry and scaly skin or tuberculosis treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients undergoing treatment for tuberculosis with isoniazid are at risk for vitamin B6 deficiency, which can present as peripheral neuropathy and dermatitis.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the emergency department with respiratory distress and bradycardia. After initiating positive pressure ventilation for 30 seconds, the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute. What is the ideal ratio of chest compressions to ventilations for this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3:1

 

  • The ratio of compressions to ventilation in the resuscitation of the newborn is 3:1 (90 compressions and 30 breaths in one minute).
  • This specific ratio is used for neonatal resuscitation because the primary cause of cardiovascular collapse in newborns is usually a compromise in gas exchange.
  • Effective resuscitation aims to restore adequate gas exchange and circulation simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30:2: This ratio is commonly used for adult cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)

 

Option B. 15:1: This ratio is not standard for any age group in CPR guidelines and would not be appropriate for neonatal resuscitation.

 

Option D. 15: 2: This ratio is used in pediatrics CPR with 2 rescuers

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, the ideal compression-to-ventilation ratio is 3:1.
  • This is crucial for effectively addressing the primary issue of compromised gas exchange in newborns.

choices.text: Large grafts can be harvested

questions.text: All are advantages of split thickness skin grafting except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Less graft contracture

 

  • This is NOT an advantage of split thickness skin grafts.
  • Contrary to full-thickness skin grafts, split thickness grafts are more prone to secondary contracture due to the lesser amount of dermis taken.
  • This makes it unsuitable for use over sites where cosmesis is desirable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Good graft uptake: This is an advantage of split thickness skin grafts because they consist of the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis, allowing for better integration with the recipient site if it's well-vascularized.

 

Option B. Reusable donor site: The donor site from where the split thickness skin graft is taken can heal and be reused for future grafts because it only involves a portion of the dermis, allowing for the possibility of re-harvesting if necessary.

 

Option D. Large grafts can be harvested: Because split thickness skin grafts involve less of the dermis, larger areas of skin can be harvested as grafts compared to full-thickness grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Split thickness skin grafts offer several benefits, such as good uptake, the potential to reuse the donor site, and the ability to harvest large grafts.
  • However, they are more susceptible to contraction limiting their use in areas of cosmesis, which is not an advantage of this grafting method.

choices.text: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma treated with surgical excision
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma treated with radiotherapy
Inverted papilloma treated with endoscopic resection
Rhinoscleroma treated with antibiotics and surgical debridement

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with recurrent severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction. On examination, a mass is visualized in the nasopharynx. Imaging confirms a highly vascular tumor extending into the pterygopalatine fossa and infratemporal fossa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and the primary treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma treated with surgical excision

 

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but highly vascular tumor that typically occurs in adolescent males.
  • It presents with recurrent severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction.
  • The tumor is confirmed through imaging, which often shows extension into the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae.
  • The primary treatment is surgical excision, often preceded by preoperative embolization to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma treated with radiotherapy: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor usually seen in adults and associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. It typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and neck masses. Treatment primarily involves radiotherapy, not surgical excision.

 

Option C. Inverted papilloma treated with endoscopic resection: Inverted papilloma is a benign tumor of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses. It presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and possibly epistaxis. Treatment is endoscopic resection, but it does not typically involve the extensive vascular nature or extension seen in JNA.

 

Option D. Rhinoscleroma treated with antibiotics and surgical debridement: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with nasal obstruction, crusting, and sometimes epistaxis. Treatment involves antibiotics and surgical debridement. The presentation and imaging characteristics are distinct from JNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a benign but highly vascular tumor in adolescent males, presents with recurrent severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction, and is primarily treated with surgical excision, often preceded by preoperative embolization.

choices.text: Weight loss > 10% of birth weight
Sleeping for 2-3 hours after breast feeding
Decreased urine output (< 5-7 times/ day)

questions.text: Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in newborn are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sleeping for 2-3 hours after breast feeding

 

  • This is the correct option. A baby should sleep for 2-3 hours after breast feeding.
  • This is an indicator of adequate breast feeding.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Weight loss > 10% of birth weight: Weight loss greater than 10% of birth weight is a clear indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in a neonate.

 

Option C. Inconsolable crying: Inconsolable crying and increased hunger are signs that the baby might not be getting enough milk. This could be due to insufficient milk production or poor breastfeeding techniques.

 

Option D. Decreased urine output (< 5-7 times/day): Decreased urine output, defined as urinating less than 5-7 times per day, is a significant indicator of inadequate breastfeeding. It suggests that the baby is not receiving sufficient fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

• Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding include weight loss greater than 7-10% of birth weight, delayed passage of stools (less than 4 times/day), decreased urine output (urinating less than 5-7 times/day), hypernatremic dehydration and inconsolable crying.

questions.text:
Dr. Sara, Epidemiologist is preparing for a community vaccination drive in a rural region with a high incidence of Japanese Encephalitis (JE). As part of the preparations, she conducts a training session for the healthcare team on the proper handling and administration of the JE vaccine. She emphasizes the importance of maintaining the vaccine's efficacy post-reconstitution. Dr. Sara asks her team how long the reconstituted JE vaccine can be safely stored and used during the drive.

What is the maximum time that the reconstituted JE vaccine should be kept before it must be discarded?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 hours

 

  • This is correct. The reconstituted Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine should be used within 4 hours of preparation.
  • This timeframe ensures the vaccine's efficacy and safety, as the stability of the active components can be compromised beyond this period.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In endemic areas, JE vaccine is given to all children aged 1-15 years age
  • JE vaccine is not used below the age of 6 months
  • Cell culture based Live attenuated freeze dried vaccine (SA-14-14-2 strain):
    • Diluent - phosphate buffer saline (PBS); 
    • Dose under NIS – 0.5 ml subcutaneous in left upper arm @ 9 m & 16-24 m under NIS [upto 15 years]

choices.text: Long QT Syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with episodes of palpitations and dizziness. His ECG is shown below. Identify the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome

 

  • WPW syndrome is characterized by the presence of a delta wave on the ECG, which represents early ventricular depolarization due to an accessory pathway.
  • It is also associated with a short PR interval and a wide QRS complex.
  • Patients with WPW syndrome can present with palpitations, dizziness, and sometimes syncope due to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Long QT Syndrome: Long QT syndrome is characterized by a prolonged QT interval on the ECG, which can lead to torsades de pointes and sudden cardiac death.

 

Option C. Brugada Syndrome: Brugada syndrome is identified by a characteristic pattern on the ECG, including coved-type ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3.

 

Option D. Atrial Fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on the ECG

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WPW syndrome is diagnosed by the presence of a delta wave, short PR interval, and wide QRS complex on an ECG.
  • It is crucial to identify this condition as it predisposes patients to tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A 62 years old man presented to the surgery OPD with swelling below the left ear since 8 months. The swelling is insidious in onset, gradually increasing in size. There is history of 20 packs per/year of smoking. On examination, a firm, non-tender swelling is noted. A parotid gland tumour is suspected. The tumor shows hot spot on nuclear imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenolymphoma

 

  • Adenolymphoma also known as Warthin's tumor, it is a benign salivary gland neoplasm that commonly presents in the fifth to seventh decade and has a strong association with smoking. It is characterized by oncocytic epithelial cells and a lymphoid stroma. Warthin's tumor is the only salivary gland neoplasm that consistently takes up Tc 99m pertechnetate, appearing as a hot spot on the scan, making it the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic carcinoma:  This is a malignant salivary gland tumor that most commonly affects the minor salivary glands, particularly the hard palate. It typically does not demonstrate a hot spot on Tc 99m pertechnetate scans.

 

Option C. Acinic cell tumour:  This is a malignant tumor that arises from the acinar cells of the salivary glands, usually the parotid gland. It is typically slow-growing but does not show a hot spot on Tc 99m pertechnetate scans.

 

Option D. Pleomorphic adenoma:  This is a type of salivary gland tumor that seen in 30-60-year age group, without any association with smoking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenolymphoma (Warthin's tumor) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with a smoking history and a firm, non-tender swelling in front of the ear, especially when a Tc 99m pertechnetate scan shows a hot spot, indicative of the high mitochondrial content of oncocytes.

choices.text: Drug C is a competitive antagonist.
Drug C is more potent than Drug A.
Drug B is more potent than Drug A.
Drug B is a competitive antagonist.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presents with moderate hypertension and is prescribed multiple antihypertensive medications. After the initial treatment, the physician needs to decide whether to intensify the treatment with a new drug. The dose-response curves for various drugs are reviewed to assess their efficacy and potency. Which statement correctly interprets the dose-response curve characteristics of the medications shown in the graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Drug B is a competitive antagonist.

 

In the graph:

 

  • Potency and Efficacy: Potency refers to the amount of drug needed to produce an effect, and efficacy refers to the maximum effect a drug can produce. The graph shows that Drug B and Drug A achieve the same maximum effect, indicating similar efficacy. Potency is suggested by the leftward position of the dose-response curve; Drug A's curve is more leftward than Drug B, indicating that Drug A is more potent.
  • Type of Inhibition: Drug B causes a rightward shift in the dose-response curve of Drug A without decreasing the maximum effect, which is characteristic of competitive antagonists. They compete with the agonist (Drug A) for the same binding site but do not affect the maximum effect of the agonist.
