Drug C causes a downward shift in the dose-response curve, indicating a decrease in efficacy, characteristic of non-competitive antagonists, which bind to a different site and reduce the maximum possible effect of the agonist.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug C is a competitive antagonist:  Incorrect because Drug C does not shift the dose-response curve of Drug A to the right, which is required for a competitive antagonist.

 

Option B. Drug C is more potent than Drug A: Incorrect because Drug C's curve is to the right of Drug A, indicating it is less potent, not more potent.

 

Option C. Drug B is more potent than Drug A: Incorrect because Drug B's curve is to the right of Drug A's curve, indicating Drug A is more potent than Drug B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug B acts as a competitive antagonist, shifting the dose-response curve rightward without affecting the maximum efficacy, while Drug C, showing reduced efficacy and no shift in potency, is a non-competitive antagonist.
  • Remember the rule: leftward and upward shifts in dose-response curves suggest increased potency and efficacy, respectively.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman was undergoing a routine check-up when the radiologist noticed gallstones on USG. However, the patient says that there have been no complaints so far and she is asymptomatic. The stone measures 4cms. What will be your treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

  • This is usually the treatment of choice for symptomatic gallstones.
  • However, prophylactic cholecystectomy may be recommended for asymptomatic gallstones in certain situations, such as when the stones are larger than 3 cm, which can increase the risk of gallbladder cancer, particularly in certain ethnic groups or geographical locations with a high prevalence of gallbladder cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conservative Management: For patients with asymptomatic gallstones, conservative management is often the initial approach. Intervention is generally not recommended unless the patient becomes symptomatic or develops complications.

 

Option C. Medical Dissolution Therapy: This treatment option involves the use of oral bile acids to dissolve cholesterol gallstones. It is typically reserved for patients who cannot undergo surgery, but the stones must be cholesterol-based, and the process is slow and has a high recurrence rate. It is not typically used for stones as large as 4 cm.

 

Option D. ERCP and Stone Removal: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is generally not used for stones in the gallbladder itself but is a treatment option for stones in the common bile duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with asymptomatic gallstones measuring 4 cm, the treatment of choice is generally conservative management, but prophylactic laparoscopic cholecystectomy may be considered due to the increased risk of complications associated with larger stones.
  • Medical dissolution therapy is not typically effective for large stones, and ERCP is not indicated unless there is choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female, recently returned from a trip to sub-Saharan Africa, presents to the emergency department with a high fever, chills, and severe headaches. A blood smear is taken as part of the diagnostic workup due to her travel history and symptoms suggestive of malaria. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear shown?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) P. falciparum

 

  • The peripheral blood smear image demonstrates ring forms within erythrocytes, characterized by the presence of double chromatin dots, resembling stereo headphones, which is distinctive of P. falciparum.
  • This species can cause severe malaria and is known for its capability to infect a larger number of erythrocytes, including those of any age, which might explain the observation of multiple rings within a single erythrocyte.
  • These rings are typically small and delicate, often adhering to the erythrocyte membrane, creating what is described as an 'accolé' appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: The parasites of P. malariae typically form larger and more compact ring forms in older erythrocytes and do not show the double chromatin feature.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Characterized by oval or fimbriated erythrocytes, with infected cells often showing enlargement and distinct Schüffner's stippling, not typically showing multiple ring forms per cell.

 

Option D. P. vivax: While this species also shows enlargement of infected erythrocytes and Schüffner's stippling, the rings do not usually exhibit the 'double chromatin' appearance and are generally fewer in number per cell compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • P. falciparum infection is identified by distinctive double chromatin dots within ring forms in erythrocytes, often with multiple infections per cell, indicative of the species' high virulence and severity potential.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to manage and mitigate severe complications associated with this malaria species.

 

Morphological forms of malaria parasites –

questions.text: Which of the following medications can be effectively used to treat both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pramlintide

 

  • Pramlintide is an adjunct treatment for patients with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes. It is a synthetic analogue of amylin, a hormone that is co-secreted with insulin by pancreatic beta cells.
  • Pramlintide aids in glycemic control by slowing gastric emptying, suppressing glucagon secretion postprandially, and enhancing satiety.
  • This multifaceted approach makes it suitable for use in both types of diabetes to control postprandial glucose spikes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Primarily indicated for type 2 diabetes, it is used to decrease hepatic glucose production and improve insulin sensitivity but is not typically prescribed for type 1 diabetes.

 

Option B. Repaglinide: Targets postprandial blood glucose levels by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, mainly used in type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin:  A DPP-4 inhibitor that enhances the incretin system, increasing insulin release in response to meals. It is effective in type 2 diabetes but does not address the insulin deficiency found in type 1 diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pramlintide provides a unique therapeutic benefit for patients managing both type 1 and type 2 diabetes, particularly for those struggling with postprandial glucose control, making it a valuable addition to insulin therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with spirometry results showing an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 after salbutamol nebulization and an FEV1 of 44% of the predicted value. According to the GOLD criteria, how should this patient's COPD be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe COPD

 

  • Severe COPD is identified by an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 and an FEV1 between 30% and 49% of the predicted value.
  • The patient’s spirometry results match this category, confirming severe COPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild COPD: According to the GOLD criteria, mild COPD is classified as FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted. The given patient's FEV1 is significantly below 80%, ruling out this option.

 

Option B. Moderate COPD: Moderate COPD is defined by FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 between 50% and 79% of the predicted value. The patient’s FEV1 is below 50%, making this classification incorrect.

 

Option D. Very severe COPD: Very severe COPD is characterized by an FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 and an FEV1 of less than 30% of the predicted value. The patient's FEV1 is higher than 30%, so this category does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria classify COPD severity based on spirometry results: Mild (Stage I) FEV1 ≥80%, Moderate (Stage II) FEV1 50-79%, Severe (Stage III) FEV1 30-49%, and Very Severe (Stage IV) FEV1 <30%.
  • Recognizing these stages helps guide treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of a loss of taste sensation. She has been experiencing this issue for the past month. As part of the diagnostic workup, a biopsy of her tongue was performed, and the histological section is shown below. Identify the type of papillae from the given histological section:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Circumvallate papillae

 

  • The histological section shows large, round structures with a central taste bud-rich area, which are characteristic of circumvallate papillae.
  • These papillae are located at the back of the tongue and are surrounded by a trench-like structure.
  • They contain numerous taste buds that are involved in the sensation of taste. Circumvallate papillae are distinct due to their large size and the presence of von Ebner's glands at their base, which secrete a serous fluid that helps in taste sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungiform Papillae: These papillae are smaller, mushroom-shaped structures located mainly on the tip and sides of the tongue. They contain fewer taste buds compared to circumvallate papillae and do not have the large trench-like structures seen in the image.

 

Option C. Filiform Papillae: These are the most numerous papillae on the tongue and are slender, conical, and do not contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in the mechanical aspect of moving food around the mouth and do not resemble the structure shown in the histological section.

 

Option D. Foliate Papillae: These papillae are located on the lateral aspects of the tongue and are characterized by multiple parallel ridges. They contain taste buds but their structure is different from the circumvallate papillae shown in the image.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Circumvallate papillae are large, round papillae located at the back of the tongue, characterized by a central area rich in taste buds and surrounded by a trench-like structure, distinguishing them from other types of papillae on the tongue.

questions.text: In the management of osteoporosis, a 60-year-old female patient is considering medication options that affect both bone formation and resorption. Which of the following medications is known to influence both decreased bone resorption and increased bone formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strontium ranelate

 

  • Strontium ranelate is unique among osteoporosis treatments as it has a dual mode of action: it simultaneously decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation.
  • This dual activity helps to rebalance the bone remodeling process, which is crucial in the treatment of osteoporosis to both reduce the risk of fractures and promote bone health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ibandronate: This is a bisphosphonate that primarily reduces bone resorption. It binds to bone minerals and inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, but it does not promote bone formation.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: An analog of parathyroid hormone, teriparatide primarily stimulates bone formation. It activates osteoblasts, which are bone-forming cells, but does not have a direct effect on reducing bone resorption.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: This hormone helps reduce bone resorption. It is used in osteoporosis treatment to slow down the bone loss but does not have a significant effect on increasing bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strontium ranelate offers a comprehensive approach to managing osteoporosis by both reducing bone resorption and enhancing bone formation, making it a valuable treatment option for patients needing intervention on both fronts of bone remodeling.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with swollen knee joints and non-blanching rashes on his legs as seen in the picture. Urine examination reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, the boy exhibits typical signs and symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP).
  • HSP is a type of small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by the presence of a purpuric rash, as well as arthritis and abdominal pain.
  • Additionally, approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal complications that can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE can cause a wide variety of symptoms including a characteristic malar rash, arthritis, and renal involvement (such as proteinuria and hematuria). However, the typical non-blanching rash and specific association with recent upper respiratory infections point more towards HSP in this case.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia with petechiae or purpura, but it does not typically cause renal involvement like hematuria or proteinuria. Moreover, the platelet levels in this boy are normal, which is not consistent with ITP.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause systemic symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and skin changes like livedo reticularis. However, it is less common in children and does not typically present with the classic purpuric rash and joint involvement seen in HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis commonly affecting children, characterized by purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal involvement such as hematuria and proteinuria.
  • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by typical findings and normal platelet levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with pain in his right ear. On examination, there is no visible infection or trauma. The patient mentions that the pain sometimes radiates to his jaw and neck. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the pain in the ear?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

  • The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), supplies sensation to the anterior and superior parts of the auricle and the external acoustic meatus.
  • It is commonly involved in referred pain to the ear from the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), explaining why the patient experiences pain radiating to the jaw and neck.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Greater auricular nerve: The greater auricular nerve is derived from the cervical plexus (C2 and C3). It provides sensation to the skin over the parotid gland, mastoid process, and part of the auricle. While it supplies part of the ear, it is less likely to be associated with pain radiating to the jaw and neck.

 

Option C. Lesser occipital nerve: The lesser occipital nerve also originates from the cervical plexus (C2). It supplies the skin on the posterolateral aspect of the head and neck, but it does not significantly contribute to the innervation of the ear. Therefore, it is unlikely to be the source of ear pain.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (CN X) supplies the auricular branch (Arnold's nerve), which innervates posterior part of the external auditory canal and the concha of the auricle. However, involvement of the vagus nerve typically presents with symptoms like cough or gag reflex rather than isolated ear pain radiating to the jaw and neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is responsible for supplying sensation to the anterior and superior parts of the auricle and the external acoustic meatus, and can cause referred pain to the ear from the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

choices.text: Tree in bud appearance
Crazy paving appearance
Signet ring appearance
Traction bronchiectasis with lung fibrosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a chronic cough and recurrent respiratory infections undergoes a CT scan of the chest to evaluate for bronchiectasis. Which of the following CT findings is least likely to be associated with bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crazy paving appearance

 

  • "Crazy paving appearance" on a CT scan refers to the presence of thickened interlobular septa and intralobular lines superimposed on a background of ground-glass opacity, creating a pattern reminiscent of irregularly laid paving stones.
  • This finding is more commonly associated with other lung conditions such as pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, acute interstitial pneumonia, and certain types of infections or non-infectious pneumonitis. It is not typically associated with bronchiectasis.

 

 

Crazy paving appearance

 

 

Crazy paving

 

Other Options:

 

The other CT findings are more characteristic of bronchiectasis:

 

Option A. Tree in bud appearance: This pattern is seen in bronchiectasis and represents dilated bronchioles filled with mucus or inflammatory material, often seen in endobronchial spread of infection.

 

 

Option C. Signet ring appearance: This is a classic finding in bronchiectasis and is seen when the diameter of the bronchus is larger than that of the accompanying pulmonary artery.

 

 

Option D. Traction bronchiectasis with lung fibrosis: Traction bronchiectasis occurs in the setting of lung fibrosis, where the scarring pulls the bronchial walls open, causing dilation. It can be seen in association with bronchiectasis, especially when there is underlying lung damage or fibrosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The crazy paving pattern on CT is not typically associated with bronchiectasis.
  • It suggests other lung pathologies like pulmonary alveolar proteinosis or acute interstitial pneumonia.
  • Classic CT findings in bronchiectasis include the tree in bud appearance and the signet ring appearance.
  • Traction bronchiectasis can occur in the context of lung fibrosis.

choices.text: Activation of cell cycle arrest

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the pancreas, and subsequent biopsy confirms pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene. What is the primary effect of this KRAS mutation in pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promotion of cell proliferation

 

  • The KRAS proto-oncogene encodes a protein involved in regulating cell division, differentiation, and apoptosis.
  • Mutations in KRAS lead to its constitutive activation, resulting in continuous signaling for cell proliferation.
  • This unchecked cell growth is a key factor in the development and progression of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
  • The mutated KRAS protein activates downstream pathways, such as the MAPK/ERK pathway, which promotes cellular proliferation and tumorigenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of Angiogenesis: KRAS mutations primarily drive cell proliferation rather than inhibiting angiogenesis. While KRAS can influence angiogenesis indirectly by promoting the production of growth factors, its main role in cancer is to promote cell growth and division.

 

Option C. Activation of Cell Cycle Arrest: KRAS mutations result in the opposite effect; they prevent cell cycle arrest and promote continuous cell cycle progression, leading to uncontrolled cell division.

 

Option D. Stimulation of Apoptosis: KRAS mutations do not stimulate apoptosis. Instead, they typically inhibit apoptotic pathways, allowing cancer cells to survive and proliferate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mutations in the KRAS proto-oncogene lead to the promotion of cell proliferation by constitutively activating signaling pathways that drive cell growth and division, which is a critical mechanism in the development of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

choices.text: Biopsy to rule out squamous cell cancer of lung
ANCA for diagnosis of vasculitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of chronic sinusitis and ulcerative lesions in the nasopharynx. He also reports hemoptysis and has nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs, as well as recent onset of renal dysfunction. What is the most important investigation to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ANCA for diagnosis of vasculitis

 

  • The patient’s presentation of chronic sinusitis, ulcerative nasopharyngeal lesions, pulmonary nodules with cavitation, and renal dysfunction is highly indicative of Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis.
  • GPA is a form of systemic vasculitis that commonly involves the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), particularly cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targeting proteinase-3, are highly specific for GPA.
  • Testing for ANCA is crucial for the diagnosis and helps distinguish GPA from other conditions with similar presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MDR Test for Tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can present with lung cavitations and sometimes renal involvement, it does not typically present with chronic sinusitis and nasopharyngeal ulcers. The specific combination of symptoms in this patient is more suggestive of GPA than tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Biopsy to Rule Out Squamous Cell Cancer of Lung: Although lung cancer can present with cavitary lung lesions, it is less likely to cause chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, and renal failure. The clinical presentation strongly suggests a systemic vasculitis rather than malignancy.

 

Option D. Culture for Fungal Infection: Fungal infections can cause cavitary lung lesions, but the combination of chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, and renal dysfunction is more indicative of a vasculitic process like GPA rather than a fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with chronic sinusitis, ulcerative nasopharyngeal lesions, cavitary lung nodules, and renal dysfunction, ANCA testing is essential for diagnosing Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), a form of vasculitis that affects these organ systems.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with symptoms of dehydration due to acute diarrhea. The doctor prescribes reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS). What is the sodium composition in the reduced-osmolarity ORS recommended for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 75 mmol/L

 

  • The sodium composition in the reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is 75 mmol/L.
  • This composition helps in effectively treating dehydration caused by diarrhea while minimizing the risk of hypernatremia and improving water absorption.

 

Note :

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sodium composition in reduced-osmolarity ORS is 75 mmol/L.
  • This formulation is designed to optimize rehydration while minimizing the risk of electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypernatremia.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was rushed to the emergency department after a severe crush injury to his leg sustained in a workplace accident. He has significant muscle damage and laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium (K+) level of 5.5 mEq/L. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur to the resting membrane potential in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less negative

 

  • An elevated serum potassium level, known as hyperkalemia, affects the resting membrane potential of cells.
  • Normally, the resting membrane potential is maintained by the difference in potassium concentration inside and outside the cell.
  • When extracellular potassium levels increase, the gradient across the cell membrane decreases, leading to a less negative (more depolarized) resting membrane potential.
  • This change can increase the excitability of neurons and muscle cells, potentially leading to arrhythmias or other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. No change: This option is incorrect because an increase in serum potassium concentration will definitely affect the resting membrane potential by making it less negative. The resting membrane potential is sensitive to changes in extracellular potassium levels.

 

Option C. First becomes more positive, then negative: This sequence does not accurately describe the typical response to hyperkalemia. While severe hyperkalemia can eventually lead to cellular dysfunction and potentially reverse the effects, the initial and primary change in resting membrane potential due to increased serum potassium is a more positive value.

 

Option D. Becomes more negative: This is incorrect because an increased serum potassium level would reduce the potassium gradient across the cell membrane, leading to a less negative resting membrane potential. A more negative resting membrane potential would occur with hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperkalemia results in a less negative resting membrane potential due to the decreased potassium gradient across the cell membrane, leading to increased cell excitability.

choices.text: Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary
Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse. After fitting her with a pessary, what is the first step to check if the pessary is adequately retained?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

  • The Valsalva maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, which can simulate the forces that might dislodge the pessary during normal daily activities.
  • If the pessary stays in place during the Valsalva maneuver, it is likely to be adequately retained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: While discomfort might indicate that the pessary is too large or incorrectly positioned, the absence of discomfort does not necessarily mean that the pessary is adequately retained. Comfort is important, but it is not the primary method to check retention.

 

Option C. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard method to check for adequate retention of a pessary. Proper fitting involves ensuring the pessary is comfortably positioned without significant gaps that would allow for easy displacement.

 

Option D. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: Voiding can help assess if the pessary is causing any obstruction or discomfort during urination, but it is not the first step to check for adequate retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first step to check if a pessary is adequately retained after fitting is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver.
  • This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, which helps determine if the pessary remains in place under stress conditions.

choices.text: Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium
Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of chronic alcohol use. He has abstained from alcohol for three days and is now experiencing irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. His vital signs are notable for tachycardia and hypertension. On physical examination, he is tremulous and diaphoretic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium

 

  • The patient’s symptoms—irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, altered sensorium, tachycardia, hypertension, tremors, and diaphoresis—are consistent with Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium (also known as delirium tremens).
  • These symptoms typically occur after abrupt cessation of heavy, chronic alcohol use and are severe manifestations of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: This condition is characterized by confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia, resulting from thiamine deficiency due to chronic alcohol use. The absence of these specific symptoms makes it less likely.

 

Option C. Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder: This involves sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, but without the history of chronic alcohol use and withdrawal context. The patient's symptoms align more with withdrawal.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: This condition can present with psychotic symptoms, but it occurs while the person is still consuming alcohol, not after a period of abstinence. The overall clinical picture fits better with Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%.
  • The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with facial swelling and decreased urine output. Her parents report that she had a sore throat and fever about two weeks ago. On physical examination, she has periorbital edema and elevated blood pressure. Urinalysis shows cola-colored urine and RBC casts. Laboratory tests reveal low C3 levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) typically presents with hematuria (cola-colored urine), oliguria, facial swelling (periorbital edema), and hypertension.
  • It usually follows a streptococcal throat or skin infection by 1-3 weeks and is associated with low C3 levels and the presence of RBC casts in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal Change Disease: Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. It does not commonly present with hematuria, cola-colored urine, or a history of recent infection.

 

Option C. IgA Nephropathy: IgA nephropathy often presents with recurrent episodes of hematuria, typically following mucosal infections, such as those of the upper respiratory tract, but the hematuria usually coincides with the infection rather than following it by weeks. Normal C3 levels are usually found.

 

Option D. Nephrotic Syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome presents with severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and generalized edema. It does not typically present with hematuria or low C3 levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is often preceded by a streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat or impetigo.
  • Key features of PSGN include hematuria (cola-colored urine), oliguria, periorbital edema, hypertension, low C3 levels, and RBC casts in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and hypercalciuria. Urine analysis is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be revealed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isomorphic RBCs

 

  • Hematuria in the context of hypercalciuria is often due to conditions such as nephrolithiasis (kidney stones) or hypercalciuria-associated damage to the renal tubules.
  • In these conditions, the red blood cells (RBCs) found in the urine are typically isomorphic, meaning they have a uniform appearance. This contrasts with glomerular causes of hematuria, where RBCs are dysmorphic due to passage through the glomerular basement membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC casts: RBC casts are typically indicative of glomerulonephritis or other glomerular diseases. The presence of casts suggests that the RBCs originate from the glomeruli. Given the context of hypercalciuria and likely nephrolithiasis, RBC casts are less likely.

 

Option C. Nephrotic range proteinuria: Nephrotic range proteinuria (defined as protein excretion of >3.5 grams per day) is associated with nephrotic syndrome, which includes conditions like minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, and membranous nephropathy. It is not typically associated with hypercalciuria and nephrolithiasis.

 

Option D. Eosinophiluria: Eosinophiluria is typically associated with allergic interstitial nephritis or certain types of vasculitis. It is not a common finding in hypercalciuria or nephrolithiasis-related hematuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a patient with hematuria and hypercalciuria, urine analysis is most likely to reveal isomorphic RBCs, which are typically associated with conditions like nephrolithiasis or hypercalciuria-induced renal damage.
  • This contrasts with RBC casts, which suggest a glomerular origin for the hematuria.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents at 7 weeks of gestation and expresses her desire to terminate the pregnancy. Which of the following combinations of drugs is used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

  • Mifepristone 200mg is administered orally on day 1.
  • The minimum recommended interval between mifepristone & misoprostol is 24 hours.
  • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14.
  • The combination of Misoprostol and Mifepristone is the most commonly used regimen for medical termination of pregnancy up to 10 weeks of gestation.
  • Mifepristone is an antiprogestin that blocks the effects of progesterone, a hormone necessary for pregnancy maintenance, leading to detachment of the pregnancy.
  • Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog that induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. This combination is highly effective and is the standard regimen for early medical abortion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin, not used for medical termination of pregnancy. It is commonly used for hormone replacement therapy or as a contraceptive, but it does not aid in the termination process.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: While Methotrexate can be used in combination with Misoprostol for medical termination, it is less common than the Mifepristone and Misoprostol regimen. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that disrupts cell division, but it is not the preferred method due to its slower action and higher risk of side effects.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone does not have a role in the medical termination of pregnancy. The combination of Mifepristone and Misoprostol is preferred for its effectiveness and safety profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of Misoprostol and Mifepristone is the standard and most effective regimen for medical termination of pregnancy up to 10 weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Vasopressin is the vasopressor of choice
Empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated within 1 hour of recognition.
Target a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of at least 65 mmHg.
Low molecular weight heparin is recommended for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of COPD has been admitted for septic shock. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this patient is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vasopressin is the vasopressor of choice

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The first-line vasopressor recommended for septic shock is norepinephrine, not vasopressin.
  • Vasopressin may be added to norepinephrine to raise mean arterial pressure (MAP) or reduce norepinephrine dosage, but it is not used as the primary vasopressor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated within 1 hour of recognition: This statement is correct. Early initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics is critical in the management of septic shock to cover a wide range of potential pathogens and improve patient outcomes. This should be done as soon as septic shock is recognized, ideally within the first hour.

 

Option C. Target a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of at least 65 mmHg: This statement is correct. The target MAP for patients with septic shock is at least 65 mmHg to ensure adequate tissue perfusion and oxygenation. Maintaining this target helps prevent organ dysfunction and supports overall patient stabilization.

 

Option D. Low molecular weight heparin is recommended for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism: This statement is correct. Patients with septic shock are at increased risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to immobility and the hypercoagulable state induced by sepsis. Prophylactic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is recommended to prevent VTE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the management of septic shock, norepinephrine is the first-line vasopressor, not vasopressin.
  • Early administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, targeting a MAP of at least 65 mmHg, and prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism with low molecular weight heparin are key components of effective treatment.

questions.text:
Match the following: Monitors (Column A) and their common sites of monitoring (Column B): 

 

Column A

  1. Invasive blood pressure monitoring
  2. Neuromuscular blockade monitoring
  3. Central venous cannulation
  4. Noninvasive blood pressure monitoring

 

Column B

  1. Ulnar nerve
  2. Brachial artery
  3. Right internal jugular vein
  4. Radial artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-c, 4-b

 

 Explanation:

 

1-d - Invasive blood pressure monitoring is commonly performed via the radial artery.

2-a - Neuromuscular blockade monitoring is often assessed at the ulnar nerve.

3-c Central venous cannulation is typically done via the right internal jugular vein.

4-b- Non-invasive blood pressure monitoring is most commonly performed using the brachial artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Invasive blood pressure is typically monitored through the radial artery, neuromuscular blockade through the ulnar nerve, central venous cannulation via the right internal jugular vein, and non-invasive blood pressure through the brachial artery.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male has come with massive retracted, chronic, irreparable rotator cuff tear. What will be best line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty

 

  • Reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA) is a specialized type of shoulder replacement surgery designed for patients with massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears and associated shoulder dysfunction.
  • In RSA, the normal configuration of the shoulder joint is reversed, with the glenoid component placed on the humerus and the humeral component placed on the scapula.

 

 

Conventional shoulder arthroplasty VS Reverse shoulder arthroplasty

 

  • Reverse shoulder arthroplasty is considered the treatment of choice for patients with massive retracted, chronic, irreparable rotator cuff tears who have failed conservative management and are not candidates for tendon transfer or traditional shoulder arthroplasty.
  • RSA relies on the deltoid muscle to provide stability and function, bypassing the need for intact rotator cuff tendons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative: Conservative management typically involves non-surgical interventions aimed at managing symptoms and optimizing function without surgical intervention. This may include physical therapy, activity modification, pain management, and possibly corticosteroid injections. Conservative management may be considered in patients who are not surgical candidates due to medical comorbidities, patient preference, or when the tear is not causing significant pain or functional impairment. However, in cases of massive retracted, chronic, irreparable rotator cuff tears, conservative management alone is unlikely to provide satisfactory long-term outcomes, especially in patients experiencing severe pain or functional limitations.

 

 

Option B. Tendon Transfer: Tendon transfer surgery involves transferring a healthy tendon from one area of the body to replace a damaged or deficient tendon in another area. In the context of a massive irreparable rotator cuff tear, tendon transfer procedures may involve using intact tendons from nearby muscles to restore shoulder function and stability. Tendon transfer surgery may be considered in cases of irreparable rotator cuff tears, particularly when the tear is not too severe or retracted, and there is sufficient muscle function and tendon quality to support the transfer. However, in cases of massive retracted tears with significant muscle atrophy and tendon degeneration, tendon transfer may not be feasible or may provide suboptimal outcomes.

 

Option C. Shoulder Arthroplasty: Shoulder arthroplasty, or shoulder replacement surgery, involves replacing all or part of the damaged shoulder joint with artificial components made of metal, plastic, or ceramic. This can include total shoulder arthroplasty (TSA), which replaces both the humeral head and the glenoid, or partial shoulder arthroplasty (hemiarthroplasty), which replaces only the humeral head. Shoulder arthroplasty may be considered in patients with irreparable rotator cuff tears who have intact glenoid anatomy and preserved joint function. However, in cases of massive retracted tears with severe rotator cuff deficiency, traditional shoulder arthroplasty may not be suitable due to the inability of the remaining musculature to provide adequate stability and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In case of a massive, chronic, retracted and an irreparable rotator cuff tear, reverse shoulder arthroplasty is the treatment line of choice because this surgical technique relies on the deltoid muscle for the stability of the joint and not on the rotator cuff.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with a sudden-onset speech disorder. Neurological evaluation reveals that he has difficulty repeating spoken words, but his language comprehension and production are intact. MRI reveals a lesion in the left hemisphere involving the superior temporal gyrus and the posterior part of the left frontal lobe. Which of the following white matter tracts is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arcuate fasciculus

 

  • The arcuate fasciculus is a critical white matter tract that connects Wernicke's area (located in the superior temporal gyrus) with Broca's area (located in the posterior part of the left frontal lobe).
  • This connection is essential for the coordination of language comprehension and production.
  • Damage to the arcuate fasciculus results in conduction aphasia, characterized by difficulty in repeating spoken words while maintaining intact language comprehension and production.
  • This specific impairment occurs because the arcuate fasciculus is responsible for transmitting information between these two key language areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior longitudinal fasciculus: Although this tract connects various parts of the brain, it does not specifically link Wernicke's and Broca's areas and is not primarily involved in the direct transfer of language-related information.

 

Option B. Anterior commissure: This tract connects the two cerebral hemispheres but is mainly associated with olfactory and some interhemispheric visual functions, not directly with language processing.

 

Option D. Inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus: This white matter tract connects the occipital and frontal lobes, playing a role in visual processing and integration rather than in language.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The arcuate fasciculus is the white matter tract that connects Wernicke's area and Broca's area, facilitating the coordination between language comprehension and production.
  • Lesions in this tract lead to conduction aphasia, which is characterized by impaired repetition of spoken words despite intact comprehension and production.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to a medical facility following an alleged sexual assault. The medical officer collects a specimen from the perianal area for analysis to confirm the presence of seminal fluid, which is crucial for the investigation. The specimen is subjected to a test that results in the formation of yellow needle shaped crystals, indicative of a specific component of seminal fluid. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

Barberio’s test – 

 

Reagent: Picric Acid.

Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland) Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options  

 

Option B. Florence test: 

Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O

Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)

Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose

Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid

Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride

Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective -

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

  • Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. After a thorough evaluation, a hysterectomy is performed. The specimen retrieved is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leiomyoma

 

  • The image shows a well-circumscribed, whorled mass within the uterine wall, characteristic of leiomyoma.
  • Leiomyomas can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure symptoms.
  • Leiomyomas, also known as fibroids, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus.
  • They are the most common uterine neoplasms and are often found in women of reproductive age, though they can persist into menopause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents with irregular, friable, and often hemorrhagic areas within the endometrial cavity. The gross appearance is typically not nodular like that seen with leiomyomas.

 

Option B. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis involves the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, leading to a diffusely enlarged uterus with a trabeculated or spongy appearance. It does not present with distinct nodules as seen in leiomyomas.

 

Option D. Endometrial polyp: Endometrial polyps are localized overgrowths of the endometrial tissue and appear as soft, fleshy masses within the uterine cavity. They do not have the firm, nodular appearance seen in the provided specimen.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Leiomyomas are the most common benign tumors of the uterus and typically present with abnormal uterine bleeding and a characteristic whorled pattern on gross pathology.

choices.text: Complement levels (C3, C4)
Anti-double stranded DNA (Anti-dsDNA)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with fever, oral ulcers, and a rash as shown in the image. She also reports photosensitivity and joint pain. Which of the following investigations would be LEAST likely to help in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Factor

 

  • The clinical presentation of fever, oral ulcers, a rash (likely a malar or butterfly rash), photosensitivity, and joint pain suggests a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease characterized by a wide range of symptoms and multisystem involvement. The following investigations are commonly used to establish a diagnosis of SLE:
  1. Complement levels (C3, C4) - Complement levels are often measured in patients with suspected SLE. Low levels of C3 and C4 are indicative of disease activity and immune complex deposition, which are common in SLE.
  2. Anti-double stranded DNA (Anti-dsDNA) - Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE and are commonly used in the diagnosis and monitoring of disease activity.
  3. Anti-Smith (Anti-Sm) - Anti-Sm antibodies are another highly specific marker for SLE, though they are less commonly found than anti-dsDNA antibodies.
  • Rheumatoid factor (RF) is an antibody that is primarily associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and is not commonly used in the diagnosis of SLE. While RF can be present in a small percentage of SLE patients, it is not a primary diagnostic test for SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement levels (C3, C4): Complement levels (C3 and C4) are often low in active SLE due to their consumption in immune complex-mediated inflammation. Thus, measuring these levels is helpful in diagnosing SLE.

 

Option B. Anti-double stranded DNA (Anti-dsDNA): Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE and are a key marker in its diagnosis. These antibodies also correlate with disease activity, particularly with renal involvement.

 

Option C. Anti-Smith (Anti-Sm): Anti-Sm antibodies are highly specific for SLE and, while not as commonly found as anti-dsDNA antibodies, their presence is highly indicative of SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid factor (RF) is primarily associated with rheumatoid arthritis and is not commonly used in the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • In contrast, complement levels (C3, C4), anti-double stranded DNA (Anti-dsDNA), and anti-Smith (Anti-Sm) antibodies are valuable investigations for diagnosing SLE.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child from a rural farming community presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and noticeable weight loss over the past few months. His family uses untreated well water and often plays in the surrounding fields. A stool sample is collected and analyzed under microscopy, revealing eggs as shown in the image.

 

 

Which helminthic infection, commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in the stool as shown in the above image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

  • The image displays the distinctive egg of Trichuris trichiura, also known as the whipworm.
  • These eggs are notable for their barrel shape with bipolar mucus plugs and an unsegmented ovum.
  • The outer shell is triple-layered, with the external layer often appearing brown due to staining.
  • These eggs are typically passed in an unembryonated state in the stool and are diagnostic of whipworm infection.
  • Transmission occurs through soil contaminated with human feces, highlighting the importance of sanitation and hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Ancylostoma duodenale and C. Necator americanus – The eggs are Oval shaped, Non-bile stained, colorless; Surrounded by thin, hyaline shell; Clear space between the egg shell and ovum. Egg is segmented with four blastomeres.

 

Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are morphologically indistinguishable; hence stool culture is done for species identification. Both are differentiated by their filariform larva grown in culture.

 

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides are larger and surrounded by a thick mammillated, albuminous coat; Crescentic space at poles; Bile stained; Floats in saturated salt solution

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichuris trichiura infection is diagnosed by the identification of its characteristic eggs in stool samples.
  • The condition can range from asymptomatic to severe, with symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and potential growth retardation in chronic cases.
  • Treatment involves anti-helminthic medications like mebendazole or albendazole.
